column3: The 5 steps to starting a club at your college
column4: ['Courtney Rozen', 'The University Of Texas At Austin', 'Varsity Tutors', 'Usa Today Network', 'Carol Alderman', 'Usa Today Network Josh Hafner Usa Today', 'Sam Lisker', 'Alexandra Samuels']
column5:
Want to make friends, reduce stress, and boost your resume? (Sounds amazing, doesnt it?) Then get involved in a campus extracurricular!

Chances are, you have a large selection to choose from: Many colleges  especially large universities  are home to hundreds of clubs. But if you cant find one thats just right for you, you may want to consider starting your own.

Starting a club can be a lot of work, especially in the beginning. But if you have a good idea, a dedicated following, and the motivation to make it work, your new club could become wildly popular.

If you are thinking of starting a club at your university, here are the five steps you need to take to make it a reality:

1. Check out other clubs

Even if youve gone through your colleges list of extracurriculars once, you should do so again if youre thinking about starting a club. Not only is there no need to start a club that already exists, but youre also unlikely to get approval for a duplicate club.

So, its a smart idea to check and confirm that theres room for your new club before you invest your time and effort into trying to get it approved. Look online by searching for your universitys name plus clubs and activities.

2. Get university approval

Once youve checked that no similar club exists, its time to get university approval for your club. The approval process varies from college to college, so contact your universitys campus life or student activities office to find out what the process entails.

Usually, youll need to fill out paperwork or an online registration form. Some colleges also require youthe club founderto attend a one-on-one meeting with your universitys activities coordinator. At the meeting, the coordinator will likely ask for verification that you are a student and will describe the exact details you need to establish your club.

3. Find members

After getting approval for your club, its time to find members. First, double-check with your universitys activities coordinator that your new club gets listed in your universitys directory of extracurricular activities. Then, use social media to get the word about your club out quickly by creating a Facebook page, a Twitter handle, and perhaps even an Instagram account. Another good idea is to design and print flyers. Hang these up on available bulletin boards in your dorm building, dining hall, and library (just remember to get permission first if needed).

4. Set up a meeting schedule

After youve gotten some members, its time to set up a regular meeting schedule. How often your club meets depends on your activities, of course. Most clubs meet at least once a week.

Planning to meet on the same day (or days) at the same time each week helps make scheduling easier. It also makes it more likely that your members will show up at each meeting, since a steady schedule means theyll likely encounter fewer conflicts.

5. Elect leaders and establish rules

Effective clubs have leaders and rules. These can change each year, or each semester, depending on what you decide. Its important to establish some structure so your club can be sustained into the future (i.e. after you graduateyou wouldnt want to see it crumble the minute you leave!).

Often, most clubs have a president, vice president, secretary, and treasurer. Your clubs leadership structure should reflect the type of club you have and what you want to accomplish together.

Similarly, the rules of your club should be designed with your clubs purpose in mind. You might create a constitution with rules about club meeting structure, etiquette, leadership policies, and so on.

Now that youve got this handy guide, dont be afraid to pursue that idea of yours!

Erica Cirino is a contributing writer for Varsity Tutors , a live learning platform that connects students with personalized instruction to accelerate academic achievement.

column3: OMG! Cajun food on the Mississippi coast
column4: ['Est March', 'A M', 'Special For Usa Today', 'Larry Olmsted']
column5:
The Darwells Sampler is shown with bowls stirred up and bread ready for dipping. (Photo: Larry Olmsted)

The scene: It doesnt get much more laid back than Darwells Cafe, a true roadside joint that is literally on the other side of the tracks. Oceanfront Beach Boulevard is the main drag in these parts, running along Americas longest manmade beach, but Darwells sits off Railroad Street, which runs parallel several blocks inland, along the tracks. Long Beach, a small neighbor of Biloxi, is home to the University of Southern Mississippi, and was once known as the Radish Capital of the World. The area is now a major tourism destination, with Biloxi and Gulfport full of marinas, museums, golf courses and casinos. But while Darwells is very close to these, you would never drive by or find it if you were not looking for it. Nonetheless, lots and lots of people come looking for it, and Darwells, though much bigger than it looks, is routinely jammed with a long line out the door, especially on weekends.

The main building has several inside dining rooms, and there is a vast outdoor dining area full of large tables. At maximum capacity it can hold a couple of hundred folks and often does, with live music nightly, indoor or out. As soon as you walk in you are at the counter, where the normal greeting is to ask whether its your first time, and if you say yes, a sample of their signature crawfish etouffee is handed to you. You order at the counter, which has handwritten specials and menu items hanging over it and on the walls on either side. Then you are handed a number, make your way to the iced tea stand to grab a beverage (its BYOB for adult beverages), then find a table. Food is delivered to you with the same ultra-friendly service that pervades the place.

Darwells is funky, and the walls are covered with whimsical art, caricatures, song lyrics and cartoon-like drawings, mostly by the owners father Papa D, who is known to wander around and spontaneously draw caricatures of customers on Styrofoam cups for instant keepsakes, or pull out a harmonica and start jamming with the band. Colorfully painted guitars hang on the walls, endless strings of Christmas lights dangle from the ceilings, and it is a place of wonder at every turn. Even the otherwise barren concrete floors are whimsically painted with colorful designs. The exception is the front dining room, by the counter, which is covered with more conventional framed article clippings and awards, and a signed poster-sized photo of TV personality Guy Fieri. He brought his show Diners, Drive-Ins and Dives here specifically for the crawfish etouffee, which he loved so much he included the recipe in his DDD Cookbook.

Reason to visit: Crawfish etouffee, shrimp creole, crab melt sandwich

The food: If the food at Darwells was merely okay it would still be a great spot, because the place is so colorful and the staff so friendly. Bu the food is better than okay, it is fantastic, made to order all the time, with a focus on the fresh wild caught seafood of the Gulf of Mexico, the source of some of the worlds best shrimp, along with excellent oysters and blue crab. While most seafood, especially shrimp, sold in U.S. restaurants is imported, often from foreign fish farms that use drugs and chemicals, these are the real deal, wild, natural and sweet, and it shows. But it is not just the ingredients, its the cooking that makes the food here amazing,

The menu is broad and ranges from barbecue to po boys, but by far the two most popular dishes are the Darwells Sampler and the crab melt sandwich, followed by larger portions of the individual components of the sampler. This consists of three bowls, crawfish etouffee, shrimp creole and gumbo, with a healthy side of toasted buttered French bread. The crab melt is a layer of fresh blue crab meat stacked on ham and Swiss, served warm on thick grilled Texas toast with a side of au jus for dipping and a bottle of thick yellow Vidalia onion vinaigrette, or house sauce, which is highly recommended as a sandwich garnish by staff. They are right, it is delicious. There are a variety of typical Southern sides, but portions are already large and as the woman at the counter said, Skip the slaw  no one comes to Darwells for veggies.

What they come for in droves is the etoufee, and it is awesome. This part of the Mississippi coast is close to New Orleans and heavily influenced by the same kind of Cajun and creole dishes, but in most places etouffee is reddish, while here it is a creamy mustard color, and comes topped with a healthy pile of blackened, spiced Gulf shrimp just for deliciousness sake. Owner Darwell Yeager III makes it entirely from scratch, going so far as to make his own crawfish stock, then adds healthy portions of butter and cream (the color) along with the so called Holy Trinity of Cajun and creole cuisine, celery, onion and bell pepper. There is also Old Bay crab seasoning, Cajun spice blend, garlic, flour and parsley, plus lots of local crawfish meat, a layer of white rice and the blackened shrimp, with a from-scratch house seasoning. The etouffee sauce is thick, creamy, rich and delicious, the seafood just makes it more so, and it is impossible to stop eating. The French bread served alongside is for mopping up every last drop. But as good as it is, the shrimp creole is even better, and just as to-the-very-last-drop addictive. For this dish the trinity gets sauteed in lots of butter with the same spice duo, plus healthy slices of andouille sausage, homemade shrimp stock, and tomato sauce, which is slow cooked into a delicious thick red mess. Some regulars order it as an entree over spaghetti, and Darwells is the kind of place where they will put together pretty much anything you ask for. The gumbo is also thick, from scratch, and very good, but the other two dishes on the sampler are so superlative it seems a little average in comparison.

Lots of people share the sampler and crab melt  we were the fifth couple that night to place this exact order, and it was still early. The sandwich is uniquely rich, creamy and meaty, crab and ham making an unlikely but successful combo. While already messy, it is worth slathering it with both the house sauce and au jus for a drippy, juicy taste fest.

The friendly staff, from the free samples to the smiles to the drink refills, add to a great experience. One of our waitresses told us she met her future husband here, got married here, had her reception here, and continues to love working at Darwells.

This is one of those places where it is truly hard to go wrong  if not impossible. Everything is bursting with flavor and freshness, and is spicy in a good way, not a hot way, with layer upon layer of complimentary tastes, as with the spicy blackened shrimp providing great contrast to the creamy, buttery etouffee, or the ham offsetting the crabmeat. Even the desserts, baked specifically for Darwells by a local pastry whiz, are great. Prices are very reasonable, portions big, smiles bigger, food delicious, and with the BYOB, it is a great spot to eat outside as a group with a couple of bottles of wine or beer, while enjoying music. Of the hundreds of Great American Bites eateries I have visited in the past five years, Darwells is among my very favorites.

Pilgrimage-worthy?: Yes  this is Southern Gulf cuisine at its very best, in a wonderful setting

Rating: OMG! (Scale: Blah, OK, Mmmm, Yum!, OMG!)

Price: $$ ($ cheap, $$ moderate, $$$ expensive)

Details: 127 East First Street, Long Beach; 228-868-8946; darwellscafe.com

Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/1paaWf2

column3: 13 rebound players to target in fantasy baseball
column4: ['Steve Gardner', 'Usa Today Fantasy Sports', 'Brian Polking', 'Tim Heaney', 'Cory Bonini', 'Hours Ago']
column5:
Buying low on previously disappointing players is one potential avenue to win your fantasy baseball league. This list of names will give you that opportunity in 2016.

1. OF Carlos Gomez, Houston Astros

Injuries hindered him throughout last year. The former first-round name in fantasy drafts ranks as one of our favorite undervalued players.

2. SP Garrett Richards, Los Angeles Angels

His strikeouts rebounded in the second half. The bargain ace should split the difference between 2014 (2.61 ERA, 8.75 K/9, 2.72 BB/9) and 2015 (3.65, 7.64, 3.30).

DRAFT GUIDE: Rankings, more

3. C Matt Wieters, Baltimore Orioles

Recovery from Tommy John surgery affects hitters, too. He should threaten 20 homers.

4. SP Michael Pineda, New York Yankees

Location issues are probably to blame for that 4.37 ERA. His peripherals (8.74 K/9, 1.18 BB/9) show hes better. Hes had swinging-strike rates of 11.4% or higher in each of his three full seasons. He lost 2012 and 2013 to injuries, and with the strength he has built up over the last two seasons, hes ready to put it all together.

5. SP Jeff Samardzija, San Francisco Giants

Hell enjoy taking his great skills from the American League and U.S. Cellular Field to the National League and AT&T Park.

6. SP Yordano Ventura, Kansas City Royals

After bouts with injuries and a demotion from the rotation, he came back and looked like an ace late in the year. At 25, he easily could build on those steps to become the ace that his velocity dictates.

7. OF Joc Pederson, Los Angeles Dodgers

Obviously, his 26-homer year was fueled by an awesome first half, before his horrid second half. Pederson should attempt to steal more bags this year, which will help offset a batting average that probably wont top .240. And you already know his power is legit.

8. SP Collin McHugh, Houston Astros

Another guy whos somewhere between 2014 (2.73 ERA, 9.14 K/9, 2.39 BB/9) and 2015 (3.89, 7.56, 2.34).

9. 2B/SS Starlin Castro, New York Yankees

Castro looked like his old self with a .295-6-31 second-half performance, with a .369-5-21 line in September/October. Now hell enjoy full-time work with home games at Yankee Stadium. He could threaten .300 with 15-plus homers.

Sleepers | busts

10. SP Julio Teheran, Atlanta Braves

He clubbed 23 homers in 2014 but felt a big drop in power with 10 last year, which came with a demotion to Class AAA. Though he hits a lot of ground balls, he has much more pop than last year showed. And with the fences coming in at Marlins Park, he should move back toward 20 taters.

column3: Can investing be less scary?
column5:
A stock trader works at the Frankfurt Stock Exchange in Frankfurt am Main, Germany, on Monday, May 10, 2010. (Photo: Mario Vedder, AP)

Q: Can investing be less scary?

A: Investors scored $16 trillion in wealth since the bull market started seven years ago. But making that money hasnt been easy.

Pullbacks and corrections routinely test the patience of investors and can make it a scary experience. The most recent pain investors had to deal with on the way to $16 trillion was a 15% drop from its high to its intraday low on Feb. 11, 2016. Even now, roughly 200 companies in the Standard & Poors 500 are down 20% or more from their highs since 2015.

Investors might be tempted to skip investing thinking its just too painful. But there are sound strategies that can help investors enjoy the gains, with less pain. Diversification is an overused strategy, but it works. By owning pieces of hundreds of stocks, you can boost the odds that you own some of the stocks that have rallied most - not just the ones still stuck in a bear market. Being patient helps, too. Short-term moves in the market are unpredictable. But investors who stay invested for years can avoid the temptation to panic sell. Above all, having an appropriate portfolio is critical. Few investors should be 100% exposed to stocks. Adding in bonds and an emergency fund help you keep your head so you can get your piece of the $16 trillion.

USA TODAY markets reporter Matt Krantz answers a different reader question every weekday. To submit a question, e-mail Matt at mkrantz@usatoday.com or on Twitter @mattkrantz.

Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/1pa1GaK

column3: 5 shot dead, 3 wounded at backyard party in Pennsylvania
column4: ['Doug Stanglin', 'Carolyn Mcatee Cerbin', 'Est March', 'A M', 'Carolyn Mcatee Cerbin Usa Today']
column5:
Five people were killed and three others injured when gunfire broke out at a backyard party in Wilkinsburg, east of Pittsburgh. USA TODAY

A woman reacts at the scene of a deadly shooting in Wilkinsburg, Pa., March 10, 2016. P (Photo: Michael Henninger, Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, via AP)

Five people were killed and three injured in an ambush-style shooting at a backyard party late Wednesday in Wilkinsburg, a working-class suburb east of Pittsburgh, police said.

Lt. Andrew Schurman of the Allegheny County homicide unit said four people were found dead at the scene and the fifth died at a local hospital. Two men were in critical condition and a woman was stable, according to police.

Police offered no motive for the shooting but said they were looking for two gunmen who barged into the cookout and opened fire.

I heard about 30 gunshots, it was just a constant, Jackie Johnson-Pendleton, a neighbor, told KDKA. When I came out, people were screaming and running and bodies were lying on the front porch. Peoples lives taken like that at the drop of a hat, its just insane and it needs to stop.

#BREAKINGNEWS: Police investigating deadly shooting in Wilkinsburg: https://t.co/IMXUkucZx1https://t.co/F4MqNWIzle  KDKA (@CBSPittsburgh) March 10, 2016

Schurman said said the shots were fired from two locations but police dont believe anyone at the party fired back.

"Partygoers appeared to try to run into the residence, at which point a person on the side or backyard adjacent to the residence fired at the back porch," police said in a statement. "All four of the individuals who died at the scene died on that back porch."

Police investigate the scene after a deadly shooting Wednesday, March 9, 2016, in Wilkinsburg, Pa. (Photo: Michael Henninger, AP)

As ambulances and police cars converged on the scene, neighbors gathered on the street, some of them sobbing and saying they lost family members, the Associated Press reported.

Kayla Alexander, a local resident, told WPXI-TV she was walking home when she heard two dozen shots and saw people running from the area. She said authorities weren't allowing her to get to her home on Franklin Avenue, a usually quiet street lined by two-story brick houses built in the early 1900s.

A woman is held back as police respond to the scene of a deadly shooting in Wilkinsburg, Pa., March 10, 2016. (Photo: Michael Henninger, Pittsburgh Post-Gazette via AP)

James Boyd, 70, has lived in a home three doors away from the shooting for 24 years. He told the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette that the gunfire went on for almost a minute.

I thought it was maybe the pipes bursting. But then we realized it was gunshots. Weve had trouble in this neighborhood before but never this close to home, Boyd said. Ive never seen anything like this before.

In 2001, the Allegheny County community of 15,800 people, was the scene of another fatal rampage when a gunman went on a lunchtime shooting spree at two fast-food restaurants, killing two people and wounding three, according to The New York Times. Ron Taylor, the 39-year-old gunman who left a suicide note, surrendered after a standoff and was later convicted. He is currently on death row in Pennsylvania.

Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/1phxAmh

column3: 3 dead, thousands flee as historic floods swamp South
column5:
Marcie Traylor rides in a boat after being rescued from the Pecan Valley Mobile Home community that was flooded because of Wednesday rains. Bossier Firefighter Cameron LaCoure was out helping as well as neighbors who volunteered their boats for rescues. (Photo: Henrietta Wildsmith/The Times))

Submerged roadways, backed-up sewers, stalled cars and flooded homes: The dramatic scenes in Shreveport, La., were being repeated Thursday in the South as historic flash flooding continued to pound the region.

Three people have been killed in Oklahoma, Texas and Louisiana since the deluge began earlier this week, and the heavy rain promises not to let up for at least another day.

In all, some areas will receive two feet of rain by the time the storm winds down Friday, the National Weather Service said. In addition to Louisiana, the hardest-hit state, parts of Arkansas, western Tennessee and southern Illinois will also be drenched by locally heavy rain Thursday, according to the weather service.

In Louisiana, 3,000 homes were under mandatory evacuations, FEMA said. At least 9,000 customers were without power, schools were closed in several parishes and many roads were closed.

Quickly rising floodwaters forced mandatory evacuations of neighborhoods near swollen tributaries. Louisiana Gov. John Bel Edwards called in the state National Guard to assist rescues by boat and in big military trucks.

There has been an awful lot of damage and a lot of people affected, Edwards said. Our thoughts and prayers and resources are with north Louisiana.

In Bienville Parish, a man drowned Wednesday afternoon when his vehicle was swept into a nearby creek as he attempted to drive across a flooded highway, the Weather Channel reported. Two people drowned in Oklahoma and Texas earlier in the week.

#Flood threat continues in parts of the South, an additional 8-12" possible for Lower MS River Valley..more on @AMHQpic.twitter.com/CVnwgoO0fC  The Weather Channel (@weatherchannel) March 10, 2016

Sharon Anderson, her three children and four grandchildren were rescued from her south Bossier Parish mobile home after rising water threatened to trap them, the Associated Press reported.

"This morning it was touching the bottom of the houses," she told the AP on Wednesday. "Now the steps on my back porch are under water and if you walk down the driveway, it's over the knee."

Residents of the Pecan Valley Mobile Home in south Bossier City boarded boats to travel through waist-high water. Evacuation was not mandatory for the communitys 1,000 residents, but manager LeeAnn Wells said more than 100 chose to flee the high waters.

Weve never had water like this before, Wells said.

Contributing: The Times, Shreveport, La.

The risk for severe flooding will last through Friday across the south-central US: https://t.co/Y689J5dFfPpic.twitter.com/ouetvzSxuN  AccuWeather.com (@breakingweather) March 10, 2016

Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/1parOT1

column3: Yahoo to start streaming NHL games
column5:
March 7: Colorado Avalanche goalie Semyon Varlamov made 37 saves to backstop the Avs to a 3-1 win over the Arizona Coyotes. (Photo: David Zalubowski, AP)

Yahoo is making a shift to the ice rink.

The media company announced Thursday a partnership with the National Hockey League to stream up to four games per week without requiring a cable subscription or authentication. The streams kick off March 11.

Users will also get access to condensed games, a 5-7 minute version of an NHL game focusing on the biggest moments, as well as countless post-game highlights.

"More and more people are finding their video experiences online, and that includes live and sports," said Adam Cahan, Yahoo's senior vice president of video.

Last year, Yahoo streamed its first live game from the National Football League, which drew 15 million viewers. The company also partnered with Major League Baseball on a "Game of the Day," and unveiled a deal last month with the PGA Tour for free, live coverage of golf events.

"Were going broadly across of all these sports to make sure we can bring unique experiences to our audience," says Cahan.

Although the majority of live sports experiences are available through cable TV subscriptions, more leagues are experimenting with live streaming. Nearly every game of the 2016 NCAA men's Division 1 basketball tournament will be available through live stream, while tech companies including Facebook, Amazon and Google have reportedly shown interest in streaming NFL games.

Follow Brett Molina on Twitter: @brettmolina23.

Oklahoma City Thunder PG Russell Westbrook had 25 points, 11 rebounds and 20 assists against the Los Angeles Clippers Wednesday, March 9. Westbrook is the first player with a 25-10-20 line since Los Angeles Lakers PG Magic Johnson did it in 1988.

Tip: Westbrook is averaging 24.3 points, 7.6 boards and 12.9 assists the last 10 games. He has elevated his game to another level this season and has shed the only concern fantasy owners had about his style of play prone to injuries. He's no worse than a top-five fantasy player.

column3: America's best bars for whiskey lovers
column5:
Novelist Raymond Chandler once wisely observed, There is no bad whiskey. There are only some whiskeys that arent as good as others. This is a philosophy that many Americans have adopted in recent years. Today, more brown booze-centric bars are popping up with grand selections of fine bottles.

According to Andrew Abrahamson, manager at LA's Seven Grand and director of Single Spirit Bars at 213 Hospitality, "Whiskey has experienced a rise culturally, not because anything has changed with what we've recently been so attracted to drinking, but because, as a society, we've returned to what we've been enjoying since 1776.

Its hard to remember the overly sweet cocktails of the 1980s and 90s when sipping a single malt scotch at Pints Pub in Denver. The few brief dark decades we were submitted to during the '80s and '90s (yes, and '70s...) can only be chalked up to a deviation from what the country really loved, not any kind of trend," Abrahamson says. "For over two centuries before, we loved and drank whiskey.

From the boozy tome of a menu at Seattles Canon to the extemporary collection of whiskey housed at Jack Rose in our nations capitol, click though the slideshow above to find some of the best whiskey bars in America.

column3: Stream Chuck Wicks new album Turning Point

column5:
Chuck Wicks makes accessible country music that resists formula. While I could see a lot of tracks on his new album, Turning Point, played on the radio, this is music that is moody, plaintive, and at times, dark.

Were streaming the album on FTW today in its entirety:

Wicks is also an actor who you might have seen on Nashville, and he used that clout to make the record he wanted to.

Turning Point is the record Ive been waiting my whole career to put out. Its a reflection of who I am as a singer/songwriter and how far Ive come as one as well.

column3: Stock futures up ahead of ECB meeting
Russell Westbrook put up a line we havent seen since Magic Johnson
column4: ['Charles Curtis', 'Luke Kerr-dineen', 'Nate Scott', 'Steven Ruiz', 'Nina Mandell', "Nate Scott Is A Writer Editor At Ftw Leading The Site's Culture Coverage He Likes Writing About Soccer Basketball Music Tv The Evils Of The Ocean"]
column5:
The rest of the Thunder may be a question mark, but Russell Westbrook and Kevin Durant are currently playing out of their minds.

Westbrook especially was outrageous for the Thunder in Wednesday nights win over the Clippers, putting up a triple double with 25 points, 20 assists and 11 rebounds.

Its been nearly 30 years since weve seen a game like that:

Westbrook is the first player with 25-10-20 since Magic in 1988. And Durant had his seventh straight 25-10-5 game, longest since Larry Bird.  Royce Young (@royceyoung) March 10, 2016

After the game, Durant said hed never seen a performance like Westbrooks. Not in real life, anyway.

NBA 2K, Durant said, when asked if hed ever seen anything like it. On rookie.

Durant had his own bit of history on Wednesday night as well, when he went his seventh consecutive game with at least 25 points, 10 rebounds and five assists. His company? Good.

Since the merger, only Larry Bird and @KDTrey5 have had 7 straight games with 25 Pts, 10 Reb, 5 Ast (@EliasSports) pic.twitter.com/pVSkaVtsCz  ESPN Stats & Info (@ESPNStatsInfo) March 10, 2016

I cant believe that these two are going to drag this team to the playoffs and potentially make a run. After these two and Serge Ibaka, theres no one that great on this team, and I still think they could potentially challenge the Warriors. Durant and Westbrook are that good. Its flabbergasting.

column3: 13 rebound players to target in fantasy baseball
column4: ['Steve Gardner', 'Usa Today Fantasy Sports', 'Brian Polking', 'Tim Heaney', 'Cory Bonini', 'Hours Ago']
column5:
Buying low on previously disappointing players is one potential avenue to win your fantasy baseball league. This list of names will give you that opportunity in 2016.

1. OF Carlos Gomez, Houston Astros

Injuries hindered him throughout last year. The former first-round name in fantasy drafts ranks as one of our favorite undervalued players.

2. SP Garrett Richards, Los Angeles Angels

His strikeouts rebounded in the second half. The bargain ace should split the difference between 2014 (2.61 ERA, 8.75 K/9, 2.72 BB/9) and 2015 (3.65, 7.64, 3.30).

DRAFT GUIDE: Rankings, more

3. C Matt Wieters, Baltimore Orioles

Recovery from Tommy John surgery affects hitters, too. He should threaten 20 homers.

4. SP Michael Pineda, New York Yankees

Location issues are probably to blame for that 4.37 ERA. His peripherals (8.74 K/9, 1.18 BB/9) show hes better. Hes had swinging-strike rates of 11.4% or higher in each of his three full seasons. He lost 2012 and 2013 to injuries, and with the strength he has built up over the last two seasons, hes ready to put it all together.

5. SP Jeff Samardzija, San Francisco Giants

Hell enjoy taking his great skills from the American League and U.S. Cellular Field to the National League and AT&T Park.

6. SP Yordano Ventura, Kansas City Royals

After bouts with injuries and a demotion from the rotation, he came back and looked like an ace late in the year. At 25, he easily could build on those steps to become the ace that his velocity dictates.

7. OF Joc Pederson, Los Angeles Dodgers

Obviously, his 26-homer year was fueled by an awesome first half, before his horrid second half. Pederson should attempt to steal more bags this year, which will help offset a batting average that probably wont top .240. And you already know his power is legit.

8. SP Collin McHugh, Houston Astros

Another guy whos somewhere between 2014 (2.73 ERA, 9.14 K/9, 2.39 BB/9) and 2015 (3.89, 7.56, 2.34).

9. 2B/SS Starlin Castro, New York Yankees

Castro looked like his old self with a .295-6-31 second-half performance, with a .369-5-21 line in September/October. Now hell enjoy full-time work with home games at Yankee Stadium. He could threaten .300 with 15-plus homers.

Sleepers | busts

10. SP Julio Teheran, Atlanta Braves

A knee ligament sprain cost him six weeks. With rebuilt lower-body strength, should return to 21-homer level from 2014. Batting average should fall somewhere between last two season-long figures of .278 and .231.

column3: Here's why Louis C.K. didn't want to promote 'Horace and Pete'
column5:
Louis C.K. (Photo: Screenshot via YouTube/ABC)

Remember back in January when Horace and Pete dropped, and we were all caught off guard?

Sure, Louis C.K. has released direct-to-consumer comedy specials via his website before, but a whole series that we knew nothing about? It's still pretty shocking.

The creator and writer of the show currently available online stopped by Jimmy Kimmel Live on Wednesday to give a little insight as to why he wanted to drop the show without any promotion.

"I just wanted it to suddenly appear," he said. "I thought this is a gift to the viewers because I hate when I see a billboard. They tell me everything before I see a show. You see a preview for a movie--like I just saw the (bleeping) movie. Why did you tell me everything?"

(Warning: This clip has some language that might be considered foul in the workplace.)

The comedian also had to get his co-stars for the project, Steve Buscemi, Edie Falco, Alan Alda, and Jessica Lange, and their agents to be mum.

"To me the exciting idea was for people to see this without having any idea what it's gonna be like--without having an expectation or idea. And, I thought that's exciting," he said.

Without prior notions, Louis C.K. thought that the audience wouldn't feel tricked into watching the show and regret investing their time and money. What a stand-up guy! We know you see what we did there.

column3: The Football Four Podcast on a new coach and new Playoff slate
column5:
Illinois Athletic Director, Josh Whitman, left, and new coach Lovie Smith have the potential to be a huge step forward for the school. (Photo: Heather Coit, AP)

Did Illinois make a good move in ousting Bill Cubit and grabbing Lovie Smith? Did the College Football Playoff make a good move in advancing semifinal kickoff times and letting the Orange Bowl have its own night in 2016?

USA TODAY Sports college football reporters George Schroeder and Dan Wolken discuss those matters and more on the latest Football Four Podcast.

They assess the quality of the Illinois job and the fit of Smith in it, and they examine the future of the Playoff in relation to the bowl system. And while we're looking into the future, they also look into the murkiest one of any of the Power Five conferences, that of the Big 12.

column3: Is Snoop Doggs son returning to the football field?
column4: ['Charles Curtis', 'Luke Kerr-dineen', 'Nate Scott', 'Steven Ruiz', 'Nina Mandell', "Nina Mandell Is A Writer Editor At Ftw She's Still Waiting For The Nationals To Call About Her Spot With The Racing Presidents"]
column5:
Snoop Doggs son may be coming back to the football field.

According to a report on Scout.com, Cordell Broadus wants to play football again after taking his freshman year at UCLA to be just a student.

Despite his fathers fondness for USC, Broadus committed to the Bruins before announcing in August that he wasnt going to join the team.

But he may have had a change of heart after some time off.

According to the Bruin Report, he will be at spring practice when it begins later this month as a walk-on.

In the past week, Broadus retweeted many messages that seemed to hint he was coming back on his Twitter account:

And had this to say earlier this month:

I can't wait to get back on the field   Cordell Broadus (@C_Broadus21) March 3, 2016

Broadus, a former 4-star recruit, played wide receiver at Las Vegas Bishop Gorman High.

column3: Top 5 fantasy picks and sleepers for NASCARs Good Sam 500
column4: ['Steve Gardner', 'Usa Today Fantasy Sports', 'Brian Polking', 'Tim Heaney', 'Cory Bonini', 'Hours Ago']
column5:
The Sprint Cup Series heads to Phoenix International Raceway this weekend for the second race of the West Coast swing. The 1.0-mile oval will host Sundays Good Sam 500, and the race will be the first flat track event of the 2016 season.

In addition to the lack of banking, Phoenix challenges drivers with two distinctly different layouts in the corners. Watch for action on the backstretch, where drivers will dive all the way on to the apron to try to make a pass. Track position is crucial at Phoenix, so expect pit strategy to play a big role in the outcome.

Kevin Harvick

Phoenix has been Harvicks personal playground, and since 2012, he leads all drivers with five wins and a 2.8 average finish in eight races. In his last five races at PIR, he has four wins and a second-place finish.

Brad Keselowski

Keselowski has finished 11th or better in eight straight starts at Phoenix, logging a seris-leading seven top-10s. During the same stretch, he ranks second in average finish and points scored.

Jimmie Johnson

His success at Phoenix has stood the test of time. Johnson is a four-time winner at the track, and in 25 starts, he has notched 19 top-10s to go along with a series-best 7.7 average finish and 112.6 driver rating.

Joey Logano

His five-race streak of top 10 finishes at Phoenix is tied for the longest in the series, and Logano is coming off a career-best third-place finish at the track last fall.

Dale Earnhardt Jr.

Junior went to victory lane at Phoenix last fall, and he is a three-time winner at the track for his career. His five top-10s at PIR over the last three seasons are tied for the most of any driver, and his four top-five finishes rank second.

Sleepers

Jamie McMurray

Aric Almirola

Ty Dillon

column3: Still talent left to be signed
column5:
USA TODAY Sports breaks down the biggest deals on a busy first day of free agency. USA TODAY Sports

Ryan Fitzpatrick (Photo: ASSOCIATED PRESS)

The majority of the NFL's most coveted free agents have already been snapped up. But there are still a handful of notable names available as the market heads into its second day.

1. DE Robert Ayers: With a career-best 9.5 sacks for the New York Giants in 2015, his market is heating up with the other marquee pass rushers already signed (for big money) and the draft devoid of any that look like immediate impact players.

2. T Russell Okung: He never developed into the next Walter Jones for the Seattle Seahawks  an unfair comparison by definition  and required shoulder surgery after dislocating it in the playoffs. Still, don't expect him to be out of work long, even has he attempts to negotiate his own deal.

3. QB Ryan Fitzpatrick: He's suddenly a more intriguing commodity now that Brock Osweiler has been claimed by the Houston Texans. Though Fitzpatrick seems a natural fit for the New York Jets, for whom he had a career year in 2015, no reason for him not to do some exploratory research to gauge his value.

4. CB Brent Grimes: Released by the Miami Dolphins on Wednesday, he should find encounter decent market. Grimes has only missed one game over the past three seasons and has been named to the Pro Bowl in all of them. But his outspoken wife could be a red flag for some teams.

5. S Eric Weddle: An all-pro in 2014, he slumped last year while dealing with injuries and what seemed like season-long divorce proceedings from the San Diego Chargers. Still, Weddle is an accomplished veteran at a position that could be tough to fill via free agency or the draft.

6. DT Nick Fairley: Theres little question about his talent, though hes certainly looked even better while playing on star-studded lines for the Lions and Rams. Fairley has had off-field issues and his motor hasnt always run hot.

7. CB Casey Hayward: His ability to play in the slot could make him a more attractive option to some teams than a big corner like Smith.

8. G Louis Vasquez: His skill set was no longer a fit in Denver, but expect the former all-pro to have more than a few offers to sift through.

9. S Reggie Nelson: It took a while for the 2007 first rounder to hit his stride, but he's coming off his first Pro Bowl season after tying for the league lead with eight interceptions. Nelson's age (32) is the only thing holding him back from a bigger deal.

10. TE Zach Miller: After missing three seasons due to injury, he proved to be playmaker in 2015 for the Chicago Bears, catching 34 passes for 439 yards despite splitting targets with Martellus Bennett.

11. WR Mohamed Sanu: He's only averaged 38 catches during his four-year career. Still, quality wideouts are in short supply, and the draft pipeline doesn't look overly promising this year, either. Bonus: Sanu's rocket arm will allow offensive coordinators to have some nice trick plays in their arsenal. He visited Falcons Wednesday night and is scheduled to visit Patriots on Thursday.

Follow Nate Davis on Twitter @ByNateDavis

column3: Stocks open higher as ECB bolsters stimulus
column5:
European Central Bank President Mario Draghi arrives for an EU summit meeting, at the European Union headquarters in Brussels, on Feb. 18, 2016. (AFP PHOTO / THIERRY CHARLIER/AFP/Getty Images) (Photo: THIERRY CHARLIER, AFP/Getty Images)

Stock prices in the U.S. rose at the open as investors reacted to the European Central Bank's decision to cut interest rates further and increase its year-old bond-buying program in a fresh effort to stimulate the eurozone economy and combat dangerously low inflation.

The Dow Jones industrial average was up about 60 points, or 0.4%, in early trading. The broader Standard & Poor's 500 stock index was 0.4% higher and the tech-heavy Nasdaq composite index gained 0.6%.

Wall Street was watching to see if ECB president Mario Draghi would deliver on his recent promises to do what it takes to revive the eurozone economy. The Draghi-led ECB appears to have given investors what they hoped for. As expected, the ECB pushed interest rates even lower into "negative territory" and said it would spend more euros each month to buy bonds.

Both moves are designed to jump-start growth by giving banks more of an incentive to lend money and to get more euros into the system.

European stocks initially surged on the news but pulled back some in later trading. The broad Stoxx Europe 600 index was 0.9% higher. Germany's DAX was 1% higher and the CAC 40 in Paris was up 1.8%. The euro weakened on the move, dipping 1.35 vs. the dollar to 1.085.

The ECB's deposit rate, or what it charges banks to park cash with the central bank, was cut an additional 0.1% to -0.4%. Normally banks pay out interest to depositors. But in the current negative rate set-up, commercial banks actually pay the ECB for euro deposits at the central bank.

The ECB also said it would increase its purchases of bonds to 80 billion euros per month, up from 60 billion euros. The expansion of the bond-buying program means the ECB will buy more bonds from financial institutions, a move that will result in an injection of cash back to the bond sellers. The hope is institutions like banks will then use the freed-up cash to make loans.

Nigel Green, CEO of financial firm deVere Group, says the ECBs latest round of stimulus will be a catalyst for investors to expand their holdings in stocks and other risk assets.

They will be keen to top up their portfolios now because there are high-quality equities to be had at bargain prices, Green noted in an e-mail. Indeed, in some sectors, stocks have reached 2009 levels, although the underlying economic environment has improved. And because the ECB is willing to take bold additional steps to encourage sustainable growth in the eurozone, thereby increasing investor confidence and making those buying opportunities look even more appealing.

The ECB moves appear to have met or exceeded investor expectations. Investors had been expecting the rate on deposits to tick down another 0.1% and were hoping the ECB would up its bond purchases by at least 10 billion euros. The ECB also added investment-grade euro bonds to the list of bonds eligible for purchase in its so-called quantitative easing program.

"Mario delivers," is the way Bespoke Investment Group put it in a note to clients.

The debate over stimulus is heating up in markets. While investors know some form of stimulus is necessary to turn around the eurozone's fortunes, there is also concern that negative rates could damage the profitability of already struggling eurozone banks. Investors also caution that the benefits of ever-bigger stimulus programs are not having the positive impact they did when they were first launched years ago.

Aggressive stimulus by the ECB could also complicate the U.S. central banks decisions on interest rates. The reason: a weaker euro means a stronger dollar, and a stronger dollar acts as a depressant on U.S. companies that do a lot of business abroad.

U.S. stocks have rallied the past four weeks as fears of a recession have faded and oil prices have stabilized, which have resulted in a big catch-up rally for beaten-down energy shares.

Shares closed mixed in Asia. Japan's Nikkei 225 rose 1.3%, but Hong Kong's Hang Seng index dipped 0.1% and the Shanghai composite in mainland China fell 2%.

Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/1pa88P6

column3: Public memorial to honor Joey Feek in her native Indiana
column5:
Joey Martin Feek from the country duo Joey + Rory passed away after a battle with cancer. She is survived by her husband and daughter. USA TODAY

Joey Martin Feek and Rory Feek perform onstage during the 45th annual Academy of Country Music Awards rehearsals. (Photo: Getty Images)

INDIANAPOLIS  A public memorial service for country music artist Joey Martin Feek will be held Sunday in the Alexandria-Monroe High School gymnasium. Feek was a native of Alexandria and died in her family home March 4, surrounded by loved ones.

The service will be hosted by Bill and Gloria Gaither, gospel musicians and family friends of Feek's.

Joey was one of a kind," Bill said. "We all will miss that sweet, transparent spirit.

Feek, along with her husband Rory, was half of country music duo Joey + Rory. Rory Feek wrote a blog called "This Life I Live," which chronicled his wife's battle with cancer and his deep devotion to her and their family, including daughter Indiana, who just turned 2.

A memorial will be held for Joey Feek in Indiana. (Photo: Shelley Mays / The Tennessean)

Feek was diagnosed with cervical cancer in 2014. The couple went from finalists on CMT's music reality competition Can You Duet in 2008 to Grammy nominees this year.

In lieu of flowers, the family has requested donations be sent to Joey and Indy at P.O. Box 5471 Vancouver, WA 98668.

Follow Allison Carter on Twitter: @AllisonLCarter

Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/1p9CpNW

column3: The numbers behind Tom Brady's contract extension
column5:
Tom Brady (Photo: Stew Milne, USA TODAY Sports)

Tom Bradys two-year contract extension with the New England Patriots doesnt guarantee hell stay with the team through 2019. But it gets the superstar quarterback a significant raise this coming season, while maintaining a team-friendly structure.

According to contract details obtained by USA TODAY Sports, Brady received a $28 million signing bonus on the deal, which was signed Wednesday. He has guaranteed base salaries of just $1 million in 2016 and 17, lowering his cap number to $14 million each of those seasons.

There is no guaranteed money beyond that, with Brady due a base salary of $14 million and another $1 million in per-game active roster bonuses in each of the last two years of the deal, with a cap number of $22 million in 2018 and 2019.

Under his old deal, Brady had been due base salaries of $9 million in 2016 (with a cap number of $15 million) and $10 million in 2017 (cap number $16 million) that were guaranteed for injury. So, the total new money on the extension is $41 million, for an average per year of $20.5 million  ninth among quarterbacks, ranking just behind Atlantas Matt Ryan ($20.75M).

Essentially converting those guaranteed base salaries in 2016 and 17 to a signing bonus the next two years also makes a difference if his four-game suspension eventually gets reinstated. With a base salary of $1 million, a four-game ban would cost Brady just $235,294.

If Bradys still playing in two years, the Patriots likely would look to restructure again after paying him $30 million for those two seasons  $7 million less than new Houston Texans quarterback Brock Osweiler will make in the same span.

Follow Tom Pelissero on Twitter@TomPelissero
