column3: Stock futures up ahead of ECB meeting
column5:
U.S. stock futures were higher Thursday, as Wall Street hoped the European Central Bank will agree to inject fresh stimulus into the ailing eurozone economy at a key meeting.

Heres where stock futures stood ahead of the opening bell:

Dow Jones: +0.1%

S&P 500: +0.1%

Nasdaq: +0.1%

Japans Nikkei 225 index rose 1.3% to close at 16,852.35 while Hong Kongs Hang Seng index dropped 0.1% to 19,984.42. The Shanghai composite index fell 2% to finish at 2,804.73.

In Europe, Germanys DAX was flat, Frances CAC 40 lost 0.1% and Britains FTSE 100 was 0.4% lower.

U.S. crude oil was 1% lower at $37.90 a barrel Thursday, while Brent crude lost 1.1% to $40.60 a barrel.

Wall Street is hoping the ECB delivers on its promises to inject fresh stimulus and spark a much-needed rise in dangerously low inflation at its meeting Thursday. The central bank disappointed investors at its last meeting, when it didnt deliver quite the stimulus Wall Street was hoping for.

U.S. stocks finished slightly higher Wednesday after a five-session winning streak ended Tuesday.

Contributing: Adam Shell

column3: Spring break: Five takeaways from #DemDebate in Miami
column4: ['Courtney Rozen', 'The University Of Texas At Austin', 'Varsity Tutors', 'Usa Today Network', 'Carol Alderman', 'Usa Today Network Josh Hafner Usa Today', 'Sam Lisker', 'Alexandra Samuels']
column5:
College students arent alone in choosing to spend Spring Break in Florida: the Democratic presidential candidates descended on Miami Dade College Wednesday night, where Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders faced off in the eighth DNC debate.

Clinton was polling ahead prior to the debate, according to USA TODAYs presidential poll tracker, so it was important that Sanders perform well  especially in a state notoriously known to throw a metaphorical wrench into presidential politics. Florida Democrats take to the polls in the states primary on March 15, so this was a perfect time to speak to a hometown crowd.

1. Bienvenidos a Miami!

What happened: The DNC may have hosted seven debates already, but this debate stood apart for one reason: With the exception of addressing the candidates directly, the moderators conducted the debate entirely in Spanish.

Audience members also asked questions in Spanish, and Clinton even threw in a Spanish phrase during one of her rebuttals. For non-Spanish speakers, Univision superimposed translations, but some may have still needed to pull out their Spanish language dictionaries from high school. Univision broadcast the debate in a similar format in the 2008 election from Coral Gables, Fla.

If you're surprised they're speaking in spanish at the debate in Miami, you've probably never been to Miami. #DemDebate  Troy Osinoff (@yo) March 10, 2016

I'm surprised I'm able to follow the Spanish tonight very well. Everybody seems to speak slower and clearer than I'm used to. #DemDebate  Chelsea W. (@heartsdesire456) March 10, 2016

Why it matters: Millennials will make up 44% of the record-breaking 27.3 million eligible Hispanic voters in the 2016 election according to the Pew Research Center. To win the 246 delegates up for grabs in the Florida primary next week, the candidates will likely need to connect with all Spanish-speaking voters, especially Hispanic Millennials.

2. What exactly is Hispandering and are the Democratic candidates doing it?

What happened: Hispandering (verb): a mashup of Hispanic and pandering that means faking interest in Hispanic issues and culture for self-serving reasons (according to NPR).

The term came up in the debate and, clearly, both candidates knew their audience: They answered questions on Puerto Ricos debt, undocumented immigration (naturally) and Cuban politics. According to video clips brought up by the moderators, both candidates have made statements against legalization of undocumented immigrants in the past.

Among things discussed, Sanders proposed improving relationships between Latin American countries and the United States; Clinton called for the election of a Democratic congress and president to begin immigration reform immediately. Both candidates pledged not to deport children.

Why it matters: People of Hispanic origin make up the nations largest ethnic or racial minority.

3. Climate change matters to Floridians  and to Millennials

What happened: Sanders stayed on message: he vowed to take on the fossil fuel industry directly to cut emissions and slow the effects of climate change. Clinton proposed a more gradual clean power plan that would utilize natural gas as a transitional fuel to gradually move from coal to clean energy. This will require bipartisan cooperation, she said. Of course, Sanders plan would as well.

Why it matters: Florida leads all states in property at risk from climate change, according to a 2015 article in the Miami Herald. Plus, higher temperatures and rising seas could slow labor productivity, stress the energy industry and dry up cash pumped into the state by tourists, the report noted.

And Millennial voters definitely want the government to take action, according to USA TODAY/Rock the Votes Millennial Survey

No city has more at stake than Miami, the city in which we are sitting, said Washington Post political correspondent Karen Tumulty, one of the debates moderators, during the debate.

I could kiss you Bernie! Thank you for being the leader we need.  _____________________________________ www.berniesanders.com www.voteforbernie.org www.feelthebern.org Turn on post notifcations Phone bank Donate Register to vote!! Like Comment Share #votetogether#womenforbernie#latinosforbernie#ohiouniversity#chicagoland#womensrights#ohiogram#floridastate#lgbtcommunity#powertothepeople#latinosforbernie#michiganstate#fightfor15#powertotheshe#blackqueens#chicagostyle#blacklivesmatter#blackgirlskillinit#womensrights#nursesunite#bernieforpresident#latinosunidos#feelthebern#berniesanders#bernie2016#bernie#hillary#millenials#millennialsforbernie#intersectionalfeminism#ohiostate#demdebate A photo posted by #FeelTheBern (@democraticrevolution2016) on Mar 9, 2016 at 10:39pm PST

4. High school, Student debt and tuition-free college, oh my!

What happened: Student debt commanded the candidates attention for part of the debate. Clintons answer: all students should be able to refinance their student loans, ensuring a lower interest rate. Sanders believes publicly funded education should continue past high school; if elected he said he plans to make public universities tuition-free to allow all high school graduates access to a university-level education. To pay for this plan, Sanders said he would impose a tax on Wall Street speculation (easier said than done, of course).

Why it matters: Student debt is on the rise. Millennials ranked college affordability and student debt as the second most important topic in this election after the economy, according to the USA TODAY/Rock the Vote survey.

5. We have to keep ourselves entertained somehow...

What happened: This debate was less than yuge on entertainment, but there were some laughs, such as when Clinton ridiculed Trumps plan to build what she called, a beautiful tall wall. Meanwhile, Sanders suit stole the show on Twitter: exactly what color was it?

@jcrew @BuzzFeedNews Bernie's suit is chocolate "brown is the new black" 1.6 decade too late  Kristan Kennedy (@KKennedy90016) March 10, 2016

Omg.... WHO CARES WHAT COLOR BERNIE'S SUIT IS! LET'S GET BACK TO THE ISSUES AT HAND   Jess (@JesssBeDope) March 10, 2016

Why it matters: The Democrats lack the entertainment factor of their Republican counterparts and come on, things can get a little boring. Not to worry, however: the Republicans will be at it again Thursday night at the University of Miami in Coral Gables, Fla.

column3: Its springtime for these 7 stocks!
column5:
Spring is in the air! Its time to get lucky with the stock market.

There are seven stocks, including tobacco companies Lorillard (LO) and Altria (MO) and nutrition company Mead Johnson Nutrition (MJN), that have been perennial winners during the spring, according to a USA TODAY analysis of data from S&P Capital IQ. These stocks have beaten the market each and every spring the past years. These stocks, also, posted average gains the past five springs of more than 8%.

Picking the right stocks can be tricky in the spring. Spring hasnt been the greatest of seasons for investors. The market has only inched up 0.2% in the past five springs and fell two of the past five springs. But savvy investors have picked their spots and found big time winners.

S&P 500 STOCK PRICE CHANGE IN SPRING

Spring of % Ch. S&P 500 2010 -3.7% 2011 1.3% 2012 -3.5% 2013 2.2% 2014 4.9%

Sources: S&P Capital IQ, USA TODAY research

If theres a theme that seems to work in the spring  its tobacco. Lorillard  maker of Newport and Kent smokes  tends to set the world on fire in the spring. The stock has gained nearly 12% on average during the past five springs. The stock did get a pop last spring on the news rival Reynolds American (RAI) is looking to buy the company. But check this out  Reynolds is also a big spring winner as it Altria. Those tobacco stocks have shot up 8.8% and 8.5%, respectively, over the past five springs. The merger between Reynolds and Lorillard is up in the air  but tobacco seems to work for investors during the season.

Rather do something healthier for your portfolio in the spring? Mead Johnson makes all sorts of nutritional products, like baby formula. The stock has gained 9.6% over the past five springs. And analysts think theres still nearly 7% upside until the stock hits their target.

Some investors might wonder if these stocks can keep their spring fever running. Thats a valid concern. But, analysts have 18-month price targets that are higher on all the stocks but one  Family Dollar. Family Dollar is in the process of being bought by Family Dollar, anyway.

Dont let a rainy season spoil your fun in the market. There will be winners  if you know where to hunt.

S&P 500 STOCKS THAT HAVE BEATED THE MARKET EACH OF THE PAST FIVE SPRINGS

Company Symbol Average gain past 5 springs Change to 18-month price targets Lorillard LO 11.6% 2.8% Family Dollar FDO 11.4% -8.1% Mead Johnson Nutrition MJN 9.6% 6.5% Avalonbay Communities AVB 9.2% 1.7% Reynolds American RAI 8.8% 3.6% Altria MO 8.5% 10.2% DirecTV DTV 8.1% 6.2%

Sources: S&P Capital IQ, USA TODAY research

column3: Rick Carlisle furious, says ref walked into huddle and baited Deron Williams into technical
column4: ['Charles Curtis', 'Luke Kerr-dineen', 'Nate Scott', 'Steven Ruiz', 'Nina Mandell', "Nate Scott Is A Writer Editor At Ftw Leading The Site's Culture Coverage He Likes Writing About Soccer Basketball Music Tv The Evils Of The Ocean"]
column5:
Dallas coach Rick Carlisle was furious with official David Jones after the Mavericks lost to the Pistons on Wednesday night and, unprompted, told reporters that Jones had intentionally entered the huddle to bait Deron Williams into a technical foul.

From ESPN:

For the first time in a 33-year NBA career, I saw a referee make a point of going out of his way and walking into our huddle and baiting one of our guys into getting a technical, Carlisle said. Ive never seen anything like that in my years in this league. I dont see how that can ever be excusable.



Watch all the latest videos at ESPN Video

Carlisle wasnt done:

Went out of his way, he continued. Could have walked away, made a point out of going back. I said, Hey, I got it. I got it. Let it go. He goes, No, and he walked back essentially into our huddle, and he baited Deron Williams into getting a technical.

For his part, Williams wasnt getting into it.

I made a decision about 10 years [ago] in my career that I wasnt going to comment about officials, Williams said. Save my money. I already got a technical. Thats money right there, so Im not going to comment any further and risk any more money.

column3: Iowa State's Monte Morris has Flint on mind as much as Final Four
column5:
Monte Morris has home on his mind even as he tries to lead Iowa State to a deep postseason run. (Photo: John Rieger, USA TODAY Sports)

KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Every time Monte Morris hears his name called as part of Iowa States starting lineup, his mind flashes quickly back to his hometown.

They my name and say Flint, Michigan, Morris told USA TODAY Sports this week. I know it'll bring me to tears. I know I'm playing for more than myself and my family. ...

It gets me emotional a lot.

Morris, Iowa State's second-leading scorer, is seventh nationally in assists per game and fourth in assist-to-turnover ratio. He said hes playing for the little kids who dont know that little kids everywhere else can drink regular water out of their faucets no problem, and the people who are trying to help fix the drinking water crisis, which has led to numerous problems in the past two years, including lead contamination.

Morris mother is still living in Flint, he said, but she downplays the situation so that he doesnt worry about her. He said he tries not to because she has a lot of cases of bottled water at home.

Its kind of a blessing that people are showing their awareness about Flint, Morris said. At the same time it's really sad, actually the water and how the situation all started, and how its now its been an ongoing problem for so long. Kids and everything been drinking the water and they're getting lead poisoning and things like that. I feel like it's real tough, but at the same time people are looking at Flint and trying to help change it.

On Morriss behalf last month, Hy-Vee, a grocery chain based in West Des Moines, Iowa, announced it would send 11 semitrailers  six trucks with water gallons and five filled with bottled water  to Flint. The company chose 11 because Morris wears No. 11 for the Cyclones.

When they did that, I was very emotional, Morris said. I pray about this all the time  and it came about.

Still, its been quite difficult for Morris, Iowa States point guard, to watch from afar. Hes also got a a little niece in Flint.

I talk to people back there, he said. It's not really good. Its worse in some areas but in some areas it's okay to drink but theres nobody recommending it. Even dogs try to drink bottled water.

column3: Fiat Chrysler moves to prop up dealers
column5:
New Fiats are on display at Golling Fiat in Brimingham, Mich., (Photo: KATHLEEN GALLIGAN, GANNETT)

Fiat Chrysler Automobiles presented its Fiat dealers with a plan on Wednesday designed to help them reduce the cost of running their dealerships, help to restore faith in the brand and to increase the exposure of Fiat cars to more customers.

FCA told Fiat dealers today they can consolidate the costs and operations of running Fiat dealerships with their Chrysler, Dodge, Jeep and Ram dealerships while keeping their Fiat showrooms open. Most dealers who own and operate Fiat dealerships also operate Chrysler, Dodge, Jeep and Ram nearby.

Dealers also will be allowed to display Fiat cars at those other stores, said FCA spokesman Gualberto Ranieri.

The new plan is a substantial shift in strategy for the automaker, which has painstakingly sought to carve out a separate identity for the funky, quirky Italian brand since it was reintroduced in America six years ago.

The new strategy  revealed to dealers this afternoon at a suburban Detroit hotel  could save a retailer selling 15 new Fiats a month an average of $180,000 per year in duplicate third-party vendor expenses, according to the Automotive News, which was first to report the news. FCA also plans to simplify its Fiat lineup. The automaker plans to cut the number of Fiat trim levels to limit price overlap among nameplates.

FCA reintroduced the Fiat brand at a time when gas prices were high and the demand and interest in small cars was rising. Today, the percentage of passenger cars sold in the U.S. is shrinking because consumers are flocking to crossovers and SUVs.

Last fall, Fiat launched the 500X crossover, and the company was hoping that the new vehicle would help to boost sales. But Fiat only sold 9,463 of the new crossovers in the U.S. over a six-month period.

For the year, Fiat's U.S. dealers sold 42,410 cars, 8% less than the prior year. Meanwhile, U.S. industry sales rose 5.7% to 17.47 million  the most ever in U.S. history.There are more than 200 dealerships nationwide. On average, those dealers sold about 212 cars last year, making it difficult for Fiat dealers to earn a profit.

Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/1pi2tHm

column3: Houston gave Brock Osweiler $72 million and no one has any idea if hes good
column4: ['Charles Curtis', 'Luke Kerr-dineen', 'Nate Scott', 'Steven Ruiz', 'Nina Mandell', "Nate Scott Is A Writer Editor At Ftw Leading The Site's Culture Coverage He Likes Writing About Soccer Basketball Music Tv The Evils Of The Ocean"]
column5:
Brock Osweiler shirked the Denver Broncos on the first day of NFL free agency and signed a four-year, $72 million dollar contract to play for the Houston Texans. Two years and $37 million of that contract are guaranteed.

Its a great deal of money, and Ill say before I even begin: Good for Osweiler. If someone is willing to pay him $72 million to throw a football, go and get yours, man. I will never fault anyone for taking a deal.

For the Texans, however, I have a question: How do you know Osweiler is any good?

Osweiler has started seven games as an NFL quarterback,. He went 5-2 in those games, which is good, but he was also playing on a team with an historically great defense, which helps matters.

And I know this seems silly, but I promise you it isnt: He looks the part. Osweiler is 6-foot-6 and can throw the ball a mile, and hes a good looking guy and Im sure NFL experts will say that speaks to his confidence, or something. He played for a good team and won most his games, and hes never been shown to be terrible in any of them. Plus his name: Brock Osweiler. Take that name in. If I were writing a bad script for an NFL movie, my antagonist would be named Brock Osweiler.

But ignore the looks. Ignore the height and the arm strength. Look at his numbers in those seven games, games that, again, he was filling in on a Super Bowl-caliber roster. He completed 61% of his passes, threw 10 touchdowns and six interceptions, averaged 245 yards a game and a hair over 11 yards per completion, and had a QB rating of 86.0.

Another player last year started a similar number of games. That QB completed 63% of his passes, threw 10 touchdowns and seven interceptions, averaged 253 yards a game and 11.4 yards per completion, and had a QB rating of 86.2. That quarterback was Blaine Gabbert.

Blaine Gabbert is currently on a 2-year, $4 million contract with the San Francisco 49ers.

This is how the NFL works, of course. Gabbert has been shown to not be an effective franchise quarterback, so he gets a backup role. Osweiler has not yet shown an inability to do a job, so theres still promise. Theres still hope there. Theres still an NFL franchise that can talk itself into Osweiler as its savior.

What would worry me most for Texans fans is that John Elway and the Denver Broncos werent going to come close to matching that. They saw what Osweiler did as a starter and in the playoffs went right back to Peyton Manning, who couldnt throw the ball 20 yards. In the offseason, they saw the contract the Texans were offering, scoffed, and sent Osweiler on his way.

Now, I have no idea if Osweiler will find his swag now that hes the man in Houston and become a top-tier quarterback. If Blake Bortles can become one of the best QBs in the game, Im done trying to figure this out. But I do know one thing, and thats that I dont know. I could see Osweiler turning into a great quarterback, I could see him in three years as the backup in San Francisco playing under that Gabbert contract.

I dont think anyone on the Texans has any idea if hes great either. But theyre tired of not having a quarterback, and theyre willing to spend $72 million to find out.

column3: 5 things you need to know Thursday
column5:
Marco Rubio speaks at a campaign rally in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., on March 8, 2016. (Photo: Gary McCullough, AP)

Rubio's last stand? GOP hopefuls debate in Miami

Hot on the heels of Super Tuesday 2, the four remaining Republican presidential hopefuls will meet on the stage Thursday in Miami for their 12th debate. Despite his home-state advantage, Florida Sen. Marco Rubio is trailing Donald Trump in the polls just days before the state's March 15 winner-take-all primary. Some are calling Florida a last stand for the fading Rubio, third in the delegate count, behind Trump and Ted Cruz. The debate, hosted by CNN, The Washington Times and Salem Media Group, will air at 8:30 p.m. ET.

Prime Minister Trudeau goes to Washington

President Obama will welcome Canada's new Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to the White House on Thursday for a state dinner, marking the first official state visit from Canada in almost 20 years. Some not-so-light dinner conversation will include ISIL and climate change, according to the White House. Trudeau, whose father is a former prime minister, led Canadas Liberal Party to victory in October.

The charismatic Canadian prime minister has won hearts over his progressive policies and easy charm. Trudeau hopes to capitalize on the attention to focus "on substance." Video provided by Newsy Newslook

Investors look for more stimulus from ECB

Wall Street will be watching Thursday as the European Central Bank meets, and hopes are that the eurozone's top monetary authority will twist open the taps of stimulus. Such a move could boost dangerously low inflation throughout the 19-nation region. President Mario Draghi has hinted the ECB could cut its already-negative deposit rate even further, which would make it more expensive for banks to hang on to their cash and encourage them to lend.

European Central Bank President Mario Draghi will lead a pivotal ECB meeting Thursday. (Photo: EMMANUEL DUNAND, AFP/Getty Images)

More details revealed about North America's wizarding community

In the world of Harry Potter, anyway. J.K. Rowling will release another entry in "The History of Magic in North America" web series on Thursday. So far, the author has taught us Muggles about what the magical world was like in North America between the fourteen and seventeenth centuries. Her last entry dove into the beginnings of Ilvermorny School of Witchcraft and Wizardry (aka the American version of Hogwarts) and the Salem Witch Trials. What new tidbits are coming in this entry? Check the Pottermore site at 9 a.m. ET to find out.

Early North American witches and wizards did not have a fun time. (Photo: Pottermore)

LeBron and Kobe's final matchup

The farewells continue for Kobe Bryant. On Thursday, the Los Angeles Lakers star will say goodbye to LeBron James when the Lakers play the Cavaliers at the Staples Center in what will be the final matchup between two of the games greats before Bryant retires. They have faced off 21 times in the past 13 seasons, and odds are that James could walk you through each and every one of those games if you asked.

Kobe Bryant of the Los Angeles Lakers LeBron James of the Cleveland Cavaliers laugh during second half NBA All-Star Game basketball action in Toronto on Sunday, Feb. 14, 2016. (Photo: Mark Blinch, AP)

Bonus: 7 volunteers choose jail for new TV series '60 Days In'

Seven volunteers go undercover as inmates in the 12-episode A&E series 60 Days In, which premieres Thursday at 9 p.m. ET/PT. (It moves to 10 p.m. on March 17.) The volunteers, each of whom had no arrest record, were booked on fake charges and held for 60 days in Clark County Correctional Jail in Jeffersonville, Ind. Each participant could tell only two adults about their participation on the show. Clark County Sheriff Jamey Noel said he hopes that when the public hears the fake inmates' stories, "maybe it'll start clicking with people that 'That's not a place I want to go.' "

'60 Days In' is new A&E series follows seven volunteers who agree to go undercover for 60 days in the Clark County jail in Indiana. A&E

On the go? Listen to the audio version of 5 things in the player below:

And the essentials:

Weather: Another day of record warmth is forecast Thursday for the eastern U.S. while storms pelt the Mississippi Valley and Northwest.

Stocks: U.S. stock futures were higher ahead of the ECB meeting Thursday.

TV Tonight: Wondering what to watch tonight? TV critic Robert Bianco looks at DC's Legends of Tomorrow, Scandal and Elementary.

Need a break? Try playing some of our games.

You can subscribe to get the day's top news each weekday in your inbox.

Contributing: The Associated Press

column3: First uterus transplant in U.S. fails amid 'sudden complication'
column5:
Doctors at the Cleveland Clinic haven't said what complication required that the organ be removed early. Video provided by Newsy Newslook

Lindsey and her husband Blake stand with Cleveland Clinic medical staff as they announce she was the nation's first uterus transplant patient, Monday, March 7, 2016, in Cleveland. Standing with the couple, from left, are Ruth M. Farrell, M.D., bio-ethicist, Rebecca Flyckt, M.D., OB/GYN surgeon, and Andreas Tzakis, M.D., program director of the Transplant Center. (Photo: Marvin Fong, AP)

The first uterus transplant in the U.S. failed after the patient experienced a sudden complication, Cleveland Clinic announced Wednesday.

The surgery, which took place on Feb. 24 in Cleveland, initially seemed to be a success.

We are saddened to share that our patient, Lindsey, recently experienced a sudden complication that led to the removal of her transplanted uterus, the Cleveland Clinic said in a statement.

The 26-year-old recipient identified only as Lindsey is doing well and recovering, according to the clinic.

I just wanted to take a moment to express my gratitude towards all of my doctors, Lindsey said in a statement. They acted very quickly to ensure my health and safety. Unfortunately, I did lose the uterus to complications. However, I am doing okay and appreciate all of your prayers and good thoughts

Lindsey is part of a research study which will include ten women who have uterine factor infertility (UFI) or cannot carry a child because they were born without a uterus.

According to the clinic, there is a known risk that a transplanted organ may have to be removed if complications occur following the surgery. Doctors are currently looking into what factors contributed to Lindsey's complications.

While the uterus transplant marks a first in the U.S., there have been successful uterus transplants in Sweden.

A woman in Sweden born without a uterus received one in 2013 from a 61-year-old post-menopausal woman, according to research published in the journal The Lancet.

She later gave birth, offering the first proof-of-concept for uterus transplantation as a treatment for uterine factor infertility, according to the report.

UFI affects thousands of women worldwide. Some women are born without a uterus, and others can acquire UFI after a hysterectomy or a serious pelvic infection, according to the clinic.

Despite the setback, the Cleveland Clinic plans to continue screening candidates for the procedure.

The study ... is still ongoing with a commitment to the advancement of medical research to provide an additional option for women and their families, the clinic said in a statement.

Follow @MaryBowerman on Twitter.

column5:
Endorsements havent mattered a huge amount this presidential cycle  Marco Rubio has amassed a huge lead in that race and questions linger over whether his campaign will be able to survive much longer  but this one from the Ohio State Head Coach Urban Meyer will be welcome news to Governor John Kasich.

The Ohio Governor is trailing by six points according to recent polls in his home state, which prompted Meyer to step in to throw his weight behind Kasich in the must-win competition.

I did some research on all the great work, the great leadership that youve done for our great state, Meyer said. Go win this darn thing

column3: St. Patricks Day celebrations in the Caribbean
column4: ['Est March', 'Special For Usa Today', 'Melanie Reffes', 'A M']
column5:
It may not be top of mind when you think of the Caribbean but on many islands, St. Patricks Day is as tropical as a fruity rum punch and a sun lounger planted in the sand. Here are some of the best parades, parties and green drinks on the islands that celebrate the patron saint of Ireland.

Montserrat

The only nation in the world apart from Ireland that celebrates St. Patricks Day as a national holiday, this tiny volcanic island is affectionately called the Emerald Isle of the Caribbean. With a melange of African and Irish history and locals who still speak with an Irish brogue, the green speck south of St. Kitts and west of Antigua is in full Irish mode from March 10-20. The go-for-the-green lineup includes jump-up breakfasts, parades, cricket games and the Freedom Walk & Run that remembers the slave uprising that occurred on St. Patricks Day in 1768. Once home to indentured Irish Catholic servants, the harp and female figure on the flag and official seal come from Irish heraldry, and a green shamrock is stamped on every passport upon arrival.

Other events worth sticking around for include the treasure hunt called Catch the Mermaid on March 12 and 13, Junior Calypso Competition on March 13, Pub Crawl on March 15 and the March 17 Heritage Day Feast with a menu of bush tea, stewed yard fowl and goat water, an Irish recipe that jazzes up mutton with cloves and rum. Of all the Caribbean islands, Montserrat is the only one to boast a noticeable Irish heritage, says Camille Gerald, permanent secretary of tourism. During our St. Patricks Day celebrations, Montserrat comes alive with green fanfare and we welcome visitors from far and wide.

U.S. Virgin Islands

The green party to beat all parties, the St. Patricks Day parade got off to a rousing start in 1969 when a gaggle of lively business people held court in Harrys Office Bar in Christiansted, the largest town on St. Croix. After a few cold ones, the chatter got around to the lack of green celebrations in the U.S. Virgin Islands, and soon a stake bed truck was commandeered with a piano securely fashioned on top, and the rest is parade history. Festivities get going on the Saturday before the holiday when the Grand Marshal welcomes green-clad marchers while parade-watchers decked out in their Irish finest sip and snack from food trucks lining King Street.

Grand Cayman

A tradition for more than two decades, the St. Patricks Day 5K Irish Jog heads to the finish line on March 17 with runners vying for top prizes as they make their way around a 3.1 mile route. Hosted by the Butterfield Bank and the Grand Cayman Beach Suites, the green jog follows a golf cart path around the Britannia Golf Course and attracts more than one thousand serious runners, moms pushing baby strollers and those wanting to burn off the resort breakfast buffet calories. Participants wear green beads, red beards and Guinness hats, and after paying a nominal entry fee can bid on prizes like hotel stays and massages at the finest spas. For the wee ones, face stickers, hats and refreshments are gratis. Proceeds benefit the Cayman Islands Cadet Corps.

Anguilla

Fronting the blue sea, CuisinArt Golf Resort & Spa is going for the green on St. Patricks Day; not only the green at the Greg Norman-designed championship golf course (the only course on the petite island across the sea from St. Maarten) but the green gourmet eats at Le Bistro at Santorini, the resorts upscale eatery and the laid-back Cafe Mediterraneo. Chefs are taste-testing their Irish recipes and will be ready to whip, whisk and wow with Guinness braised short ribs, house-cured corn beef and cabbage, and hearty holiday sandwiches crowned with sauerkraut and a dab of spicy mustard.

The Bahamas

Go for the gold (and the green) at the Atlantis Casino at Atlantis Paradise Island when the St. Patricks Day slot tournament tempts gamblers on March 12 with a $25,000 (U.S.) jackpot. During the holiday weekend, Dragons Ultra Lounge in the ginormous resort over the bridge from Nassau amps up the Irish vibe with lucky charms, shamrocks and horseshoes, and is the place to play with its multi-media machines and Irish nibbles.

Bermuda

Though adored for its pink sandy beaches, on St. Patricks Day, Bermuda is all green. At Flanagan's Irish Pub in the capital city of Hamilton, the only Irish pub on the island, the balcony with views of Hamilton Harbor and Front Street becomes Ireland in the islands with television screens tuned to Celtic football, bartenders pouring Blarney Stone cocktails potent with Goslings rum, Jameson and Guinness, and chefs serving Irish standouts like corned beef and cabbage. Green-themed dancers and live Irish music rocks the Pub from March 1520.

Curacao

Start with Jameson whiskey, green melon liqueur and even greener kiwi syrup, add a splash of fizz and make it pretty with a cherry and a pineapple wedge, and youre in an Irish frame of mind at the Renaissance Curacao. Brand new this year, the Shammy Shamrock Fizz  is the green cocktail at the crayon-colored resort near the Rif Fort across the bridge from the capital city of Willemstad. Created by bartender Stanley de Jong and priced at $12.00 a pop, the heady green fun in a glass will be shaken, stirred and poured at the Infinity Beach Club on March 17.

Nevis

Bottoms up at the AAA Four Diamond Relais & Chateaux Montpelier Plantation where bartender Kaddy Simmonds celebrates St. Patricks Day in green style with his Nevisian Rainforest. On the menu from March 13-17 at the Indigo Bar in the swishy resort, fans can make the green elixir at home with spiced rum, coconut rum, creme de banana, and melon liqueur. To bring out the green, Bartender Kaddy recommends layering the glass with Blue Curacao liqueur and decorating it with a sliced ripe green lime.

Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/1pcVyPQ

column3: Russell Westbrook with astounding line
column5:
Oklahoma City Thunder PG Russell Westbrook had 25 points, 11 rebounds and 20 assists against the Los Angeles Clippers Wednesday, March 9. Westbrook is the first player with a 25-10-20 line since Los Angeles Lakers PG Magic Johnson did it in 1988.

Tip: Westbrook is averaging 24.3 points, 7.6 boards and 12.9 assists the last 10 games. He has elevated his game to another level this season and has shed the only concern fantasy owners had about his style of play prone to injuries. He's no worse than a top-five fantasy player.

column3: Beer winners announced
column5:
There are more than 3,000 breweries in the U.S. alone. (Photo: blizzard_77, Getty Images/iStockphoto)

The United States surpassed 4,100 breweries in 2015, according to the Brewers Association. That's a lot of beer! Demand for high-quality craft beer is at an all time high, and USA TODAY 10Best set out to find the creme de la creme of the craft beer world.

Enlisting the help of a panel of beer experts, 10Best nominated 20 finalists in the categories of Best Beer Scene, Best New Brewery, Best Beer Bar, Best Brewpub, Best Beer Festival and Best Beer Label. For the past four weeks, readers have been voting daily for their favorites in each category, and the results are in.

The winners for the USA TODAY 10Best beer awards are as follows:

Best Beer Scene

While you can find craft beer just about anywhere these days, not all cities are created equal when it comes to brews. These are America's 10 best beer scenes -- places with exceptional beer bars, gastropubs, craft breweries and a thriving beer culture -- as voted on by 10Best readers.

With world-renowned beer and a "Beer City Ale Trail" that features more than 40 breweries, this city proudly stakes its claim as "Beer City USA." VPC

Grand Rapids, Mich. Fort Collins, Colo. Tampa Cleveland Asheville, N.C. Philadelphia Chicago Portland, Maine Baltimore Atlanta

Best New Brewery

Hundreds of new breweries are opening every year, and 10Best set out to find the best newcomers -- breweries that have opened in the past three years -- with the help of a panel of beer experts and our reader votes.

WeldWerks Brewing Company was voted as the best new brewery in the U.S. by 10Best readers. (Photo: WeldWerks Brewing Company)

WeldWerks Brewing Company - Greeley, Colo. Rhinegeist - Cincinnati Stoneface Brewing Co. - Newington, N.H. Moody Tongue Brewing Company - Chicago Bottle Logic Brewing - Anaheim, Calif. Orpheus Brewing - Atlanta Creature Comforts Brewing Co. - Athens, Ga. Bissell Brothers - Portland, Maine Right Proper Brewing Company - Washington Green Bench Brewing Co. - St. Petersburg, Fla.

Best Beer Festival

Great beer festivals not only allow you to sample a huge variety of interesting brews, they also often offer opportunities to interact directly with the brewers, sample professionally paired food and mingle with fellow aficionados. These 10 winning festivals rank among the most travel-worthy in the U.S.

The Great American Beer Festival in Denver took home top honors in the Best Beer Festival category. (Photo: Brewers Association)

Great American Beer Festival - Denver Atlantic City Beer and Music Festival - Atlantic City Great Taste of the Midwest - Madison, Wis. Field of Beers - Jupiter, Fla. BrewMasters Craft Beer Festival - Galveston, Texas North American Belgian Beer Festival - Westland, Mich. Tailspin Ale Fest - Louisville Belgium Comes to Cooperstown - Cooperstown, N.Y. Festival of Barrel-Aged Beers - Chicago Decatur Craft Beer Festival - Decatur, Ga.

Best Beer Bar

Mekong Restaurant in Richmond, Va. pours a stellar selection of craft beer served alongside Vietnamese cuisine. (Photo: Bogdanhoda, Getty Images/iStockphoto)

While you can get a good craft beer just about anywhere these days, these 10 winners for Best Beer Bar offer so much more. Stellar selections of local, rare and unusual brews, knowledgeable bar staff to help narrow down the choice and a great atmosphere make these beer bars must-visits for any craft beer enthusiast.

Mekong Restaurant - Richmond, Va. HopCat - Grand Rapids, Mich. Cloverleaf Tavern - Caldwell, N.J. The J. Clyde - Birmingham, Ala. The Birch - Norfolk, Va. The Bier Stein - Eugene, Ore. Thirsty Monk - Asheville, N.C. Maria's Packaged Goods & Community Bar - Chicago Brick Store Pub - Decatur, Ga. Max's Taphouse - Baltimore

Best Brewpub

Titletown Brewing Company was voted Best Brewpub by 10Best readers. (Photo: Titletown Brewing Company)

What's better than great beer? Great beer and great food, served side by side. That's just what you'll find at our 10 winners for Best Brewpub -- establishments that brew their own beers and serve them alongside a stellar menu.

Titletown Brewing Company - Green Bay, Wis. Brewery Vivant - Grand Rapids, Mich. The Schlafly Tap Room - St. Louis Urban Chestnut Brewing Company - St. Louis Ithaca Beer Company Taproom - Ithaca, N.Y. TAPS Fish House and Brewery - Corona, Calif. Piece Brewery and Pizzeria - Chicago Revolution Brewing Brewpub - Chicago Founders Brewing Co. Taproom - Grand Rapids, Mich. 3 Floyds Brewpub - Munster, Ind.

Best Beer Label

Newburgh Brewing Company's Cream Ale has the best beer label, according to 10Best readers. (Photo: Newburgh Brewing Company)

They say don't judge a book by its cover, but when faced with an ever expanding selection of craft beer cans and bottles, sometimes you have to judge a beer by its label. A great beer label pushes boundaries, epitomizes the beer within, captures the eye or makes us smile. Some manage all four.

Cream Ale - Newburgh Brewing Company 8-Bit Pale Ale - Tallgrass Brewing Co. B/A/Y/S (Black As Your Soul) Imperial Stout - Adroit Theory Brewing Ninja vs. Unicorn Double IPA - Pipeworks Brewing Co. Breakfast Stout - Founders Brewing Co. Moondance - Southbound Brewing Company Fade to Black - Left Hand Brewing Company Selfies Are For Wieners Double IPA - Spiteful Brewing Sexual Chocolate Imperial Stout - Foothills Brewing Suburban Beverage - Perennial Artisan Ales

Congratulations to all our beer category winners! To see other Readers' Choice winners or cast your vote in current categories, visit 10Best.com.

column3: Yahoo adds to board amid threat of proxy battle
column5:
In this Feb. 19, 2015 photo, Yahoo President and CEO Marissa Mayer delivers the keynote address at the first-ever Yahoo Mobile Developer's Conference, in San Francisco. The company, which is facing a potential challenge to its board, added two directors Thursday. (Photo: Eric Risberg, AP)

NEW YORK -- Beleaguered Internet company Yahoo has added two new directors to its slimmed down board  a move that could help it defend itself against the threat of a shareholder-led board battle.

The Sunnyvale, Calif., company increased the board to nine directors from seven by adding a former banker and former telecom executive to its ranks. The two new directors, whose experience could help Yahoo signal that it has the expertise to assess acquisition offers, are Catherine Friedman, a former Morgan Stanley executive, and Eric Brandt, former chief financial officer of Broadcom Corporation.

The additions replace seats that were vacated in recent months by tech entrepreneur Max Levchin and brokerage founder Charles Schwab. The two long-time directors left the company as Yahoo's board was grappling with unhappy shareholders and uncertainty over the company's future.

By replacing the empty seats, Yahoo makes them less vulnerable to attack by angry shareholders, who have threatened to campaign for seats when the board faces re-election later this year. The deadline for nominating a dissenting slate of candidates is later this month.

Yahoo faces pressure from shareholders to sell its core Web assets, like Yahoo Sports and Yahoo Mail, to the highest bidder. Potential suitors are expected to include telecom companies like Verizon, which recently bought Yahoo competitor AOL.

Failure to shop itself could result in an ugly and costly board battle waged by hedge fund Starboard Value, which wrote a scathing letter to the board in January saying that "investors have lost all confidence" in them and CEO Marissa Mayer.

"If the board is unwilling to accept the need for significant change, then an election contest may very well be needed," Starboard CEO Jeff Smith said in the letter.

Today we are expanding our board of directors with additional expertise to help advance our strategic goals as Yahoo continues its transformation," Mayer said in Thursday's press release.

The company's strategic plan includes a tax-free spin off of the core Web assets from Yahoo's massive stake in Chinese Internet company Alibaba. The company has also said it will entertain suitors in the meantime, but seriousness of its efforts have been questioned by some shareholders, including Starboard.

By prioritizing the spin-off, Yahoo would delay any sale by at least a year.

Follow USA TODAY reporter Kaja Whitehouse on Twitter: @kajawhitehouse

column3: Next 'Diary of a Wimpy Kid' book arrives on Nov. 1
column4: ['Jocelyn Mcclurg', 'Clive Cussler', 'Nora Roberts', 'Jojo Moyes', 'Est March', 'A M', 'Marie Kondo', 'Paul Kalanithi', 'Justin Scott']
column5:
Promotional art for the next 'Diary of a Wimpy Kid' book. (Photo: Amulet/Abrams)

Now that Greg Heffley survived a gadget-free week (barely) in the last Diary of a Wimpy Kid book, the middle-schooler is ready for his next misadventure.

Book 11 in Jeff Kinneys hit illustrated kids series will go on sale Nov. 1, his publisher, Amulet, announces today. (And here is a first look at a promotional image for the new book.)

The title, along with the jacket, will not be unveiled until April 28.

Heres what we know about the plot of the new book so far: Greg Heffley has always believed there was something that set him apart from everyone else. In the new book, Greg discovers what makes him unique, and it's not at all what he expected.

Eight Wimpy Kid books have hit No. 1 on USA TODAYs Best-Selling Books list, including book 10, Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Old School, released in November 2015.

More than 165 million copies of the series are in print worldwide, and the new book will be published in at least 20 countries on Nov. 1. Last year Kinney went on a worldwide tour in support of Old School.

After the tenth book, I found myself at a crossroads in my career, Kinney said in a statement. I wasn't sure if I should continue writing Diary of a Wimpy Kid books or go down a different path. I had the opportunity last year to travel all over the world and meet fans of the series in places like China, Brazil, and Romania. The trip was incredibly energizing, and made me feel certain that there is a demand for more stories about Greg Heffley for years to come. This book is really special to me, because it reflects a renewed commitment to the series and a plan for the future.

No doubt fans, and Greg, are breathing a sigh of relief.

Kinney plans to continue his international tour this year in support of Book 11.

Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/1phWN01

column3: Spear phishing data breach hits SevOne
column4: ['Est March', 'Del News Journal', 'Scott Goss', 'P M', 'The Wilmington']
column5:
SevOne employees are seen at the company's Innovation and Technology Center at the University of Delaware Star Campus. (Photo: SUCHAT PEDERSON/THE NEWS JOURNAL)

WILMINGTON, Del.  SevOne fell victim to a cybersecurity attack that has put current and former employees at risk for identity fraud.

The tech company has confirmed it released W-2 wage and tax data to an unauthorized recipient outside the company. That information is believed to include Social Security numbers, home addresses, dates of birth and other personal information criminals can use to file false tax returns and commit other forms of identity theft.

The "unauthorized disclosure," which company officials said occurred Monday, was reported to current and former staff late Tuesday night in an email from SevOnes chief legal officer Diane Pryon. A copy of the email was obtained by The News Journal.

We are actively working to understand the incident and at this time we have no reason to believe any other SevOne data was affected, Pryon wrote. We sincerely apologize to anyone who may have been affected and will send additional communications as further information is learned.

Company officials declined to comment on the data breach, including details about how it occurred or how many people were affected, Wednesday.

Earlier this month, SevOne laid off less than 10% of its global workforce, which numbered about 525 in late 2015.

About 200 employees work out of the companys Innovation and Technology Center at the University of Delawares Science Technology and Advance Research campus in Newark.

The company said it will be providing current and former employees with two years of free credit monitoring services to help them avoid being victimized by the unauthorized disclosure.

Criminals behind the phishing scams use personal information gleaned from companies to make fraudulent tax filings to collect the returns. Pryon directed SevOne employees to file their taxes as soon as possible to pre-empt a possible false claim using the leaked data.

SevOnes data breach is believed to have been a cyberattack known as spear phishing. The scheme involves a spoof email that appears to come from a company executive requesting sensitive information from an unsuspecting employee.

SevOne, a network infrastructure monitoring company with Fortune 500 clients, might be a high-tech business, but that does not mean its employees are any less susceptible to a phishing scam, said Greg Gurev, head of the Stanton IT security company MySherpa.

"This kind of thing has nothing to do with tech," he said. "These scammers aren't attacking the tech by cracking your password. They're socially engineering their way in by exploiting a flaw in the human condition."

This screen grab from the Internal Revenue Service website shows a sample W-2 form. Employers are being tricked into sending detailed employee tax information to scammers as part of an emerging tax fraud campaign. (Photo: ASSOCIATED PRESS)

Several companies across the country have fallen victim to spear phishing attacks in recent weeks, including the video messaging app Snapchat, California-based data storage company Seagate and Main Line Health in Pennsylvania.

Smaller businesses ranging from concrete supply companies to landscaping businesses also reportedly have been suckered by the scam.

The Internal Revenue Service issued a consumer alert about phishing and malware scams last month after recording a 400% surge in reports this tax season.

The IRS followed that alert with a March 1 warning to payroll and human resources professionals specifically regarding spear phishing schemes.

Nearly 800 criminals have been sentenced in the last year for IRS-related identity theft, but many email phishing scams originate overseas, making prosecution nearly impossible.

Some form of tax-related theft has always existed, but its something that has taken on new forms as our reliance on technology has increased, said IRS spokesman Clay Sanford. Its unlikely these scams are ever something that can be completely eliminated.

Sanford said similar email-based scams have been reported in which messages are sent purporting to be from the IRS, tax accountants and tax software companies. The messages typically seek information related to refunds, filing status, personal information or claim to require personal identification number verification.

"They often go so far as to use logos, fonts and false identifiers directly from our website, he said. Unfortunately, the best tool we have to prevent taxpayers from becoming victims to these types of attacks is raise public awareness.

The IRS website includes several tips to avoid becoming a victim to scams. Those suggestions include learning how to recognize phishing emails, not opening email attachments from unfamiliar sources and using virus/malware protection software.

Gurev said companies also should routinely conduct a data security audit that maps out their sensitive data, where that information is stored and who can access it.

"You have to raise awareness in an organization and create a policy," he said. "That way anyone who is asking you to transfer money or send information that's critical, your people know that data is not to be sent via email. At the very least, you walk over to your manager and get verification in person first."

Sanford also warned about lower-tech IRS telephone scams that have cost taxpayers an estimated $26.5 million over the last three years.

We dont send unsolicited emails to taxpayers, he said. And we dont call taxpayers requesting personal information without some written verification being sent in advance.

Anyone who receives an unsolicited email that appears to be from either the IRS or an organization closely linked to the IRS, such as the Electronic Federal Tax Payment System (EFTPS), can report it by forwarding the message to phishing@irs.gov.

Follow Scott Goss on Twitter: @ScottGossDel

Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/1p9tBro

column5:
The pale, gaunt prince of punk is back.

Iggy Pop has a new album out Thursday, Post Pop Depression, which is a collaboration with Queens of the Stone Age and Eagles of Death Metals Josh Homme. I havent listened enough to form a coherent opinion, but on first listen: It sounds fantastic.

The album stream is available now via NPR:

Pop says this might be his final record.

column3: 13 big companies keep growing like crazy
column5:
Sunflowers are in full bloom on a sunny day on August 16, 2010 in Altlandsberg near Berlin, Germany. (Photo: Andreas Rentz, Getty Images)

Good and dependable growth is getting hard to find. But a few companies seem to have found the answer.

Just 13 companies in the current Standard & Poor's 500, including social media giant Facebook (FB), apparel maker Under Armour (UA) and drugmaker Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALZN), have consistently and definitively posted faster revenue growth than the average company and are expected to do it again this year, according to a USA TODAY analysis of data from S&P Global Market Intelligence including just-released 2015 results. Each of these companies has posted revenue growth of five percentage points or greater than the average stock in the S&P 500 each of the past five years.

Growth is becoming golden - if for no other reason than its scarcity. Investors are getting increasingly concerned about where corporate growth will come from going forward. Last year, S&P 500 companies reported 2.9% lower revenue, S&P Global says. Analysts are also calling for revenue to drop 0.6% in the current quarter and inch up just 1.2% in 2016.

The average revenue growth of S&P 500 companies has been trending lower. (Photo: S&P Global Market Intelligence, USA TODAY via Microsoft Excel)

That's why investors seem willing to pay up for these dependable growth companies. The 13 companies growing like crazy have seen their shares gain an average of 6.9% over the past year - while the S&P 500 has declined by 4.3%.

These companies aren't just having a lucky year - or two. Five of the 13 stocks are technology companies - and it's not an accident they keep growing, says Joe Bonner, media and telecommunications analyst at Argus Research. "These companies have business models that are just very difficult to duplicate," he says. "These companies put the user experience first, before profitability" or catering to investors or analysts.

Take Facebook, which is the leader in the fast-growing social-media space. The company has posted average revenue growth of 56% over the past five years - outstripping the average annual growth of any of these 13 company. Last year, the company reported revenue of $17.9 billion, which is up 44% from the previous year. Analysts expect the company's revenue to grow another 43% this year.

Consumer discretionary companies are the second-most common source of companies with dependable growth after tech. Under Armour has been the fastest growing of this batch, posting average revenue growth the past five years of 30% and expected to grow another 26% this year. The growth, again, goes back to delivering the goods consumers want. The "bottom line," says Camilo Lyon, managing director of equity research at Canaccord Genuity, Under Armour "is a once-in-a-generation brand."

Growth isn't an automatic ticket to investor wealth. Alexion Pharmaceuticals, which develops and sells treatments for genetic diseases, has grown an average of 37% the past five years and expected to grow another nearly 20% this year. Shares are down about 24% over the past 12 months to Thursday's close of $140.52. Why? Growth expectations play a role, too. The company's revenue grew more than 16% last year to $2.6 billion. The trouble, though, was investors expected as much - and it was first time since 2006 the company didn't beat revenue expectations.

It's important to note fast growth doesn't always mean profit, either. Online retailer Amazon.com has posted average revenue growth the past five years of 26% and is expected to grow nearly 22% this year. But the company has posted net losses in two of the past five years. But this highlights one of the traits of these companies, Bonner says. "This is a bit of an exaggeration but if (Amazon) need(s) to hire 500 new engineers in a quarter of build out new data centers, they dont worry so much about how its going to look on" the bottom line, Bonner says.

Growth doesn't always come cheap.

Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/1phYGtF

column3: All towels at U.S. hotels will be made in USA
column5:
Marriott has announced it will produce all towels and bathmats used in its U.S. hotel rooms in the USA. (Photo: Standard Textile)

From now on, all towels made for Marriott Internationals nearly 3,000 hotels in the USA will be made in the USA.

Thursday, Marriott will announce that it will have only Made in the USA towels and bath mats in every guest bathroom.

The Bethesda, Md.-based hospitality giant has partnered with Standard Textile, which has factories in Thomaston, Ga., and Union, S.C., to produce the towels and bath mats with 100% cotton fiber grown in the USA.

Previously, Marriotts terry cloths were made in Jordan.

All its brands from the Courtyard Marriott to the Ritz-Carlton will participate in the new program.

The fact that these items can be made in the USA like they were 20 years or so ago I think makes more sense today than ever because the customer is very much more attuned into looking at an item to see if this is made far, far away, says John Adams, Marriotts senior vice president of global operations.

The move comes as Made in America has become a touch point in the U.S. presidential campaign. Candidates for both parties have campaigned against outsourcing manufacturing to other countries in order to produce more jobs domestically. Republican front-runner Donald Trump, also a hotelier with his Trump Hotel Collection, has come under fire for manufacturing branded products in China.

On the face of it, this seems rather clever, says Carl Winston, director of the Payne School of Hospitality at San Diego State University. I doubt its going to be much of an increase in supply costs. Theyre tapping into the public sentiment. Theres a sort of a nationalistic furor seeming to grip the U.S. in both the Democratic and Republican parties.

He added: "Its a nimble move for a giant company to make, At the end of the day will it make people go to their hotels? I dont know".

Annually, Marriott expects to produce 2.6 million bath towels and 4.9 million hand towels  about 5.6 million pounds of textiles that could stretch 4,300 miles.

Standard Textile says it has already hired 110 additional workers to handle the production. It expects to hire at least 40 more.

The two companies also say the initiative will reduce greenhouses gas emissions by eliminating more than 300 ocean-going container shipments annually.

Gary Heiman, president and CEO of Standard Textile, which has worked with Marriott for about a decade, says the company has invested $40 million in its U.S. plants to handle the production. Previously, the company manufactured products in Jordan and China.

We needed to enlarge those plants, he says. It just worked out perfectly that they wanted to manufacture in the USA, and we wanted to manufacture in the USA, and we wanted to grow our production. Were really investing in our people.

Marriott says producing in the USA wont cost the company any more money. It also promises that all the products, which will be phased in over the next two years, will be of the same quality.

We put a lot of time into making sure those products are really well-done and fit the brand that theyre in, in terms of size, quality and durability, Adams says.

column3: America's sweetest annual festivals
column5: There are dozens of annual sweets and dessert festivals across the USA to satisfy every appetite, from the Whoopie Pie Festival in Maine to the San Diego Cake Show in California and everywhere in between. On the traditional side, these festivals feature cookies, cakes, donuts and pies, from traditional fruit to something called a sonker. This summer, when the temperatures rise across the country, check out the ice cream and even banana split festivals, while loads of chocolate events take place well into the winter months. Peruse the gallery above for a sweets festival worth traveling to indulge in, and see more tasty festivals below.

column3: Greek yogurt makers aim for sales boost with all-day appeal
column5:
Get ready for Greek yogurt to take over your day. Brands are expanding their offerings from savory items to yogurt-based drinks in an effort to get people to consume Greek yogurt throughout the day. USA TODAY

Chobani will launch a line of savory yogurt-based "meze" dips in June as it aims to expand its portfolio beyond yogurt itself. (Photo: Chobani)

Greek-style yogurt is already a mainstay for many breakfasts, but makers are now hoping it can take over your day.

As sales growth has slowed, Greek yogurt makers are looking for ways to expand sales and maintain interest by working themselves into other parts of the American diet.

The latest move comes from the nation's largest Greek yogurt brand, Chobani, which is announcing today that it will venture outside the dairy aisle with a line of yogurt-based savory dips in June. The brand extension will come in un-Greek flavors like smoked onion and parmesan, and three pepper salsa. That will be followed by Greek yogurt-based drinks in July.

New York-based Chobani, which launched in 2005, hopes that its dips and drinks will sell with the same health halo of its Greek yogurt, underscoring its use of natural ingredients and reduced sugar content. Walmart is one of the main retail partners on the launches.

Chobani CEO Hamdi Ulukaya says the goal is to branch out from sweetened yogurts.

"This is the opening of our savory (push)," says Ulukaya, who founded the company based on the idea of bringing the yogurt he grew up with in Turkey to the U.S. "I am not just a yogurt company. Youll see Chobani entering in different categories."

The move to look for new opportunities comes as sales growth for the protein-packed cups has started to level off.

Chobani Executive Chef Tim Reardon makes us the new roasted red pepper dip. USA TODAY

At one point, between 2012 and 2013, sales grew by more than 50%, while non-Greek yogurt sales fell 9%, according to Nielsen data. In the past 12 months, the category saw sales of $3.7 billion, up 4.8% from same period last year.

While industry experts agree that appetites for Greek yogurt are still strong, they also say more intense competition is putting pressure on the category to introduce customers to something new.

"It certainly seems like Greek yogurt is ripe for innovation right now," says Darren Seifer, food and beverage industry analyst for NPD Group. "There are just many more considerations when people are grabbing for a morning meal or snack meal and the segment needs to compete with that."

And compete with each other. As Chobani gained strength, General Mills countered with a Greek version of its Yoplait brand in 2010. Dannon launched a Greek brand called Oikos the same year. Then both brands more recently followed Chobani  which launched it's mix-in line called "flip" in 2014  with new versions focused on letting customers swirl in different grains, nuts and seeds. Dannon launched Oikos Crunch in January, with mix-ins like coconut chocolate crunch and key lime crumble.

Now in order to keep up momentum, market researchers say companies need to convince Americans to broaden their palates.

"Americans will have to fundamentally change the way they eat breakfast, snack, and dine at lunch and dinner for consumption to rise significantly," wrote analyst George Puro in a report on the yogurt industry last year for market research firm Packaged Facts.

Makers are looking at how yogurt is eaten abroad  in greater varieties and throughout the day and sensing new opportunity in the U.S.

"The evolution of yogurt into savory and different cuisine type of flavors will happen," says Doug Martin, marketing director for yogurt innovation at General Mills. "Our challenge is for the American consumer today  they tend to be in that morning, creamy, fruity mindset. They might not necessarily be looking for it."

While it's not ready to share details yet of what customers can expect beyond the dips and drinks, Chobani's Ulukaya is certain it will spark major change in the way Americans fill their pantries and refrigerators.

"You're going to look back five years from now and youll see that yogurt is going to be a dominant, dominant food of every household in America," he says.

Even after Fuller House we're not comfortable with the laugh track on Netflix. We'll have to see if Kutcher makes it worth it. The Ranch debuts on Netflix on April1.

column3: Report: Ex-ISIL militant leaks thousands of files
column5:
In this undated file image posted on June 30, 2014, by the Raqqa Media Center of the Islamic State group, a Syrian opposition group, which has been verified and is consistent with other AP reporting, fighters from the Islamic State group parade in Raqqa, northern Syria. (Photo: Uncredited, AP)

A disillusioned former Islamic State militant leaked tens of thousands of documents containing the names, addresses and phone numbers of 22,000 of the groups extremists to Sky News, the British broadcaster said Thursday.

Sky said the informant, who calls himself Abu Hamed, stole a memory stick containing the information from the head of the extremist groups internal security police and passed it to its reporter at a secret location in Turkey.

Hamed is a former member of the Free Syrian Army  formed by deserters from Syrian President Bashar Assad's military  who defected to the Islamic State, also known as ISIS or ISIL. He said he quit ISIL because Islamic rules have collapsed in the organization.

Sky reported that jihadis from at least 51 countries including Britain, the United States and Canada joined the group after filling out a form with 23 questions. It said some of those on the list were known to authorities, but others were not and the details, which have been passed on to officials, could be used to prevent further attacks.

One of the files  marked "Martyrs"  contained the names of those who wanted to carry out suicide attacks, Sky said. It added that many of the militants named in the documents were able to enter Syria to fight and then return to their home countries.

Hamed told Sky that ISIL planned to move its headquarters from Raqqa in northern Syria to the central Syrian deserts and then to Iraq, where the group originated.

He also claimed that ISIL, the Kurdish People's Protection Units (YPG) militia  which has been an ally of the U.S.  and Assad's regime were jointly working against the moderate Syrian opposition. Turkey considers the YPG to be a terrorist organization, but Washington does not. Assad claims to be fighting ISIL.

Col. Steve Warren, a spokesman for the U.S.-led coalition against ISIL, said he could not verify the documents, but said he hoped that a media outlet publishes the information if they have it.

This would allow the law enforcement apparatus across the world to become much more engaged and begin to help do what we can to stem this flow of foreign fighters  so were hopeful that its accurate and if so we certainly plan to do everything we can to help, he said.

Germany's Federal Criminal Police said Monday that it was in possession of confidential ISIL documents containing fighters personal information and that experts said they were authentic, the DPA news agency reported. The agency said it wasnt clear how the police force obtained the documents.

German newspaper Sueddeutsche Zeitung said it also obtained similar files.

Germany's Interior Minister Thomas de Maiziere on Tuesday said the information will facilitate "speedier, clearer investigations and stricter prison sentences" and "it helps us to understand the underlying structures of this terrorist organization," DPA reported.

column3: The 5 steps to starting a club at your college
More airports calling out TSA for long lines
column5:
Passengers wait in line to go through the new north security checkpoint of Terminal 1 at the Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport on Feb. 26, 2016. (Photo: Leila Navidi/Star Tribune via AP)

The Transportation Security Administration finds itself under increasing criticism for its airport staffing levels as the busy spring travel season begins to shift into high gear.

Already, Atlantas airport  the busiest in the world  publicly called out the agency last month for persistently long lines that it blamed primarily on staffing levels.

Now, some of the nations other top airports are joining the fray.

Seattle-Tacoma International Airport became one of the latest. The airport warned fliers on Wednesday via Twitter they should expect longer wait times because TSA staffing (is) not keeping pace (with) passenger volumes. Seattle added a hashtag saying #PackYourPatience.

@AskTSA staffing not keeping pace w/ passenger volumes. Expect longer wait times & #PackYourPatience. pic.twitter.com/zoKInTWV4M  Sea-Tac Airport (@SeaTacAirport) March 9, 2016

And it was just last week that officials at Minneapolis/St. Paul International Airport (MSP) publicly aired their frustrations about growing security queues there.

Jeffrey Hamiel, CEO of the agency that operates MSP, fired off a letter to TSA Administrator Peter Neffenger decrying the TSAs staffing. In his letter, Hamiel said passenger volume at MSP has jumped more than 10% since 2011 while the number of TSA screeners nationwide had dropped about 15% over that period.

"Those diverging trend lines  increasing passenger levels and declining numbers of federal screeners  are a recipe for unacceptable customer service. We have reached that point at MSP," Hamiel wrote in the March 3 letter to Neffenger, according to The Associated Press.

Hamiel says security checkpoint wait times of up to 40 minutes have become common at MSP.

Chicago OHare also has seen a spike in checkpoint wait times, with some airlines going so far as to post advisories on their websites warning Chicago fliers to arrive to the airport earlier than normal.

"We are doing the best we can with the resources that we have," TSA spokeswoman Lorie Dankers told AP in response to the complaints from MSP.

However, AP notes the TSA may have its hands tied when it comes to addressing staffing levels. The news agency writes Congress has capped the number of uniformed screeners for budgetary reasons: About 42,800 screeners nationwide now, compared with a peak of about 50,000 a few years ago, (Dankers) said.

Against that backdrop, the TSA has began conducting more thorough inspections of people and carry-on luggage since last summer's revelation of startling security gaps at U.S. airports, AP writes.

Both Neffenger and Homeland Security secretary Jeh Johnson have acknowledged the creep in average wait times in testimony to Congress. But, for now, only a modest increase in TSA staffing appears likely for the forseeable future.

"Eventually, we will reach capacity, and in some places we already exceed capacity during peak travel periods," Neffenger acknowledged in testimony to Congress on March 1.

Sharon Pinkerton, senior vice president for legislative and regulatory policy at Airlines for America, urged TSA to reduce wait-times in the short term through better staffing assignments during peak travel times and additional canine teams.

"We need to make sure theyre going to the right spaces," Pinkerton told USA TODAY. "We urge TSA to focus on short-term wins to try to make sure that we keep those wait-times reasonable."

column3: Go champion speechless after 2nd loss to machine
column5:
South Korean professional Go player Lee Sedol appears on the screen during the second match of the Google DeepMind Challenge Match against Google's artificial intelligence program, AlphaGo at the media room in Seoul, South Korea, Thursday, March 10, 2016. (Photo: Lee Jin-man, AP)

SEOUL, South Korea - The human Go champion said he was left speechless after his second straight loss to Googles Go-playing machine on Thursday in a highly-anticipated human versus machine face-off.

Lee Sedol, one of the best Go players in the world with 18 world championships, was grim and ashen after the game, which lasted more than four hours.

Im quite speechless, he said at the press conference that was livestreamed on YouTube. It was a clear loss on my part. From the beginning there was no moment I thought I was leading.

The latest victory by AlphaGo over South Koreas Lee puts Googles AlphaGo team one victory away from claiming the $1 million prize.

If AlphaGo wins, the prize money is to be donated to UNICEF, Go organizations and charities.

AlphaGos first win against Lee, on Wednesday, shook the Go-playing world, marking a milestone in the development of artificial intelligence.

Hundreds of thousands of South Koreans, even those who do not play the popular board game, followed the games on live TV and on YouTube. All major local newspapers reported Lees loss on their front pages.

2-year-old artificial intelligence masters 5,000-year-old human Go, said a headline in the Chosun Ilbo, South Koreas most circulated daily newspaper.

Many had believed it would take another decade for computers to conquer the ancient Chinese board game, one of the most creative games ever devised and the only board game left to conquer after chess was mastered by computers in 1997. Go is much more complex than chess.

Googles team compared AlphaGos win to landing on the moon.

The three remaining games run until Tuesday. Even if Lee loses the third game, he will play all five games.

Lee, 33, brimmed with confidence two weeks ago but that confidence was missing after two straight defeats.

The third game is not going to be easy for me, he said.

column3: New car tech speeds into the future
column4: ['Est March', 'A M', 'Special For Usa Today', 'Jennifer Jolly']
column5:
Tech columnist Jennifer Jolly shows you the hottest car tech speeding into the future.

2017 Chevrolet Bolt EV (Photo: Chevrolet)

Imagine for a moment that youre driving late at night and start to fall asleep at the wheel. What do you do? Pull over and sleep for a few hours? Maybe. Crank open the windows, blast music and smack yourself a few times? Probably. Put your car on auto-pilot and snooze away? Never. Well sooner than you think, you very well might.

Ive just finished a 10-day test drive of Volvos 2016 XC90 T6 R. It already provides semi-autonomous features that let the SUV take over the steering and throttle to follow the car in front of it at speeds up to about 35 miles per hour. Thats perfect for traffic jams and congested city driving, and just one of several new next-generation features aimed at making people safer behind the wheel.

By now we all know that our car is really just one big gadget, and a dangerous one at that. According to government reports, traffic fatalities rose nearly 10% in 2015. Thats the biggest one-year leap in a half century. So now, automakers are in a race to curb the biggest cause of traffic accidents to date: drivers themselves. Semi-autonomous features like pilot assist are just the beginning.

The Smarter, Safer Car of the Future

Tomorrow's smart cars are already starting to show up today. In addition to Volvos pilot assist, feature, its one of several new vehicles sporting new safety tech that bring us one step closer to self-driving cars. Audi, Tesla, Cadillac, Lexus, and others also contain various levels of active safety features, where your car takes over driving in certain instances.

With the XC90, the car's ability to put the brakes on and react faster than a human in certain situations is pretty amazing. It recognizes if you turn into traffic or a cyclist swerves in front of you, and warns you with a loud beep and flashing red flag in the built-in heads-up-display. It also taps the brakes, and just in case youre still not getting the message, the XC90 actually comes to a full stop.

An array of sensors, cameras and a generous dose of AI drive these functions. The Volvo can also warn you of a possible collusion if a car is approaching too fast, see lane markings on the road and keep you safety between them. As is becoming more and more common in high end cars, the XC90 can even park itself. It's not quite a self-driving car, but it's at least half way there.

Of course it's not all about safety: The iPad-esque 9-inch Sensus touchscreen serves as the high-tech control center of it all, with a built-in Wi-Fi hotspot and support for Apple CarPlay and Android Auto for easy integration with your smartphone. Its also a twin-engine plug-in hybrid, that just happens to go from 0-60 in about five seconds.

I was shopping for a car when I test drove this beauty and would have bought in an instant if the mileage were better (average 22 combined city/highway) and the price tag lower. The Volvo starts at $43,950. Sadly, thats a little too much awesome for my more practical budget.

The Greener, More Efficient Car of the Future

While the XC90 is a fantastic car, its still a long way from being the most efficient car on the road. Fortunately for anyone looking to go green, we're finally starting to see all-electric cars with enough rangeand a low enough price tagfor them to be accessible to all of us.

The 2017 Chevrolet Bolt, due out later this year, has a starting price tag of about $37,500 which you'll likely be able to drop to around $30,000 with tax credits. This won't put the Bolt at lowest price tierit will compete with models like the $28,995 Volkswagen e-Golf, the $29,010 Nissan Leaf, the $33,900 Ford Fusion Energi and even Chevy's own $33,170 Voltbut Bolt has another advantage.

Modestly priced electric vehicles currently on the market have limited battery life. The Ford Fusion Energi can only go a scant 21 miles before needing to recharge, while the Nissan Leaf is the best of the lot with a maximum of 107 miles between charges. But The Bolt has an impressive 200-mile range. That's double the mileage of current moderately priced electric options and nearly reaches the 270-mile range of the pricey $69,000 Tesla S. Though Tesla is working on its own affordable electric carthe Model 3  it won't be in production until next year while you'll be able to pick up the Bolt this fall.

Never having to stop for gas isn't the only thing the Bolt has going for it  you can expect to find all of the regular high-tech bells and whistles. Chevy's MyLink system pairs your phone and car together to let you send or receive calls and texts, control music, and use voice commands. One particularly cool feature of the Bolt's 10.2" touchscreen interface is the fact that you can configure the on-screen widgets to display however you'd like  a customization you don't see on most cars. For electric car newbies, the Bolt's display will walk you through information about the car's energy usage and tech you about car features, making it as much a digital manual as an in-dash control center.

Even More High-Tech Car Tech

Safety and efficiency aren't the only buzzwords you'll find in the auto industry shopping for a new car. Carmakers are also trying to figure out how to use virtual reality and augmented reality to help you buy the right car or learn to use the one you have. As you might have seen from my CES coverage this year, Audi has already started rolling out a VR car-shopping experience in its showrooms and certain 2016 Hyundai models have AR manuals that let you point your device at the car to see more information.

And as for affordable self-driving cars? Though the industry is pushing forward with features like the Volvo's automatic parking and breaking features, autonomous cars are likely still a few years away. But theres a good chance self-driving cars will be here sooner than you think, as semi-autonomous driving continues to roll out on roadways near you, one spectacular feature at a time.

Jennifer Jolly is an Emmy Award-winning consumer tech contributor and host of USA TODAY's digital video show TECH NOW. E-mail her attechcomments@usatoday.com. Follow her on Twitter @JenniferJolly.
