column3: Oh Canada! U.S. dollars go far when the whole country is on sale
column4: ['Est March', 'Heather Greenwood Davis', 'Heather Greenwood Davis Smartertravel Com', 'A M']
column5:
Ontario has more than 60 maple syrup-producing farms, and most offer family-friendly experiences. (Photo: Getty Images/iStockphoto)

International family travel can be a tricky business. On the one hand, there's so much world out there to see. On the other: terror alerts, the expense of trying to feed and entertain the whole family, and long travel times. All of which can make it very easy to talk yourself out of a trip.

If only there was a place with worldly charm that was close enough to get to easily, felt safe, and didn't cost you an arm and a leg. There is. Canada  thanks to a strong U.S. dollar and a falling Canadian loonie  is on sale. One Canadian dollar is about 70 U.S. cents. Book a flight or just hop in the car and head for the border to take in one of these five truly Canadian experiences for less. We guarantee you'll be singing the country's praises all the way to the bank.

Sweet deal in Ontario

Get to: Toronto, Ontario

Why: There's something about that northern air that makes Canadian maple syrup the best there is.

Why now: A warmer winter means that production will be underway sooner than usual, and could result in a record-setting production year. Good-natured Canadians will be more than happy to share the bounty.

The deal: Ontario has more than 60 maple syrup-producing farms, which means you can have your pick of where you go. Most offer family-friendly experiences where you cannot only watch it be made, but also have a treat or two while you do so. Tour prices at most farms come in at about $7.50 USD per person. Time your visit for April 2 or 3 and the price will even better: Free! The second annual Maple Weekend will offer everything from pancake breakfasts and horse-drawn sleigh rides to production tours and demos.

Lazy days in Quebec

Get to: Montebello, Quebec

Why: Montreal and Quebec City tend to steal most of the French province's tourists, but if what you're after is a charming weekend getaway with the kids during which you're hoping your biggest concern will be how many times you'll indulge in the decadent foie gras poutine during your stay, this is your spot. The gorgeous Fairmont Chateau Montebello fills up quickly. For good reason: On any given day, guests in yoga pants, slippers and robes reading books and playing board games make up the majority of loungers around the six-sided, 80-foot-tall fireplace in the hotel's main hall.

Why now: In the winter, outdoor enthusiasts will love the snowshoeing, dogsled rides and curling lesson options, as well as the outdoor skating rink. In the summer, fishing, bear watching, horseback riding and hiking will keep kids excited and engaged.

The deal: The hotel is intimate and popular. Book now to lock in summer dates and you'll be rewarded. The July Family Month promotion offers rooms from $206 USD ($279 CDN) per night including daily buffet breakfast and your choice of a family fun activity. (Choices include a family pass to the phenomenal Parc Omega  a nearby wildlife park where animals roam free and eat right from your car window.)

Drumheller is home to the world's largest dinosaur, an 86-foot-tall Tyrannosaurus rex whose mouth acts as a lookout point over the town. (Photo: ronniechua, Getty Images)

Prehistoric monsters in Alberta

Get to: Drumheller, Alberta

Why: What Roswell is to aliens, Drumheller is to dinosaurs. Year-round, the town celebrates the prehistoric animals that once roamed these badlands. From the world-famous Royal Tyrrell Museum of Paleontology (filled with incredible artifacts and interactive models) to the world's largest dinosaur (an 86-foot-tall Tyrannosaurus rex whose mouth acts as a lookout point over the town), you'll be able to satisfy any dinosaur fan.

Why now: New dinosaur discoveries are being found in the area all the time and your family can participate in archeological digs that vary according to age. Don't feel like getting dirty? "Hellboy"  a Regaliceratops skull found by a member of the public in 2005  is now on display inside the paleontology museum.

The deal: The town's Ramada Inn offers comfortable rooms, free buttered popcorn, and a giant pool and waterslide. Its Royal Tyrell Museum Package starts at $110 USD ($150 CDN) and includes a skip-the-line museum family admission pass for two adults and up to six kids.

Prince Edward Island, the real island home of the fictional Anne of Green Gables, is a popular spot for fans from around the world. (Photo: Elenathewise, Getty Images/iStockphoto)

All about Anne in PEI

Get to: Charlottetown, Prince Edward Island (PEI)

Why: The real island home of the fictional redheaded Anne of Green Gables is a popular spot for fans from around the world. There's plenty of Green Gables lore to see here  from namesake chocolates to the house that author Lucy Maud Montgomery based her stories around  but it's not the only reason to come. A wealth of festivals that celebrate music and art, theatrical productions that impress, and seafood suppers that require loose-waisted pants all make Prince Edward Island the perfect Canadian getaway.

Why now: Canadians know to book cottages in PEI early to beat the summer rush. Waiting to reserve accommodations won't net you a better deal, and it might mean you won't find a spot.

The deal: The Island's The Vacation the Kids Took Over packages offer a variety of three-night packages at various cottages and resorts for stays between June 18 and Sept. 1. One example: A three-night stay in a two-bedroom chalet at the four-star Fairways Cottages for $580 USD ($789 CDN), plus taxes. The deal includes a four-day, unlimited entrance pass to the best area family attractions and beaches for a family of four.

Wildlife and road trips in British Columbia

Get to: Blue River, British Columbia

Why: British Columbia is a thing of beauty. From the cosmopolitan charm of Vancouver to the sky-high old-growth forests of Vancouver Island, and beyond to the warm waters of Osoyoos, a road trip offers breathtaking views of mountain, ocean and sky.

Why now: Spring brings new life to the province. When you aren't marveling at the size of trees wider than your car or at the gourmet offerings of chefs who rely on Pacific Ocean bounty, you'll be wondering about the animals that call the West Coast home. Spend time in Clearwater; Alpine Meadow Resort offers incredible views and comfortable log cabin accommodations off the beaten path.

The deal: The River Safari company in nearby Blue River will offer your family the experience of a lifetime. Book the Super Safari package for tours on land and water of Grizzly Bear Valley. Kids will have fun playing lookout as your eagle-eyed guide points out the local bears who call the temperate rainforest home. Packages are $110 USD ($150 CDN) for a 2.5-hour tour. Stay for lunch  the forest-to-table meals in the restaurant are to die for.

column3: Russian Foreign Minister questions meldonium ban
column5:
(Photo: The Associated Press)

MOSCOW (AP)  Coming to the defense of Maria Sharapova and others caught using meldonium, Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said Thursday the drug never should have been banned.

Lavrov, echoing comments made by the inventor of the drug, said it was "a very strange decision, according to expert opinion" to put meldonium on the list of banned substances.

"In recent days there has been no limit at all to comments from specialists, including the inventor of this substance," Lavrov told Russia's Ren TV. "They clearly and professionally explain that it isn't doping at all but a normal method for supporting the body and its basic functions."

Meldonium, a blood-flow drug that historically was used to improve Soviet soldiers' endurance, was banned as of Jan. 1.

On Monday, Sharapova said she had tested positive for the drug at the Australian Open. She said she had been taking it for years to treat a number of medical issues.

Despite her positive test and suspension from playing tennis, Sharapova thanked her fans on Wednesday in a Facebook post.

"I woke up yesterday morning with an inbox, in full capacity of love and compassion," Sharapova wrote. "On average, I love the mornings. New day, new start. It is fair to say that this day was not average. Nothing came to mind at 6am, except that I am determined to play tennis again and I hope I will have the chance to do so."

The World Anti-Doping Agency said meldonium was banned because there was evidence it enhanced performance and was being widely used in sports.

Lavrov, however, demanded that WADA present more evidence to prove that meldonium did enhance performance while suggesting the drug's Soviet origins could have led to prejudice against the substance.

"The recent situation raises a lot of questions when a flurry of bans and accusations has been aimed at our leading, great athletes," he said.

A study published Wednesday in the British Journal of Sports Medicine found that up to 490 athletes may have been taking meldonium during last year's European Games in Baku, Azerbaijan. The drug was not banned at that time.

So far this year, Sharapova and top Russian athletes in sports such as speedskating, ice dancing and cycling have tested positive for meldonium. Others include 1,500-meter runner Abeba Aregawi of Sweden and Olympic wrestling silver medalist Davit Modzmanashvili of Georgia.

Another Russian athlete tested positive on Thursday. The Russian Biathlon Union said Eduard Latypov, a 21-year-old biathlete who won a gold medal at last year's world junior championships, tested positive at a round of the IBU Cup last month.

Latypov is the third biathlete to have tested positive for meldonium after Ukrainian national team members Olga Abramova and Artem Tyshchenko.

All three have been provisionally suspended by the International Biathlon Union.

Copyright 2016 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.

column3: GM investors like Russia exit
column5:
Russia says General Motors (GM) will miss opportunities in the country by cutting back on sales and production there. Investors disagreed, bidding up GM shares about 0.2%, to near $38.70, in afternoon trading today.

GM said Wednesday that its discontinuing its German Opel brand in Russia, phasing out mainstream Chevrolet models and concentrating instead on high-dollar, high-profit vehicles such as the Cadillac brand and Chevrolets Corvette and Tahoe.

GM said it will close a Russian factory this year, close dealerships and take a $600 million charge for the moves.

Russias Trade and Industry Minister Denis Manturov told reporters at a conference in Moscow today that he thinks its unlikely that other automakers, or companies in general, will bail from Russia, where the rubles value had fallen in half making imports strikingly expensive.

Russian officials also said GM now will be in no position to capitalizing when the Russian economy and car market rebound.

In a note to clients Thursday before the market opened, Ryan Brinkman of JP Morgan said of GMs plan: We find the move encouraging....it will benefit adjusted earnings by helping reduce losses in Europe.

It also signals that GM is no longer focused on being the worlds largest automaker, but more appropriately on return on capital and return of capital, he wrote.

That follows a pledge by CEO Mary Barra on March 9, when she announced a $5 billion share buy-back. She told analysts in a conference call that GMs goal is to become the worlds most valued automotive company, and to do that it will return all available free cash flow to investors, realize 20% return on investment or higher and maintain a cash balance of $20 billion.

Ford Motor (F) previously said it has cut production in Russia as the new-car appears likely to continues slumping for the foreseeable future.

column3: Barack Obama taunts Canadian prime minister over Chicagos Stanley Cup win
column4: ['Luke Kerr-dineen', 'Charles Curtis', 'Maggie Hendricks', 'Nate Scott', 'Steven Ruiz', 'Nina Mandell']
column5:
President Barack Obama is hosting Canadian prime minister Justin Trudeau, and pointed out a fact that made Canadians wince.

Pres. Obama jokes to Canadian PM Trudeau: "Where's the Stanley Cup right now? I'm sorry, is it in my hometown?" https://t.co/y616fS2DyK  ABC News (@ABC) March 10, 2016

To be fair, the Blackhawks would not have won the Stanley Cup without the contributions of Canadians like Jonathan Toews and Duncan Keith. Trudeau made a similar jab at Obama during a February visit when he pointed out Canadas many Olympic gold medals in hockey.

The Blackhawks have won three Stanley Cups during Obamas time in office, and currently are in the lead of the Western Conference with a record of 41-21. If they do manage to win back-to-back Stanley Cups  a feat not accomplished since the Red Wings did it 1997 and 98  they will need to rush their White House appearance to make sure they can get in one last visit with their hometown president.

But Obama will have no problem going to the United Center to see the Blackhawks play, as the team gave him a lifetime parking pass at their last visit.

column3: DNC chair speaks on earning Millennial votes
Pope Francis cleans up costly saint-making process
column5:
Pope Francis arrives to lead the weekly general audience in Saint Peter's Square, Vatican City on Feb. 24, 2016. (Photo: L'Osservatore Romano via epa)

VATICAN CITY (RNS)  The Vatican published new rules Thursday tightening financial oversight of the canonization process after leaked documents revealed abuses and high costs in creating saints.

The new measures, approved by Pope Francis, focus on how the Holy See handles applications for sainthood, a lengthy and expensive process that involves examining claims made by supporters of a would-be saint.

The guidelines demand regular accounting by the person managing the application in addition to scrupulously respecting the intention of donors who finance an appeal for sainthood.

They also impose greater supervision at every stage, giving the Vaticans Congregation for the Causes of Saints the power to demand financial information and documents from the administrator at any time.

Anyone caught abusing their office in the sainthood process will face disciplinary measures, the Vatican said. The rules were put in place for a three-year trial period.

The move comes four months after leaked documents published by Italian journalists Gianluigi Nuzzi and Emiliano Fittipaldi detailed financial mismanagement within the Vatican administration, including the sainthood process.

Faithful fill St. Peter's Square during an unprecedented canonization ceremony by Pope Francis for two of his predecessors, John XXIII and John Paul III, at the Vatican on April 27, 2014. (Photo: Alessandra Tarantino, AP)

Nuzzis Merchants in the Temple claimed the canonization process cost an average of $550,000and said the Congregation for the Causes of Saints failed to keep balance sheets despite Francis attempts to impose greater financial accountability.

Nuzzi and Fittipaldi are currently being prosecuted by the Vatican for their alleged role in leaking the documents, in a trial widely criticized by press freedom groups.

Francis is expected next week to announce the date for the canonization of Mother Teresa, whose upcoming sainthood was fast-tracked following her death in 1997.

The high profile nature of Mother Teresas work in India and worldwide meant the cause for her sainthood was well-funded, although the popes new rules recognize this is not always the case.

Under the new measures, the Vatican is setting up a Solidarity Fund so applications for sainthood without wealthy backers can appeal for financial support. The Congregation for the Causes of Saints will decide whether to donate the requested funds on a case-by-case basis.

column3: The rise of robots
column5:
Meet Pepper the robot at CES 2016 in Las Vegas, Nevada. Aldebaran, the Japanese-owned company based in Paris that makes the 4-foot-tall robot is hoping everyone will want a robot companion. USA TODAY

SAN FRANCISCO  In an oddly positive view of a potentially dystopian future, almost two-thirds of Americans think within 50 years robots and computers will have taken over most work, but few think their own jobs are at risk.

A survey by The Pew Research Center found that 65% of American adults expect that by 2066, robots and computers will definitely or probably do much of the work currently done by humans.

And yet, even more expect that their own jobs will continue to exist unchanged.

Eighty percent said they expect their job will continue to exist in its current form during that time.

Only 6% said they expected their job would definitely not exist, the survey found.

While looming robot-enabled layoffs worry about 11% of workers, other concerns are much higher in their thoughts.

- 26% fret they could lost their job because their company is poorly managed.

- 22% say their shrinking industry could cause them to lose their job

- 20% lay in bed at night fearing their boss can find someone else who will do their job for less pay

- 13% fear they wont be able to keep up with the technical skills they need to stay competitive in their position.

Better-educated and wealthier Americans are less concerned about losing out in the job market to a robot or a computer.

For people with college degrees, 37% say losing their job to aa mechanical or computerized entity is unlikely.

Among those who have a household income of $75,000 or more, only 38% worry about non-human competition for their livelihood.

But the Americans who fear the rise of digital workers the least are those who labor in government, education or at a non-profit. Just 7% of them think robots and computers will definitely take over most human employment in 50 years.

column3: Stybar wins 2nd stage to lead Tirreno-Adriatico
column5:
POMARANCE, Italy (AP)  Zdenek Stybar timed his attack to perfection to win the second stage of the Tirreno-Adriatico on Thursday and move into the overall lead.

The Czech rider went clear at the top of the tricky final climb, opening up a gap on the short descent and holding off the chasing pack to win the 207-kilometer (129-mile) stage from Camaiore to Pomarance.

Peter Sagan of Slovakia led home an elite group of chasers, finishing second behind Stybar. Edvald Boasson Hagen of Norway was third.

Stybar took the leader's blue jersey from Daniel Oss and has an advantage of nine seconds over Greg Van Avermaet in the overall standings.

column3: Firefighters in Nova Scotia find fish clogging hydrant
column5:
Volunteer firefighters in Nova Scotia recently got a strange surprise when they found multiple fish lodged in a fire hydrant. (Photo: Screenshot)

Volunteer firefighters in Nova Scotia recently got a strange surprise when they found multiple fish lodged in a fire hydrant.

A fire crew was responding to a grass fire on Tuesday when they made the fishy discovery.

The crew tried to hook their truck to a water pump on the edge of a pond, but were unable to get any water from the pump, Shawn Carey, chief of the Aylesford and District Volunteer Fire Department, told the Canadian Broadcasting Company.

Carey said the crew took the hydrant apart to see what was obstructing the flow and found "a bunch of fish that came up through the strainer."

How they got in there is beyond me," Carey told CBC. "It actually clogged off our pipe so we couldn't get any water."

N.S. firefighters battling blaze find hydrant clogged with fish https://t.co/3h9C7RNccbpic.twitter.com/COEqMYZm7o  CBC Nova Scotia (@CBCNS) March 9, 2016

Carey said its not uncommon for salamanders to find their way into dry hydrants, but hes never heard of fish. "It was a first for all of us, he said.

Carey told CBC there were a dozen or so fish in the hydrant. He said a few survived and were thrown back into the pond.

Follow @MaryBowerman on Twitter.

column3: Nowhere is safe on '10 Cloverfield Lane'
column5:
Mary Elizabeth Winstead, John Goodman and John Gallagher Jr. star in what producer J.J. Abrams calls "a blood relative" of the 2008 found-footage monster movie. (Paramount Pictures/Bad Robot)

Mary Elizabeth Winstead and John Goodman in '10 Cloverfield Lane.' (Photo: Michele K. Short)

Sorry, Scooby-Doo, nobody heads up a Mystery Machine anymore like J.J. Abrams.

The producers signature, stamp and influence permeate the thriller 10 Cloverfield Lane (*** out of four; rated PG-13; in theaters Friday nationwide), a well-crafted affair by debuting director Dan Trachtenberg that mixes elements of an intimate stage play with the white-knuckled tension of a cracking good Twilight Zone episode.

Its not quite a sequel to 2008s Abrams-produced Cloverfield. And thats the best thing about it: Lane shares some connective and thematic tissue with the found-footage monster mash while also existing as both a Hitchcockian drama and an unlikely heros journey.

Something is amiss from the very start, with Michelle (Mary Elizabeth Winstead) packing her bags and heading down the Louisiana highway to somewhere, anywhere, in a fantastic wordless opening set to Bear McCrearys roiling, glorious score. One frightening car wreck later  for her and the audience  and Michelle wakes up in the underground bunker of very odd doomsday prepper Howard (John Goodman).

You get to know just enough about those two and their other enigmatic new housemate Emmett (John Gallagher Jr.) as Howard insists they dont go above ground because, as he says, theres been an attack. Is it Russians? Martians? North Korea? No one knows but its not safe outside, and insides a bit iffy as well, as a serious and often darkly comic situation develops between the threesome.

The middle of the movie borders on Lifetime-level drama theatrics, though Trachtenberg nails enough scenes to keep an appropriate tautness as the film moves into its revelatory third act, the definite highlight of Lane. Its not fair to ruin the payoff here, but its exceedingly well-played, consistent with the rest of the film and offers some surprise. (For those who absolutely, positively need a hint, pay attention to the songs that play on the bunkers jukebox.)

Proving again that he's undoubtedly one of the best character actors working, Goodman shines as Howard, an impossible-to-read lug of a guy with a burly, intimidating stature but also a sad sense of loneliness. Winstead is just as good, carrying the movies emotional burden on her shoulders much of the time.

Just like other Abrams films, where the central secrecy tends to overpower everything else in an audiences eyes, 10 Cloverfield Lane never tells the whole story and instead lets the viewer fill in their own blanks.

And if the geek guru and his chosen filmmaking collaborators go forward in keeping the Cloverfield name alive in such an insightful fashion  as Black Mirror has done for the TV sci-fi anthology crowd  then having the questions outnumber the answers is just the right formula.

Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/1piqv4X

column3: United pilots throw their support behind airline in board dispute
column5:
Pilots throw their support behind United in looming proxy board fight. (Photo: Alan Diaz, AP)

The union representing Uniteds pilots threw their support behind the airline Thursday, criticizing the attempt by two activist investors to reshape the carriers board with their own slate of directors.

In a statement, Todd Insler, chairman of the United Master Executive Council of the Air Line Pilots Association said that United's pilots have grave concerns about the sudden attempt by two activist investors to gain effective control of Uniteds Board of Directors. This coup attempt, being done for their own benefit and without publicly stating their intentions for the future of the airline, unnecessarily distracts all employees from our commitment to improve customer service and grow United Airlines.



Insler added that if those activist backed directors gain power, they will make changes that may please shareholders, but will promote short term gains to the detriment of Uniteds customers and employees.

The union, which represents over 12,000 pilots flying for United, said that is behind Uniteds CEO Oscar Munoz, who will return full time to the airlines helm on Monday after suffering a heart attack last year, and getting a heart transplant.

Its the latest volley in a brewing battle between United and PAR Capital Management, Inc. and Altimeter Capital Management, two hedge funds that together own 7.1% of the companys shares. On Tuesday, the funds announced that they would be nominating six candidates to the carriers board of directors, led by Gordon Bethune, the former CEO of Continental Airlines.

Bethune is responsible for turning Continental around in the 1990s when the airline had lagged in ontime performance, luggage handling and other important measures. Par and Altimeter have accused Uniteds board of previously lacking airline expertise, and steering the carrier to the bottom of the industry in terms of stock and operational performance.

column3: Raiders reach 4-year, $40 million deal with CB Sean Smith
column5:
ALAMEDA, Calif. (AP)  The Oakland Raiders added another top free agent to their offseason haul, agreeing to a four-year, $40 million deal with former Kansas City cornerback Sean Smith.

Smith's agent, David Canter, said Thursday that Smith had agreed to join the big-spending Raiders. Oakland previously reached deals with offensive Kelechi Osemele for up to $60 million for five years and pass rusher Bruce Irvin for up to a reported $39 million for four seasons.

But finding a cornerback was the top need in free agency, and Oakland won a heated competition for Smith. Smith has allowed opponents to catch fewer than 60 percent of passes for all seven of his NFL seasons and gives the Raiders the starter they needed alongside David Amerson.

column3: Fight Valley, starring Miesha Tate and Holly Holm, looks absolutely abysmal and we cant wait
column4: ['Luke Kerr-dineen', 'Charles Curtis', 'Maggie Hendricks', 'Nate Scott', 'Steven Ruiz', 'Nina Mandell', 'Laken Litman', "Nate Scott Is A Writer Editor At Ftw Leading The Site's Culture Coverage He Likes Writing About Soccer Basketball Music Tv The Evils Of The Ocean"]
column5:
Miesha Tate and Holly Holm, along with Cris Cyborg, are starring in a new movie called Fight Valley and, well, it just looks terrible. Not even terrible, though. Triumphantly terrible.

This movie is going to be an absolute nightmare of a movie, a completely putrid mess, and I couldnt be more excited about it. I will be there opening night with a large popcorn and so much Diet Coke my hands will shake.

Look at this thing:

The tagline is: One way in. No way out! It looks like it was shot by an 8th grader with a Handicam! A line from the actual script is I fight for all the wrong reasons! They didnt even have another character give that assessment! They had the character say it about herself! Also! Fight Valley is not a metaphor but apparently is an actual place!

This will be a Mona Lisa of badness. A wonderfully bad movie. So bad that it turns the corner and leans right into good. Lets all go. Lets go to Fight Valley, which again, is an actual place in this movie.

column3: Girls Sports Month: South Carolinas Aja Wilson on how sports helped her come out of her shell
column4: ['Jim Halley', 'Smith Iii', 'Cam Smith', 'Wtsmith Greenvillenews Com', 'Scout Recruiting', 'Usa Today High School Sports', 'Evan Daniels', 'Willie T']
column5:
COLUMBIA, S.C.  Aja Wilson could have attended any university in the country as a top-rated high school girls basketball player in the country as a senior at Heathwood Hall (Columbia, SC).

But the 6-4 athlete who was named to the American Family Insurance ALL-USA first team as a senior chose to remain close to home, signing with the University of South Carolina.

Since her arrival at the school, the outgoing Wilson has not disappointed. She was named the Southeastern Conference Freshman of the Year after helping the Gamecocks finish with a 34-3 record and a trip to the schools initial Final Four since the sport went under the guidance of the NCAA.

During the period USC posted a 15-1 record in the SEC for its second league regular season title. That was followed by the schools first SEC Tournament title.

Wilson improved during her sophomore season as she was named the SECs Most Valuable Player and Defensive Player of the Year, the second player to pull off that double.

The Gamecocks finished its first undefeated SEC campaign, going 16-0 and repeated as SEC Tournament champion.

Wilson was earlier named USA Basketball Female Athlete of the Year after her MVP performance in the 2015 FIBA World Championships in Russia.

As part of Girls Sports Month, we caught with Wilson as Mondays NCAA Tournament selections approach. The Gamecocks (31-1) are expected to get a No. 1 seed.

Q: When did you first become interested in sports?

Aja Wilson: I would have to say when I was 13 or 14 years old. I was kind of the girlie girl at the beginning. I didnt want to sweat, didnt want to get into it. But I just really started to fall in love with it just by watching it and having my dad, he played sports so of course I guess he is going to push his daughter to be an athlete.

I really got it from him watching it and being around it.

Q: Did you watch sports with your dad?

Aja Wilson: I would. I kind of had that daddy/daughter bond with him. We would just kind of sit and watch games, any sport really. I actually started out wanting to be a quarterback for the NFL. We could go outside and we would throw the football. I had a football in my hand before I had a basketball in my hand.

RELATED: More Girls Sports Month Coverage

I was kind of the tomboy. He really wasnt the type who was going to shoot me down. Nah, you cant play football. He really just went outside, threw the football with me and kept my dream going.

Q: You have much of an arm?

Aja Wilson: Yeah, a little bit.

Q: I know you were a very good volleyball player, did you play that or basketball first?

Aja Wilson: Basketball. Basketball was my first love, but I still have a thing for volleyball. I really enjoyed it. It kind of brought out a different side of me. I also ran track, played soccer.

Q: What track events did you compete?

Aja Wilson: The 100, 200, 400 and the 4X100.

Q: Pretty good?

Aja Wilson: I was the anchor so I guess they trusted me in some way to run that in the 4X100.

Q: How has sports helped you?

Aja Wilson: It really helped me become more sociable. It really opened a lot of doors for me. It just kid of taught me to say hey. When I went to trials you want to get to know people because you never know who you may be playing with.

Its always opened that extra door for me. Im always running my mouth. I just love talking and meeting with new people and being around new people. I feel sports have helped me a lot with that.

Also, coming out of my comfort zone. (USC) Coach (Dawn) Staley really pushes us to come out of our comfort zone on the court and it just turns over when we get off the court.

RELATED: Tamika Catching or her illustrious career and plans for afterward

Its just a habit. Its like second hand. You just kind of go with the flow of it. Youre like, Im doing it all the time on the court, so just do it in my everyday life. It opened up a lot of doors for me socially, just getting out of my comfort zone and not being that shy girl I had inside of me.

Q: Considering you height, has that social part of your personality helped considering youre always recognized?

Aja Wilson: It does, plus my mom always told me youve got to keep a good rep because you never know whos watching. I think sports really helped me because you really dont ask for it when youre an athlete. It just comes to you.

When they see a 6-4 girl walking through, theyre not going to be like  I cant hide. They know who I am. They see me. If they dont know my name, they see the height. You always have to be a people person and thats really where sports kind of helped me out, just to know everyone is watching so you might as well keep a smile on your face and just take it all in because you dont ask for it, it just happens.

Q: Where you always taller than you age group?

Aja Wilson: I had a growth spurt. It started when I went to high school. I was an average size girl. I think my dad was kind of worried because hes like 6-8 and my mom is 5-10. They were kind of like OK, whats going on with this child? It started my freshman year.

Q: What was that like, having it happen so late?

Aja Wilson: Thats a good question. I just took it all in. I really enjoyed being tall. I always kind of judged my height by my mom. I went from having the same show size as her in middle school  my mom kind of knew she might have a growth spurt.

Then, literally, I just woke up and was looking at the top of my moms head. I was like whoa.

It was kind of fun seeing me grow and just taking it all in, being a tall girl.

Q: I guess the positive part of it was getting to shop for new clothes?

Aja Wilson: Oh yes, yes, yes. Im pretty sure my mom was not a fan of that. Im like 14 looking in the womens section. My mom was like youre not going to wear that. It was a lot of shopping, especially shoe shopping. I think thats why Im a shopaholic now.

RELATED: Diana Taurasi used to play with the boys in high school

Q: Any role models in or out of sports?

Aja Wilson: Out of sports my mom and my grandmother are my role models. In sports its Elena Delle Donne and Candace Parker.

Q: Any advice youd give young girls interested in sports?

Aja Wilson: I dont want to sound like a cliche but just dont let anyone stop you from being you. Along with road there are a lot of people saying different stuff. But dont let anyone stop you. Enjoy who you are because, at the end of the day, youre going to be you no matter what. Just do you ad dont let anyone else say you cant do anything.

column3: First-generation American Carlos Balderas hopes to put U.S. Boxing back on the medal stand in Rio
column4: ['Luke Kerr-dineen', 'Charles Curtis', 'Maggie Hendricks', 'Nate Scott', 'Steven Ruiz', "Laken Litman Is An Enterprise Reporter Covering College Football Women's Soccer The Nfl", 'Nina Mandell', 'Laken Litman']
column5:
BALTIMORE  Carlos Balderas first stepped into a boxing gym when he was 7 years old. His father, Zenon, took him there because he was fighting in the streets and getting suspended from school.

Perhaps boxing would be a way to release energy and take out that anger, Zenon thought.

But the gym owner in Santa Maria, Calif. said Carlos was too young. Come back when youre older, Carlos Balderas recalled him saying. Maybe when youre eight or nine.

But when they walked into the gym that day, Zenon noticed a boy who couldnt have been much older than his son.

(The owner) was like, Oh thats my grandson, hes eight, but hes been boxing for a long time, Carlos said. My dad said, Lets put them up to box and if my son beats your grandson, we can stay here. If your grandson beats up my son, well come back.

The guy was like OK. So they put us up to box and I beat him. He was crying. And they allowed me to continue boxing. And it went on from there.

Balderas, now a 19-year-old lightweight boxer (132 pounds), is a first-generation Mexican-American who qualified for the Rio de Janeiro Olympics back in November. He was the first athlete to make the team and does not have to participate in Olympic team trials because he won a series of matches in 2015 that earned him a spot.

As Balderas prepares for Rio, hes focused on that gold medal. He wants to win it not only to honor the sport that saved him from a future of drugs and gangs, but for his familyhis motivation.

The Balderas are from an impoverished area in Oaxaca, Mexico. Balderas grandfather, David, moved to California over 40 years ago in search of a better life. He left his wife Sofia and their eight sons and workedand sleptin strawberry fields in order to make enough money to bring his whole family to the United States one day.

Eventually, David saved up enough to bring his family to Americaslowly. First some of his older sons came, then his wife and Zenonthe youngest boymade the trek. Carlos doesnt know how many years his grandma and grandpa lived apart, but said it took time and that David only stopped working in the fields a couple years ago.

I feel like I owe it to my family to do something good for myself as well as for them, Carlos said from a media summit with other Olympians at the Under Armour headquarters this week.

When his coach called in November to inform him hed qualified even before the Olympic trials, Carlos thought he was kidding.

It was very unexpected at the time, he said. I was in shock ... My family went crazy. I could see my dad. He started tearing up. So did my grandma and grandpa.

Balderas said hell have some family members with him in Rio, but not many because travel is expensive. But hell be boxing in their honor the whole time.

My family came from nothing, he said. It feels like, this is sort of a way to pay them back. I feel like this is only halfway. The other half is arriving in Brazil and bringing back a medal. I know my family would be happy with any medal, but Im looking for gold.

USA Boxing has struggled the last two decades. The U.S. has had a medalist in every Games since the inaugural boxing competition in 1904  until the 2012 Olympics in London.

The U.S. boxing program boasts 110 medalists  49 gold  and has given us stars like Muhammad Ali, Joe Frazier, George Foreman, Ray Leonard, Oscar De La Hoya and Floyd Mayweather. But there has only been one mens gold medal in the last three Olympics.

Balderas isnt thinking too much about this. When asked about the history of USA Boxing and its downfall, he remains steady on the task at handRio.

We have a very strong team, Balderas says. Im focused on myself and my performance because at the end of the day, each fighter is focused on himself.

This determination, he believes, will help him get what the U.S. hasnt achieved in some time.

Last spring, he faced off against the No. 1 lightweight boxer in the worldAlbert Selimov of Azerbaijanand even though the fight was called after four rounds, Balderas thought he should have won.

I was winning the fight, Balderas said. I hurt him on two occasions, I had him bad. But in the fourth round, he gave me a headbutt, and they had to stop the fight. I had nine stitches. I was beating him though so I feel like I have a big chance of beating him.

As soon as Balderas got involved in boxing as a kid, the trouble stopped. No more school suspensions or scoldings from his parents. The sport became his life. He chose it over beach trips or playing handball after school with his friends.

It saved me, he said. It takes up a lot of your time. You wake up early in the morning, you train, you go home, you rest, you eat, you go back to the gym. You really dont have time to be out in the streets or be out doing other stuff.

Boxing kept me away from bad friends, bad habits, parties. I didnt really have a childhood. I was always in the boxing gym. Im not complaining though because I got to the Olympic Games ... I had friends who were involved in drugs and gangs, so I had to pull myself away from that. I knew eventually I would start heading down that path if it wasnt for family and boxing.

A couple weeks ago, the Balderas family visited its roots in Mexico. Carlos had never seen the house where his grandparents lived in Oaxaca before moving to the States. He couldnt believe the size.

Seeing it in real life hit him hard.

Its a very, very small house, he said. We passed by and my grandma started tearing up. To see them like that...I feel like Im my familys greatest hope going to the Olympic Games. The first American generation made it to the Olympic Games.

I feel like I can give them a little more.

column3: Viewpoint: Why social media is destroying our social skills
column4: ['Courtney Rozen', 'Jasmine Fowlkes', 'Varsity Tutors', 'Usa Today Network', 'The University Of Texas At Austin', 'Usa Today Network Josh Hafner Usa Today', 'Sam Lisker', 'Alexandra Samuels']
column5:
Facebooking, tweeting and texting are not only the prevalent but also the preferred forms of communication for many college students and young adults today.

Social media interaction now dominates both online and offline conversations. In a society where interacting and over-sharing online is the norm, youre probably more likely to speak to friends and family through electronic devices than face-to-face.

But are social media and modern technology destroying our interpersonal social skills? Recent research and studies say so.

A study conducted for online casino Yazino found that one in four people spend more time socializing online, via sites such as Facebook and Twitter, than they do in person.

Too often at events or parties, guests are attached to their smartphones tweeting or texting, but no one is truly engaging or interacting with the people around them.

As more generations are born into the social age, social media will continue to be the favored communication form among young people. However, this shift may begin to affect their ability to properly communicate in person with peers.

Social media vs. interpersonal communication

Communication is constantly evolving. Some people are as used to seeing their friends online avatar as they are their face, Yazino founder Hussein Chahine said in The Telegraph. People increasingly prefer quick and frequent engagement with instant updates on news than a prolonged chat and are also finding new ways to catch up with friends from the comfort of their sofa.

The study also found that even when there is an opportunity to see people face-to-face, on weekends for example, up to 11% of adults still prefer to stay at home and communicate on their devices instead.

People tend to want to show others that they are having fun than actually having fun themselves, said University of South Florida graduate Mark Clennon.

Theres a greater desire to share with other people you barely know, than actually hanging out with friends and making memories, he added.

At the end of the day, nothing can replace face-to-face conversation and interactions. Despite the explosion of online endorsements and social media dialogue between individuals and brands, researchers have found word-of-mouth exchanges and in-depth conversation are still most influential.

According to the TalkTrack research used in Ed Keller and Brad Fays The Face-to-Face Book: Why Real Relationships Rule in a Digital Marketplace, our conversations in person are much more powerful than those online.

...The decisions we make are based on true interpersonal influence: social influence, which happens most often, and most powerfully, face-to-face, Keller and Fay note.

Keller-Fays TalkTrack research study also suggests that 90% of the influential conversations that we have every day happen offline, while only 8% are online.

Social media is big and growing, but it is still dwarfed by the analog world in which people live and interact, explain Keller and Fay.

Although being in the know and active on social media is amusing, hip and convenient, socializing online should be done in moderation when in the presence of friends at a gathering. Youll gain much more from having an in-depth conversation with a friend, rather than tweeting back and forth with them.

Step away from the smartphone

Cant seem to put your mobile device down when mingling with friends? Try these four suggestions to engage more with your peers.

1. For those who like to share their locations online using Foursquare and Facebook check-ins, check in before the party, concert or event even starts. Checking in and tweeting in the middle of the festivities not only takes away from your fun but also distracts you from socializing with friends and party-goers.

2. If everyone in your crew is attached to their phones when hanging out, make it entertaining by placing a bet or creating a game. Try making everyone put their cellphones away, and the first one to give in and use theirs pays for dinner. Or, have everyone place their phones in a common area at your next party; the last one to use their phone that night wins a prize or bragging rights.

3. With the increased popularity of Instagram, we all know how important it is to show everyone the fun youre having through pictures. Why not post your pics on Facebook and Instagram at the end of the night, or after leaving an event or party? This way, you arent missing out on a good time with friends while frequently uploading pictures. Youll have more great pics to choose from at the end of the night anyway.

4. When spending quality time with friends or family you havent seen in awhile, refrain from constantly checking and responding to emails or texts. Replying to a quick text or email during downtime is fine, but make a conscious effort to be present with the people youre spending time with. Encourage others to do the same.

Nothing replaces the once-in-a-lifetime experiences and memories made in college, and believe it or not, even with modern technology, those moments and feelings cant be tweeted, Facebooked or emailed.

column3: 'School of Rock' back in session, on stage and, now, TV
column5:
Tha cast of the new Nickelodeon series 'School of Rock': from left, Lance Kim, Ricardo Hurtado, Jade Pettyjohn, Breanna Yde, Tony Cavalero, Aidan Miner (Photo: Michael Elins)

School of Rock, the 2003 comedy classic starring Jack Black as Dewey Finn, a wanna-be guitar god who fakes his way into a job as substitute teacher at an elite school, is enjoying a second life right now, and a third one. Not in the form of a sequel (yet), but through stage and TV adaptations. A Broadway musical opened last fall, and Saturday marks the premiere of the Nickelodeon TV series School of Rock (9:30 ET/PT, then 8:30 starting next week) produced with Paramount, which released the film.

"So many parents love the movie," says Jim Armogida, who wrote and produced the new series with brother Steve. "It had great characters, and we felt we could focus a little more on their relationships and friendships, and tell the story from the kids' perspectives."

As in the film and musical, the young actors cast as students sing and play their own instruments, and the first season leads up to a Battle of the Bands that is Finn's mission and obsession. But details differ from version to version:

Ther Broadway cast of 'School of Rock,' Andrew Lloyd Webber's hit adaptation of the film, includes (L to R) Evia Dolan, Jared Parker, Isabella Russo, Alex Brightman, Brandon Niederauer, Alex Brightman (the tall guy) and Lucca Padovan. (Photo: Michael Monday, for USA TODAY)

THE FLAWED HERO

Movie: After getting tossed out of his band, Finn (Jack Black) poses as his roommate, Ned Schneebly (Mike White), to land a gig at the prestigious Horace Green Prep School. (Any resemblance to New York's prestigious Horace Mann is purely coincidental.) He bonds with his students after discovering they're musically gifted, but still neglects to pay rent, to the irritation of Ned's girlfriend (a marvelously whiny Sarah Silverman).

Broadway musical: Essentially the same, but Alex Brightman plays Finn, Spencer Moses plays Ned and Mamie Parris plays the irritable girlfriend.

Nickelodeon series: Ned and his girlfriend are missing, and the setting is William B. Travis Prep in Austin. Finn, played by Tony Cavalero, uses his own name, if not his own credentials; the students quickly figure out he's a fraud. (His mom is a teacher.) And he's blond.

THE SCORE

Original movie: The soundtrack featured rock classics by Led Zeppelin, Cream and Stevie Nicks, along with newer acts, with some original material performed by Jack Black and the cast.

Broadway musical: Musical-theater composer and rock fan Andrew Lloyd Webber wrote new songs with lyricist Glenn Slater, and included songs from the film.

Nickelodeon series: Tunes by artists from The Who to Demi Lovato are covered, and expect to hear some original contributions: "We have a number of musically inclined people on staff," Jim Armogida notes.

Jack Black (center) with Robert Tsai, Joey Gaydos Jr., Kevin Clark and Rebecca Brown in a scene from the 2003 film 'School of Rock.' (Photo: Andrew Schwarz,, Paramount Pictures)

THE GUITAR PRODIGY

Original movie: Joey Gaydos Jr. played Zack, the student who blows Finn away on axe, in the movie.

Broadway musical: Zack is played by 12-year-old Brandon Neiderauer, a protege of Jon Batiste, who performed on Ellen DeGeneres's show at 10. He has since performed with Gregg Allmann, George Clinton, Gary Clark Jr., Dr. John and the Neville Brothers.

Nickelodeon series: Zack is played by Lance Lim, 15, a film actor and TV actor (Fresh Off the Boat) who became a "fan favorite" singing on the Korean TV competition Star Audition.

Meet the new Finn: Tony Cavalero teaches the children well (Photo: Michael Elins)

PUPPY LOVE?

Original movie: As if! No crushes in this class, as far as we can see.

Broadway musical: Ditto

Nickelodeon series: In early episodes, Summer (Jade Pettyjohn) seems to be sweet on Freddy (Ricardo Hurtado), who becomes drummer in the class band.

Joan Cusack and Jack Black play Rosalie Mullins, no-nonsense principal of an elite school, and Dewey Finn, a hire with unconventional teaching methods, in the 2003 film 'School of Rock.' (Photo: Andrew Schwarz,, Paramount Pictures)

Sierra Boggess, right, plays the uptight Rosalie Mullins, who unwinds a bit in this scene with Alex Brightman, as Dewey Finn, from 'School of Rock -- The Musical.' (Photo: Matthew Murphy)

GROWNUP ROMANCE

Original movie: Finn and uptight principal Rosalie Mullins (Joan Cusack) bond over Stevie Nicks in a memorable bar scene.

Broadway musical: Rosalie is played by the silver-voiced Sierra Boggess

Nickelodeon series: No sparks between Finn and the principal (Jama Williamson) yet, but who knows?

Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/1pirzpq

column3: Richmond reserve Marshall Wood sidelined by concussion
column5:
NEW YORK (AP)  Richmond forward Marshall Wood will miss the Spiders' Atlantic 10 Conference tournament opener against Fordham on Thursday because of a concussion.

The school says the redshirt junior suffered the concussion Sunday in a single-car accident when he swerved to avoid a deer on the road.

He is in the Spiders' medical staff's concussion protocol and his status will be evaluated day to day if Richmond advances.

A transfer from Virginia Tech, Wood averaged 8.6 points and 3.9 rebounds this season. He was second on the team in 3-pointers made with 58 and scored a season-best 29 points with 7 3-pointers in a 93-82 victory at Fordham on Jan. 10.

Copyright 2016 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.

column4: ['Luke Kerr-dineen', 'Charles Curtis', 'Maggie Hendricks', 'Nate Scott', 'Steven Ruiz', "Luke Kerr-dineen Is A Writer Editor At Ftw Anglo-american Who Likes All Sports But Especially Golf Soccer He Saw The Spice Girls In Concert Once It's Been Downhill Ever Since", 'Nina Mandell', 'Laken Litman']
column5: This poor guy. He was just trying to have some fun catching a beer with his friends and then this happened. Though, in fairness, probably not the best idea to be trying to pull off this stunt this close to something that could really hurt you.

column3: Ivy League to hold postseason basketball tournaments in 2017
column5:
Yale players celebrate after securing the Bulldogs' first NCAA bid since 1962. (Photo: Nicole Auerbach, USA TODAY Sports)

The last Division I holdout on postseason conference basketball tournaments to decide an NCAA bid has acquiesced and will to join the other 31 leagues in 2017.

The Ivy League announced Thursday that it would hold men's and women's basketball tournaments beginning next year at the Palestra in Philadelphia, March 11-12.

"The presidents adopted the proposal to establish men's and women's basketball tournaments after thoughtful discussions and careful review of the thorough information provided by our athletics directors and head coaches. Ultimately, this decision was based on enhancing the overall experience for our basketball student-athletes, while also paying attention to time demands by shortening the regular season," said Peter Salovey, Yale president and chairman of the Council of Ivy League Presidents.

The format will be different, however: Four teams, two semifinal games on the first day (Saturday) with the No. 1 seed playing the No. 4 seed and No. 2 vs. No. 3 seed, followed by the championship game played the next day (Sunday). The winners will receive the automatic NCAA bids. The teams that finish with the best records from the 14-game, regular-season conference schedule will continue to be recognized as Ivy League champions.

"This is a great opportunity to showcase our talented student-athletes when all eyes are on college basketball, " said Princeton men's coach Mitch Henderson. "These tournaments enhance the importance of every single game of our conference schedule as our teams compete for the opportunity to be a part of a championship experience."

This year's champs are Yale (men), in the NCAA tournament for the first time since 1962, and Penn (women).

column3: 7 companies with good chances at big profits
column5:
Companies start revealing their third-quarter profit growth in just a few days. But savvy investors already know which stocks have the best chance for big-time profit growth.

There are seven stocks in the Standard & Poors 500 including real-estate firm Host Hotels & Resorts (HST), energy company Tesoro (TSO) and biotech Gilead Sciences (GILD) that Wall Street analysts are expecting to deliver 100% or greater profit growth for the third quarter, according to a USA TODAY analysis of data from S&P Capital IQ.

Hopes are high for these companies profit growth. If analysts are right, these companies will absolutely blow away the 6.8% profit growth expected from the S&P 500 during the quarter, S&P Capital IQ says.

When it comes to great profit growth expectations, no other company can match up to hotel property management firm Host Hotels. The company has been on the vanguard of the industrys move to reduce their business of owning hotels and shift more to a business model of managing franchisees and collecting lucrative license fees. The strategy is paying off big-time this quarter with profit growth. Analysts are calling for the company to post adjusted profit of 9 cents a share, up 800% from the same period last year.

Another company expected to report eye-popping earnings growth is Gilead Sciences. The biotech firm with breakthrough treatments for everything from liver disease to hypertension is expected to deliver adjusted quarterly profit of $1.89 a share. If the analysts are right, that would be profit growth of 263%. That might seem to be an impossible hurdle until you realize the company actually delivered even-higher 372% profit growth in the second quarter.

Perhaps more surprisingly is the huge expectation for Tesoro, an energy firm. Despite falling oil prices, analysts are still incredibly optimistic for what the company can deliver in terms of earnings growth for the quarter. Analysts see the company earning an adjusted 44 cents a share during the quarter, up 295% from the same-year-ago period.

But with great expectations comes great responsibility. With expectations for these companies so high already, it makes it that much higher to beat views. And during earnings season, investors are usually most impressed with the companies that manage to do better than expected, even though not much was expected.

Keep in mind, too, that these expectations are disseminated and priced into investors valuations of the stocks. High hopes for future profits often create high valuations. All but one of the stocks, Health Care REIT (HCN) are rated outperform by the average Wall Street analysts.

But five of the seven stocks already have dangerously high prices, according to New Constructs, a stock research firm that compares stocks current value with the current value of future cash flows. The two stocks with lukewarm neutral ratings are Gilead and Marathon Petroleum (MPC).

It wont be long before investors see if these companies can meet  or better yet beat  the sky-high expectations set for them.

Below are the seven stocks in the S&P 500 that are expected to deliver 100% or greater adjusted earnings growth:

Company Ticker Exp. Q3 profit % Ch. Wall Street rating New Const. rating Host Hotels HST 815% Outperform Dangerous Tesoro TSO 296% Outperform Dangerous Gilead Sciences GILD 263% Outperform Neutral Marathon Petro. MPC 249% Outperform Neutral General Growth GGP 206% Outperform Dangerous Health Care REIT HCN 148% Outperform Dangerous Valero Energy VLO 136% Outperform Dangerous

Sources: S&P Capital IQ, USA TODAY research, New Constructs

column3: Bosh says he has no blood clots, still hoping to return
column5:
MIAMI (AP)  Chris Bosh says he no longer is dealing with any active blood clots, and remains hopeful that he can return to the Miami Heat at some point this season.

The 11-time All-Star made those remarks in a statement released Thursday. He did not offer a potential timetable for his return to the court.

Bosh has been sidelined since the All-Star break. He was diagnosed with a blood clot in his left leg and subsequently resumed taking bloodthinning medication, a person with knowledge of the situation told The Associated Press last month.

Bosh's statement does not mention bloodthinners, so it remains unclear if he is still taking them.

Copyright 2016 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.

column3: DeMarco Murray as I-back more often
column5:
St. Louis Cardinals SS Jhonny Peralta (thumb) underwent surgery Thursday, March 10, to repair a torn ligament in his left thumb.

Tip: He's expected to miss three or four months, and he could be affected by it all season because thumb injuries tend to wreck havoc on swings. Aledmys Diaz and Jedd Gyorko figure to at least platoon at shortstop for now. Stay tuned to this situation in camp.

column3: Daisy Ridley pens powerful message after receiving misogynist hate
column5:
You do you, girl. (Photo: Robert Deutsch, USA TODAY)

Daisy Ridley is not here for your misogyny. She's not here for body shaming or unkindness. She's just here. And the world needs to be OK with that.

The Star Wars: The Force Awakens star wrote a message to her fans via Instagram after a comment on one of her posts, which just happened to be a message of support on International Women's Day, shamed her for being too skinny. Ridley wrote a measured and thoughtful response.

Guys it was not my intention for anyone to send messages to that poor person that posted the original picture. My whole post is about being kind to each other, so please refrain! A photo posted by @daisyridley on Mar 9, 2016 at 1:13pm PST

Ridley and the character she portrays in The Force Awakens have been lightning rods for only sexism and hate since the movie debuted and her character was revealed as the film's protagonist and hero, to the chagrin of some in desolate corners of the Internet. And she's not alone, considering how much hate and harassment many women get on any given day online.

Good thing both Rey and Ridley are here to stay for a long time.

Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/1paDCo7

column3: First-generation American Carlos Balderas hopes to put U.S. Boxing back on the medal stand in Rio
column4: ['Luke Kerr-dineen', 'Charles Curtis', 'Maggie Hendricks', 'Nate Scott', 'Steven Ruiz', "Laken Litman Is An Enterprise Reporter Covering College Football Women's Soccer The Nfl", 'Nina Mandell', 'Laken Litman']

I was winning the fight, Balderas said. I hurt him on two occasions, I had him bad. But in the fourth round, he gave me a headbutt, and they had to stop the fight. I had nine stitches. I was beating him though so I feel like I have a big chance of beating him.

As soon as Balderas got involved in boxing as a kid, the trouble stopped. No more school suspensions or scoldings from his parents. The sport became his life. He chose it over beach trips or playing handball after school with his friends.

It saved me, he said. It takes up a lot of your time. You wake up early in the morning, you train, you go home, you rest, you eat, you go back to the gym. You really dont have time to be out in the streets or be out doing other stuff.

Boxing kept me away from bad friends, bad habits, parties. I didnt really have a childhood. I was always in the boxing gym. Im not complaining though because I got to the Olympic Games ... I had friends who were involved in drugs and gangs, so I had to pull myself away from that. I knew eventually I would start heading down that path if it wasnt for family and boxing.

A couple weeks ago, the Balderas family visited its roots in Mexico. Carlos had never seen the house where his grandparents lived in Oaxaca before moving to the States. He couldnt believe the size.

Seeing it in real life hit him hard.

Its a very, very small house, he said. We passed by and my grandma started tearing up. To see them like that...I feel like Im my familys greatest hope going to the Olympic Games. The first American generation made it to the Olympic Games.

I feel like I can give them a little more.

column3: ECB stimulus should be small gain for economy
column5:
Mario Draghi, president of the European Central Bank (ECB), discussed new stimulus measures for the euro zone on Thursday. (Photo: ARNE DEDERT, EPA)

The European Central Bank on Thursday trotted out more of its monetary-policy artillery in a bid to jumpstart the euro zones sluggish economy and head off persistent deflation, but the impact will likely be more akin to a pellet gun, economists say.

While its new stimulus measures will likely have some positive effects, they dont address the deeper capital problems that are preventing the regions beleaguered banks from increasing lending.

Its better than they do this than that they dont do it, says HIS Chief Economist Nariman Behravesh. It will be a small net positive.

And with financial markets largely expecting the moves, It is something they had to do to avoid a sharp stock selloff, Behravesh says.

The ECB cut its key deposit rate for banks further below zero, to -0.4% from -0.3%. That means banks must pay even more to park their money at the central bank  instead of earning interest, as they would in normal times -- theoretically spurring them to lend more.

The ECB also increased its monthly bond purchases to 80 billion from 60 billion euros through March 2017, pumping more cash into the banking system and pushing down long-term interest rates. And the central bank cut its main interest rate on loans to banks zero from 0.05%.

Those measures too are aimed at coaxing banks into opening the lending spigots and making borrowing cheaper for consumers and businesses.

We have shown today that we are not short of ammunition, Draghi told reporters.

But euro zone banks are still heavily burdened by bad loans and short of capital, legacies of the 2008 financial crisis. As a result, theyre largely lending to customers with pristine credit only. Providing them more incentives to make loans will help, but only on the margins, Behravesh says.

Yet both the increased asset purchases and negative interest rates have other benefits. They should further weaken the euro, boosting the regions exports by making them cheaper for overseas buyers. And they should further prod investors to move money to higher-yielding assets, such as stocks, lifting markets and making consumers feel wealthier.

Yet the ECB already has taken similar steps on a larger scale, and so the net effects are likely to be smaller, Behravesh says.

On the downside, negative interest rates further squeeze banks profits as they typically cant pass them to consumers or businesses. Still, the net effects of the strategies are likely to be positive.

Draghi said the euro zone economy is expected to grow just 1.4% in 2016, and inflation of just 0.1% is projected. In February, consumer prices fell for the first time since September but Draghi denied the region was now in deflation, or falling wages and prices, since it has now become a persistent trend.

Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/1pireTW

column5:
We can only imagine what a 'Big Bang' version of 'Tell Me More' would sound like. (Photo: CBS)

The Big Bang Theory cast goes together more like Einstein and gravity waves more than "rama lama lama ka dinga da dinga dong" but that didn't stop them from dressing up as Grease characters for Wednesday's A Night at Sardi's benefit in L.A.

The whole cast gathered to perform We Go Together at the Alzheimer's Association fundraiser.

Guess we should have known that Raj (Kunal Nayyar) would be the one to play Danny Zuko

We'll always be together!  #nightatsardis @normancook @therealjimparsons @missmayim @kunalkarmanayyar @sanctionedjohnnygalecki #simonhelberg Photo cred: @richardweitzla A photo posted by Melissa Rauch (@themelissarauch) on Mar 9, 2016 at 11:10pm PST

The BBT gang was honored for their 5-year-streak of song-and-dance numbers at Sardi's for the past five years, including songs from Hair and The Rocky Horror Picture Show. (And if you haven't seen Jim Parsons in full Frank N. Furter regalia, you have not truly lived.)

Check out the BBT ladies in their poodle skirts

Greased lightning with these chicks! @themelissarauch @missmayim #anightatsardis #alzheimersassociation A photo posted by @normancook on Mar 9, 2016 at 10:19pm PST

And in case you haven't picked up from Kaley Cuoco's Lip Sync Battle performance or any of her other recent red-carpet excursions, she is not passing up any opportunities to show off her post-divorce gym bod.

Check out Cuoco's costume from her solo number from A Chorus Line:

#bts #alzheimersassociation #anightatsardis right before my performance of Dance 10 Looks 3 aka (tits and ass) from A Chorus Line  nailed it! A photo posted by @normancook on Mar 9, 2016 at 11:21pm PST

column3: Fight Valley, starring Miesha Tate and Holly Holm, looks absolutely abysmal and we cant wait
column4: ['Luke Kerr-dineen', 'Charles Curtis', 'Maggie Hendricks', 'Nate Scott', 'Steven Ruiz', 'Nina Mandell', 'Laken Litman', "Nate Scott Is A Writer Editor At Ftw Leading The Site's Culture Coverage He Likes Writing About Soccer Basketball Music Tv The Evils Of The Ocean"]
column5:
Miesha Tate and Holly Holm, along with Cris Cyborg, are starring in a new movie called Fight Valley and, well, it just looks terrible. Not even terrible, though. Triumphantly terrible.

This movie is going to be an absolute nightmare of a movie, a completely putrid mess, and I couldnt be more excited about it. I will be there opening night with a large popcorn and so much Diet Coke my hands will shake.

Look at this thing:

The tagline is: One way in. No way out! It looks like it was shot by an 8th grader with a Handicam! A line from the actual script is I fight for all the wrong reasons! They didnt even have another character give that assessment! They had the character say it about herself! Also! Fight Valley is not a metaphor but apparently is an actual place!

This will be a Mona Lisa of badness. A wonderfully bad movie. So bad that it turns the corner and leans right into good. Lets all go. Lets go to Fight Valley, which again, is an actual place in this movie.

column3: How a mini skateboard makes for a fascinating sport, in one video
column4: ['Luke Kerr-dineen', 'Charles Curtis', 'Maggie Hendricks', 'Nate Scott', 'Steven Ruiz', 'Nina Mandell', 'Laken Litman']
column5:
Theres apparently a sport called fingerboarding, which is sort of what it sounds like: Using your digits to manipulate a teeny skateboard.

But before you scoff and wave it off, just look at this video of some guys turning a Lazy Susan into a mini-skatepark. You think you could pull of these tricks with ease?

Didnt think so. It also turns out fingerboarding isnt a new sport (cue The More You Know music). Im officially a fan:

column3: Bryce Harpers take on baseballs tired unwritten rules is correct but unnecessary
column4: ["Ted Berg Is Ftw's Lead Baseball Taco Bell Writer He Lives In New York City Where Darryl Strawberry Once Bought Him A Sandwich", 'Luke Kerr-dineen', 'Maggie Hendricks', 'Charles Curtis', 'Ted Berg', 'Nate Scott', 'Steven Ruiz', 'Nina Mandell', 'Laken Litman']
column5:
Young Nationals superstar Bryce Harper said some fairly interesting things about his sport in an ESPN profile. Here they are:

Bryce Harper is here to demolish baseball's unwritten rules. Bless him https://t.co/oehJ9ocBGA pic.twitter.com/cPM0woZXb1  Dan Steinberg (@dcsportsbog) March 10, 2016

Look: I agree with basically everything Harper says in the above excerpt, and Im certainly not here to blame him for saying them or blame ESPN for printing them. Harpers the biggest thing in baseball right now, so basically everything he says is noteworthy to fans of the sport, and piling on baseballs so-called unwritten rules remains an enjoyable  if obvious  pastime. Harper took a similar stance in an interview with this site nearly two full years ago.

But in listing players who flout those unwritten rules, Harper names seven of the games most prominent young stars. And plenty of others, like Anthony Rizzo, Noah Syndergaard, Jose Bautista, Yoenis Cespedes, and Josh Donaldson  to name a handful  have either tacitly or explicitly fired their own shots in baseballs ages-old but ever-overblown war on the nebulous code of conduct that some still believe govern it.

So wheres the opposition? Sure, occasionally players will complain about the way an opponent behaves, and plenty of fans will object to a bat-flip or mound celebration when it comes against their favorite team. But those appear increasingly like instances of sore losing, and as long as Major League Baseball is played by some of the worlds most competitive human beings and followed by passionate fans, there will always be that.

Failure is inevitable in baseball, but if you dont absolutely hate it with every inch of your soul, youre probably not getting to the big leagues. Of course pitchers get steamed when a guy unleashed a massive bat-flip after a tremendous homer. But far rarer is the player who objects to it when perpetrated by a teammate. By now, even the crustiest old baseball dude  provided hes at all reasonable  will admit when pressed that he might not love everything he sees on the field but recognizes it as the way preferred by many players and most fans in 2016.

And though baseball remains fueled by nostalgia in many ways, it often seems like nostalgia for an era that never really existed. I grew up in the 1980s loving Rickey Henderson, a guy who pimped basically everything he did on the baseball field. And I appreciated Ozzie Smith for how much fun he appeared to be having when he did backflips on the diamond. When exactly was this Golden Age in which every player who homered simply put his head down and jogged the bases in sullen silence, and how awful must that have been? Did Babe Ruth abide the unwritten rules? Did Ty Cobb?

Also  and, again, Ive got no problem with Harpers comments  youre Bryce Freaking Harper. Baseball has never been played at a higher level than it is played in the contemporary Major Leagues, and youre 23 years old and coming off one of the greatest offensive seasons in baseball history. You might very well be the greatest hitter who ever lived, if not relative to your era than at least in terms of actual ability (the Majors in Babe Ruths day, for example, were probably played around the same level as todays Class A ball, and imagine  imagine!  what Harper would have done against Class A competition in 2015).

Literally no one in the world is better suited to alter the way baseball is played and watched and perceived than Bryce Harper is right now. Be the change you wish to see in the world, or whatever. If you dont want baseball to seem tired, your best option is to simply continue showing everyone youre not yet tired of it. Maybe start with these simple suggestions and work from there.

And though its hard to envision the perceived backlash to baseballs arbitrary standards of decorum, this particular baseball fan  me  believes its past time we stop viewing every bat-flip and fist-pump and walk-off celebration as existing to defy the unwritten rules. Yes, therell always be a stubborn few players and fans bleating on about how opponents need to respect the game, but the truth is, theres no better way to respect the game than by daring to enjoy it.

Baseball is for fun, and it should be celebrated. Maybe someday soon we can recognize on-field demonstrations of baseballs awesomeness not as more thrusts in some ongoing tilt against boring old windmills, but only as understandable observances of how joyful and triumphant and awesome it must be to play baseball for a living and hit massive homers.

column3: Chris Bosh says he has no active blood clots, hopes to return
column5:
Bosh has played 53 games this season. (Photo: Mark J. Rebilas, USA TODAY Sports)

Miami Heat forward Chris Bosh, who has been out since the All-Star break with an undisclosed calf injury, said he doesnt have any active blood clots and he is hopeful that he can return to the surging Heat.

There was concern that Bosh, who missed the end of the 2015 season after a blood clot ultimately moved to his lungs, might have to miss the remainder of the season but he tweeted this past weekend that he was feeling great. Hes also been working out with Miamis training staff.

I know there have been many questions regarding my health and when I will play again, Bosh said in a statement. My situation this year has never been life threatening. I am feeling great and currently do not have deep vein thrombosis. Together with the Miami Heat I am working with doctors, exploring the best precautionary treatment options, and taking every necessary step to make sure Im healthy for myself, my family and my team. ... I remain positive that I will be able to return this season.

His full statement:

Full text of Bosh statement. pic.twitter.com/PhXpX2EV1T  Tim Reynolds (@ByTimReynolds) March 10, 2016

The Heat, currently the No. 4 seed, have won seven of their last 10 and are 8-3 since Bosh went down.

column3: IOC retests Beijing drug samples ahead of Rio
column5:
(Photo: The Associated Press)

LONDON (AP)  Armed with enhanced techniques, the IOC is retesting hundreds of doping samples from the 2008 Beijing Olympics to weed out drug cheats before they can compete in this year's Summer Games in Rio de Janeiro.

In an interview with The Associated Press, IOC medical director Dr. Richard Budgett said athletes who competed in Beijing and are likely to be selected for Rio are having their stored samples reanalyzed to catch any violators who evaded detection eight years ago.

"We want to protect the clean athletes who are going to be competing in Rio," Budgett said. "We are making sure that athletes who cheated back in 2008 don't get to compete in Rio in 2016."

The International Olympic Committee stores blood and urine samples from each games so they can be reanalyzed years later with improved testing methods. Any positive tests can lead to retroactive sanctions, disqualifications and loss of medals.

The statute of limitations for retesting was extended in 2015 from eight to 10 years, meaning the Beijing samples remain valid through 2018.

"Many of the athletes who are likely to be selected for Rio will have their samples retested a couple of years earlier than we need to," Budgett told AP on the sidelines of the Tackling Doping in Sport conference in London. "There are some new analyses that are available. The samples are in the process of being retested. It's in the hundreds."

"We've cooperated very closely with the international federations, finding out which athletes are still competing, finding out which athletes are likely to be selected for Rio," he added. "If we've got samples for them from Beijing, we're doing that testing."

Budgett said the process should be completed in the next few weeks.

"If we have any adverse analytical findings, there will be a sanctioning process and those athletes will be very unlikely to compete in Rio," he said.

Noting that scientific techniques will continue to improve in the next two years, the IOC is keeping the other Beijing samples for retesting closer to the 2018 deadline, Budgett said.

It's not the first time that samples from Beijing have been retested. A few months after those games, the IOC reanalyzed nearly 1,000 of the total of 4,000 samples with a new test for the blood-boosting drug CERA. Five athletes were caught, including 1,500-meter gold medalist Rashid Ramzi of Bahrain.

Budgett said some samples from the 2012 London Olympics are also being retested now on a targeted basis ahead of the Rio Games, although most are being saved for later reanalysis.

"We want to reserve samples for the expected advances that will happen over the next six years," he said.

Nearly 500 doping samples from the 2006 Winter Olympics in Turin have already been retested. The IOC has not disclosed whether those retests had produced any positive cases.

Five athletes were caught in retests of samples from the 2004 Athens Olympics, including men's shot put winner Yuriy Bilonog of Ukraine.

On a separate issue, Budgett said he is confident that Brazil's national anti-doping agency will comply with World Anti-Doping Agency rules by next week's deadline to prevent Rio's drug-testing laboratory from being ruled ineligible for the Olympics.

The Brazilian agency has until March 18 to meet WADA's guidelines. If it fails, the Rio lab would be declared non-compliant, meaning thousands of doping samples during the games would have to be sent out of Brazil for testing, posing major logistical and financial issues.

Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff is scheduled to sign a decree on March 15 that would bring the agency into compliance.

"We're very hopeful that it finally will be resolved," Budgett said. "The laboratory itself is performing well and really is state-of-the-art. We always have a Plan B. Anything can happen. That's there in case, but I do not expect to be using it."

Budgett said the IOC plans to carry out a "similar number" of tests in Rio as the 5,000 conducted in London. An intelligence unit created by WADA is targeting athletes for testing in the lead-up to the games.

"We're not talking about the numbers any more, we're talking about the quality," Budgett said.

Copyright 2016 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.
