column3: 10 templates thatll make people want to accept your LinkedIn invitations
column4: ['Courtney Rozen', 'The University Of Texas At Austin', 'The Muse', 'Varsity Tutors', 'Usa Today Network Josh Hafner Usa Today', 'Sam Lisker', 'Alexandra Samuels']
column5:
This morning, when I logged into LinkedIn, I had nine connection requests waiting for me. Some were from recruiters, some were from total strangers, some were from fellow writers, and some were from old classmatesbut they all said the exact same thing:

Id like to add you to my professional network on LinkedIn.

It baffles me that everyone isnt customizing their invitationsbut in fact, very few people do. Those 300 characters can have a big impact, though: If youre connecting with someone you know well, its a great opportunity to say something nice and reinforce the relationship. If youre connecting with someone you dont know well, its a great opportunity to remind him or her how you met. If youre connecting with someone you dont know at all, its your only opportunity to convince him or her to accept.

However, maybe your problem isnt finding motivationits finding what to say. Thats why Ive created 10 templates for LinkedIn invitations, so no matter who youre connecting with, youll have the right words. (Of course, youll need to adapt them to your own situation.)

1. A Colleague

Everyone loves feeling like their contributions have been noticed, so when connecting with co-workers, mention their projects, interests, or strengths. This is an ideal way to give your colleagues a boost and strengthen your professional relationships. It may even be just the prompt they need to endorse you or write you a glowing LinkedIn recommendation.

Hi Mariah,

Although Ive never gotten the chance to work with you directly, Ive heard rave reviews about your sales techniques and ability to work with tough clients. Hopefully one of these days I can see you in action! Til then, Ill catch you in the break room.

Best,

Emily

2. A New Colleague

Obviously, youll want to be less familiar if youre connecting with people youve just met. Say you recently landed a role with a tech company and you want to connect with your supervisor. You should still compliment her and show youre familiar with what she doesjust be a little more reserved.

Dear Colette,

Im so excited to join the product development department. The teams innovation and commitment to always finding the best testing methodologies is one of the reasons I was so drawn to work at Jones Wheeler. Looking forward to contributing.

Best,

Ryan

3. A Former Co-worker

Youd assume everyone youd ever worked with you would remember you, but if you worked at a big company, if you only had the job for a year or two, or if it was a long time ago, you might find your connection requests being denied. Theres an easy fix: Describe exactly when, where, and how you worked with someone.

Dear Mike,

It was such a pleasure working together at GX from 1999 to 2001. Your computer troubleshooting skills were the best in the officecan you imagine if we had to go back to working on those huge computers? If you have the chance, Id love to catch up and learn more about what youre doing in your new role at Microsoft.

Best,

Alisha

4. Someone You Know Casually

It may seem a little awkward to personalize a connection request to Joe, a friend of a friend who youve talked to at a couple get-togethers. The last time you saw each other, you were swigging beerswont it feel weird to slip into work-speak?

Yupso dont! Use a friendly tone, but reference Joes career to acknowledge youre not at a party, youre on LinkedIn.

Hey Joe,

Im glad Aaron introduced us. Next time we run into each other, youll have to tell me more about what you do for PfizerIve always been interested in the healthcare industry.

Cheers,

Doug

5. Someone You Met at a Networking Event

When youre trying to connect with people you only talked to for a couple minutes or hours, its important you remind them right away who you are. Give a reason for connecting as well. A good default is so you can keep tabs on their career, but you can also suggest meeting for coffee, trading tips, providing each other with new contacts, helping each other with projects, informing each other about open positions, discussing industry newsthe possibilities are endless.

Dear Mark,

It was great speaking to you at the ESRI User Conference in San Diego last month. The mapping and charting work you do for airports sounded fascinating! Id definitely like to stay up-to-date on your career.

Thank you,

Lindsey

6. Someone You Admire

Sending connection requests to total strangers is always tricky, because their first instinct is to say no. Again, its important to immediately establish who you are and why youre reaching out. Prove youre not just on a hunt to break 500 contacts by specifically referencing projects theyve worked on or achievements theyve made. (Bonus points if you find this info on an external site, not LinkedIn!)

You should also include an askthe reason youre reaching out. Maybe you want an informational interview, or a way to see what he or she is working on, or the opportunity to help him or her with a project. One exception: You should never ask for a job over LinkedIn.

Dear Erin Holt,

Im a college senior interested in working in marketing. For the last year, Ive been following your work for Bryan & Associates, and its really impressed me. I particularly loved your campaign recent campaign in The Atlanticthat multimedia component was totally unexpected and really effective. If you ever have 20 or so minutes, Id love to hear more about how you started working in the field and what skills you believe are most relevant to the profession.

Thank you so much,

Fina Beauchamp

7. Someone in the Same LinkedIn Group

Maybe youre in the Society of Professional Journalists group, and you notice one frequent poster always posts unique insights and relevant articles. Luckily, the fact youre in the same group gives him an automatic reason to accept.

Dear Ron,

Im also in the Society of Professional Journalists, and Ive really enjoyed reading your posts. The piece you shared a week or two ago about the future of data journalism was pretty thought-provoking. Id love to keep in touch and learn more about your work.

Best,

April

8. A Recruiter

In general, you should contact recruiters with which you have something in common, whether thats a mutual connection, participation in a professional organization, or membership in the same LinkedIn group. If you want to reach out but dont have anything in common, career expert Jenny Foss recommends checking out what groups a recruiter is in and joining one of them.

Dear Samantha Kennedy,

I found your profile on the Association of Professional Women page and wanted to reach out to discuss potentially working together. Im a social media strategist with six years of experience and currently seeking new opportunities. Id love to chat about whether my background might be a fit for any of your openings, and Id also be happy to connect you with other professionals in my field.

Looking forward to hearing from you,

Kendra Holloway

9. An Alumnus

Most people feel fondly about their alma mater, which means your request has a good shot of being successful. Appeal to their school spirit, and, like always, prove you spent more than 30 seconds on their LinkedIn profile before you clicked Connect.

Dear Steve,

I see that you graduated from my current university, UC Berkeleygo Bears! Im an aerospace engineering major and would be excited to hear more about your work with NASA. Ill be in your area in a few weeks for vacation; if you have any free time, Id love to meet up for coffee.

Thanks so much,

Evan Beasley

P.S. Did you watch Saturdays game against Stanford? That last quarter was so tense.

10. Someone You Want to Work With

Perhaps youre trying to get a side project off the ground, and you want to hire a graphic designer. Or maybe youre a software engineer looking to collaborate with someone whos really experienced in a particular coding language. Or maybe, like the writers that contact me, you want someone to bounce ideas off of and trade feedback with.

The key is making it explicitly clear the kind of relationship youre seeking. If theyre not interested, youll want to know right away so you can move on to the next potential partner.

Dear Sarah,

I was really impressed by the social media strategy you put together for Bella Bru Coffee Shop. Im also a small business owner, and Im interested in hiring you for a similar project. If youre interested, let me know and we can arrange a phone call to discuss timeline, rates, scope, etc.

Looking forward to possibly working with you,

Rebecca

With these templates, youll never have to wonder what to write in that invitation box again. Good luckand let me know if I missed a type of possible connection!

column3: Can anyone beat Kevin Harvick on his playground?
column4: ['Est March', 'Mike Hembree', 'A M', 'Special For Usa Today Sports']
column5:
USA TODAY Sports' Jeff Gluck previews the race in Phoenix. USA TODAY Sports

Kevin Harvick has won five of the past seven races at 1-mile Phoenix International Raceway. (Photo: Gary A. Vasquez, USA TODAY Sports)

NASCAR enjoys promoting its home tracks, generally the short tracks across the country where the stars of stock car racings major series got their starts.

For 2014 Sprint Cup champion Kevin Harvick, home always will be defined as Phoenix International Raceway, the one-mile track in the Arizona desert where the Chevrolet driver practically holds the deed.

Harvick owns a record seven Cup wins at PIR and has led a record 1,345 laps there. He has won four of the past five races and five of the past seven.

Five of Harvicks wins have been scored on the tracks relatively new surface, which was used for the first time in November 2011.

Three races into the new season, Harvick is winless, but clearly the odds lean in his favor in Sundays Good Sam 500. Despite being locked out of victory lane, his 2016 worksheet is strong  fourth at Daytona International Speedway, sixth at Atlanta Motor Speedway and seventh at Vegas.

Beyond the expected pursuit of Harvick, teams will be facing a new game at PIR as NASCARs lower downforce aero package is tested for the first time on a relatively flat track.

Denny Hamlin won the season-opening Daytona 500, where restrictor plates control speeds. Jimmie Johnson won at Atlanta and Brad Keselowski at Las Vegas in the first two seasonal tests of the package. Atlanta and Las Vegas are 1.5-mile high-banked tracks, while Phoenix has little banking and demands a different approach.

NASCAR developed the new aero package in an attempt to spice competition, an effort that produced fruit at Atlanta and Las Vegas, although most drivers say there is much more room for improvement.

Keselowski and his teammate, Joey Logano (who finished second at Vegas), showed strength over the closing laps of that race, indicating Team Penske might have pushed to the forefront in dealing with the new rules package. More Penske success on the different landscape at PIR would solidify that thinking.

Kyle Busch faded late at Vegas but is considered among the favorites at Phoenix. The defending series champion (and current points leader) has one win and four top-fives at PIR.

Busch is winless this year but has had a good seasonal start with two thirds and a fourth.

Keep top-fiving it, and the wins will come, he said.

Justin Bieber's world tour began last night in Seattle and the images and tweets are rolling in like tantalizing mini-trailers.

He sings Love Yourself seated on a couch.

Justin Bieber ft. Beliebers pic.twitter.com/UpknckjJOj  Crowd Goals (@crowdgoals) March 10, 2016

All while wearing his Calvins. When he's actually wearing clothes, that is. The brand is an exclusive partner for the tour in a continuation of the recent ad campaigns.

#mycalvins campaign features a shirtless Bieber, because obvi. (Photo: Tobin Yelland)

Many of the glimpses we've caught of outfits have a grunge vibe that worked well with a kickoff in the birthplace of Nirvana.

Add the pony-tail and tattoos, and it's all really working for us. Particularly the fitted but relaxed jeans, which scream independent artist rather than the super-tight skinnies of a boyband.

The Seattle Times may be right in it's review that this tour is a reinforcement of the 22-year-old's newfound maturity.

column3: 15 years after 2000 top, Nasdaq sets new record high
column5:
The Nasdaq composite is finally back to where it was 15 long years ago at the tippy-tippy top of the dot-com stock bubble. The tech- and biotech-fueled stock index closed at a new record high Thursday, finally wiping out all of the nearly 80% loss it suffered after the tech-stock crash in 2000.

The old closing record of 5048.62 dating back to the dot-com era and March 10, 2000, was eclipsed Thursday. The Nasdaq, the onetime posterboy for stock market excess, climbed 20.89 points, or 0.4%, to a new all-time closing high of 5056.06.

After crashing during the 2000-02 bear market, few folks on Wall Street thought the Nasdaq, which arguably was the biggest stock market bubble in history, would ever hit a new high in their lifetime.

No, I didnt think Id see it, but then again, I didnt think Id see the Berlin Wall come down so peacefully, says Quincy Krosby, a market strategist at Prudential Financial. I didnt think Id see Nasdaq climb this high in just 15 years , but then again I never thought Id see the Feds balance sheet reach $4.5 trillion, either.

52,000% GAIN: The stocks rocking the Nasdaq

The Nasdaq, like the rest of the U.S. stock market, of course, has enjoyed the tailwind of cheap money and massive stimulus from the U.S. Federal Reserve since the financial crisis in 2009.

The new Nasdaq record high equates to a complete recovery and demonstrates the U.S. markets resilience despite headwinds ranging from financial crises to wars. It is also likely to restart the debate over whether another stock bubble is brewing.

It is also a sign that investors are willing to take risks despite all the headwinds, such as the threat of coming interest rate hikes, above-average valuations, slowing earnings growth, and the negative fallout on earnings and sales due to the super-strong U.S. dollar, says Michael Farr, president of money management firm Farr Miller & Washington.

Its clearly a sign of a risk-on mentality, in my opinion, says Farr, who says investors have been emboldened by Fed support in recent years.

Just as it did back in its heyday at the start of the century, the Nasdaq in 2015 is again leading the U.S. stock market higher, driven again by innovative new companies that are changing the world and have growth potential that investors salivate over. For the year, the Nasdaq is up 6.8%, better than the other major U.S. indexes such as the Dow Jones industrial average and Standard & Poors 500.

The Nasdaq  which became a pop-culture sensation back in the go-go 1990s when tech stocks ranging from software giant Microsoft to an army of unknown Internet stocks with no earnings but big promises and dreams climbed higher in price than anyone thought possible  has finally rewritten the Wall Street record books.

And while the Nasdaq is back to levels last seen 15 years ago, this is in not your fathers Nasdaq.

This is not your fathers 1999 market, says Krosby.

Whats different? Back then everybody from Wall Street pros to taxi drivers turned day traders thought stock prices only went up. Today, thats no longer the case.

Today, your father doesnt trust the market and thats actually helped the market climb higher, Krosby says.

Todays Nasdaq is not all about tech, either. Biotech stocks are hot, as are the new darlings of the Internet, the so-called social media stocks.

Indeed, the Nasdaq, which was once known for its tech stocks like Microsoft and IBM, is now but home to some of the hottest and best-performing health care and biotech stocks on Wall Street. Todays Nasdaq, which regained the 5000 level for the first time in 15 years in March, gets the bulk of its performance from the innovative biotech sector, as well as new tech titans like Facebook, Twitter and Google.

Heading into todays historic trading session, the Nasdaq composite was being paced this year by digital marketing and advertising company Voltari (up 2,194%, according to FactSet) and health care names like Capnia (+367%), Eagle Pharmaceuticals (up 291%), Recro Pharma (up 275%) and Nymox Pharmaceutical (up 230%).

The index is now within striking distance of its intraday high of 5132.62, also from March 10, 2000.

The first chart below shows the rise and fall  and then rise again of the Nasdaq over the past 15 years. The second chart shows when the Nasdaq hit each of its 1,000-point milestones. Youll notice that the Nasdaq first closed above 5000 on March 9, 2000.

column3: 13 tips for throwing a St. Patricks Day party on a budget
column4: ['Courtney Rozen', 'The University Of Texas At Austin', 'Varsity Tutors', 'Usa Today Network Josh Hafner Usa Today', 'Sam Lisker', 'Alexandra Samuels']
column5:
St. Patricks Day parties and decorations make up a billion-dollar industry, but you dont have to overspend to celebrate. Save some green with these tips for throwing a St. Paddys Day bash on a budget.

Skip the invitations

Unlike a wedding where its etiquette to mail invitations, you can make your own rules with a St. Patricks Day party. Forgo the invites and send a text or email invite instead.

Stay home

Host your March 17 party at your own place, rather than going to someone elses house or going out. As long as you have enough room in your digs to entertain your friends, youll save money by skipping the cost of gas, high-priced alcohol and cover charges.

Dress the part

As much as you dont want to get pinched on St. Patricks Day, you dont want to spend a fortune on your festive attire, either. As you plan your wardrobe for your shamrock shindig, pull out something green from your closet instead of buying anything new.

BYOB

Ask your partygoers to bring their own booze and other beverages. Alcohol can be one of the most costly purchases of any party, so have your attendees chip in and save you some dough.

Shop for budget supplies

Youll likely want to set the stage with green and gold balloons, streamers and a few party favors. But dont go all out on decorations. Shop on a budget at stores such as Dollar Tree or Party City. Youll be using these supplies for only one day, so dont overspend on them. For example, you can grab a Shamrock beaded necklace for 99 cents from Wal-Mart.

Make your own eats

Instead of ordering takeout or opting for catering, make your own meal for the party. Try a traditional Irish recipe. Use this as an opportunity to test out festive baking ideas from Pinterest. Green food coloring likely required.

Seek out retail sales

Last year, retailers threw their own celebrations with deals and discounts inspired by the March holiday. This year, Amazon has already kicked off its Luck O the Irish-inspired price cuts. Look for bargains at department stores and party supply retailers too.

Use coupons

In the absence of flashy green retail sales, be on the lookout for coupons. Use apps from RetailMeNot, The Coupons App and Coupons.com so youll never miss an opportunity to take some dollars and cents off your total.

Search for freebies

When you can, get party essentials for free. Borrow from friends, reuse things around the house or find supplies online. About Home compiled a collection of cyber St. Patricks Day freebies, including printable greeting cards, decorations and computer wallpapers and clip art.

Provide your own entertainment

You dont have to purchase a single game or activity for your St. Patricks Day party. Instead, keep the fun going with what you already have. For example, listen to some Irish tunes like this St. Patricks Day inspired streaming-music list.

Move it to the weekend

This year, March 17 falls on a Thursday. Save money by throwing your St. Patricks Day party on the following Friday or Saturday instead. That way, you can purchase discounted party supplies, as retailers traditionally cut prices after the holiday is over.

Set a realistic budget

Before you officially begin party planning, set a realistic amount of money that youre willing to (and able to) spend. Then hold yourself accountable with an app like Mint, a free money manager that tracks your spending. Dont go into the red when you celebrate the holiday of green.

Treat your credit like debit

If you use your credit card to purchase supplies, use it wisely. Making purchases with a credit card (as opposed to a debit card) can protect you if your financial information is compromised and can even earn you cash back depending on your card. But dont charge more than you can pay off. View your credit card as a debit card and make purchases only that you have money in the bank to pay for.

Follow these tips to throw a festive party without emptying your pot of gold to pay for it.

More from NerdWallet:

is a USA TODAY content partner providing general news, commentary and coverage from around the Web. Its content is produced independently of USA TODAY . Courtney Jespersen writes for NerdWallet, a website that helps consumers make smarter financial decisions. NerdWallet

column3: Boeheim suspension puts Syracuse in unusual bubble situation
column5:
(Photo: The Associated Press)

WASHINGTON (AP)  Jim Boeheim had no comment about Syracuse's unusual NCAA Tournament uncertainty. Then he had plenty of comments.

Boeheim couldn't tell the selection committee what to think after Syracuse lost to Pittsburgh in its ACC Tournament opener to fall to 19-13. He was suspended for nine games, including three in conference play, so no one's sure how that stretch will be judged.

"I'm not on the committee," Boeheim said Wednesday. "Every coach in the country that's got any kind of record thinks they should get in the tournament. What do you want me to say? They're going to have to evaluate what we've done based on all the circumstances and make a decision."

Syracuse went 4-2 out of conference and 0-3 in the ACC without Boeheim, when Mike Hopkins was in charge. The Orange went 15-8 with Boeheim on the bench, including victories against Duke and Notre Dame.

Boeheim, who has led Syracuse to the NCAA Tournament 31 times, boasted that his team had beaten four teams in the top 35 in the country and eight in the top 100. He said, "if there's teams better than that, so be it."

Better is subjective, but the ACC has five NCAA tournament locks in North Carolina, Virginia, Miami, Duke and Notre Dame and another solid bet in Pitt. Syracuse didn't help itself by falling behind by 14 against the Panthers and falling short of what would've been its 20th win.

"It's a tough spot, a really tough spot," graduate student guard Trevor Cooney said. "We have some good wins and some quality wins and we're a good team and we've proved that throughout this year, so we'll see moving forward."

Syracuse isn't the only team on the bubble in the coming days, but Boeheim's suspension makes its case among the most unusual. Boeheim used his time at the microphone Wednesday pleading his case for why his players should not be punished more for past transgressions of the program.

"I think we've had our punishment," Boeheim said. "The players on this team didn't do anything wrong, were not involved in anything. They should be evaluated on how well they played when they played their best. That's the only thing that I think should happen. We should be evaluated on what kind of team we are."

Selection committee chairman Joe Castiglione has said Boeheim's absence should make a difference. Boeheim has no idea how that'll play out in the final deliberations.

"I think everybody has their own opinions," Boeheim said. "How much is that important? I don't know. How much is that taken into consideration? I don't know."

His players understand they could've eased the situation by beating Pitt. A one-point loss, the Orange's third to the Panthers this season, set them up for a few sleepless nights.

"I think our seniors deserve it and hopefully we'll be going," freshman guard Frank Howard said. "Just have to wish for the best at this point."

___

This story has been corrected to show that Boeheim says his players should not be punished further, instead of should be punished further.

column3: Georgia offers nine football players from same school on same day
column4: ['Cam Smith', 'Smith Iii', 'Special To Usa Today High School Sports', 'Detroit Free Press', 'Jim Halley', 'Wtsmith Greenvillenews Com', 'Mick Mccabe', 'Usa Today High School Sports', 'Joel Beck', 'Willie T']
column5:
Perhaps following the lead of Tennessee, the Georgia football program offered scholarships to nine players on the same day at St. Thomas Aquinas (Fort Lauderdale), according to Rivals.com.

Tennessee recently offered 20 players in the same day at IMG Academy in Bradenton, Fla.

Aquinas is expected to be one of the top schools in the nation when the Super 25 preseason rankings come out in August.

The offers went to players in the 2017, 18 and 19 classes and included four second-generation athletes who all play deefnse  the sons of former NFL players Cornelius Bennett, Asante Samuel, Al Blades and Benjamin Sapp.

Blades has already re-committed to Miami after initially de-committing.

RELATED: Al Blades Jr. video diary

According to Rivals.com, defensive end LaShawn Paulino and defensive tackle Kivon Bennett were offered from the Class of 2017; defensive backs Asante Samuel Jr., Benjamind Sapp III and Al Blades Jr., defensive end Nikolas Bonitto, wide receiver Elijah Moore were offered from 2018; and inside linebacker Anthony Solomon and running back Daniel Carter from the Class of 2019.

Bennett, whos father was a College Football Hall of Famer at Alabama, also received an offer from Arkansas on Wednesday.

Whether any of these players  all of whom have a long way until their respective signing days  lands with Georgia remains to be seen. But the tactic of mass offers at top schools could be a new strategy that other schools emulate.

column3: Jennifer Aniston talks married life with 'funniest person' Justin Theroux
column5:
Jen adding bird wrangler to her resume. (Photo: Camilla Akrans, Harper's BAZAAR)

One of our favorite Friends, Jennifer Aniston, is the April cover girl for Harper's BAZAAR. In the issue on newsstands March 22, the funny lady, for whom time does not exist, opened up about newlywed life, her list of film credits that she's not entirely proud of, and why she's been pretty MIA when it comes to social media.

Jen confessed that married life with Justin Theroux is "normal" and "not much different" since the couple pulled off a surprise wedding last August. And, that she absolutely loves that her hubby can make her LOL. "I'm lucky because Justin is the funniest person I've met," she said. "Laughter is one of the great keys to staying youthful."

If laughing can make us look as good as J.A. we're dropping everything we're doing to watch cat videos right meow!

But going back to Jen, she said she really has to "love something" now if she's going to leave her home, fur babies, and that hot husband behind. She also admitted that being a people pleaser led her to make some films that she wouldn't necessarily give two thumbs up.

"Some of the movies I've made, I bow my head in slight shame over."

Well, Jen, let's just let the past stay in the past then.

Is she walking on smartwater? (Photo: Camilla Akrans, Harper's BAZAAR)

In the article, the Mother's Day actress mentioned that Pretty Woman Julia Roberts and Emma Stone are on her list of people she wants to work with, but don't expect her to make a plea to those actresses over social media, a la 'Ye asking Mark Zuckerberg to invest. Even though Jen looks pretty friendly with that fowl at the top of our post, she's not down with the Twitter blue bird or any other social media for that matter.

"We work so hard to maintain some sort of life and privacy," she said. "Why would we intentionally put ourselves out there?"

Looks like if you want to see Jen on social, you'll have to follow Mr. Theroux or her BFF and hair stylist, Chris McMillan.

column3: Cardinals Peralta undergoes surgery for thumb injury
column5:
(Photo: The Associated Press)

PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. (AP)  St. Louis Cardinals shortstop Jhonny Peralta has undergone surgery for a left thumb injury and likely will be sidelined for about 10-to-12 weeks.

Manager Mike Matheny anticipates Peralta will return to the team's spring training site in Jupiter, Florida, in a few days. The surgery took place in St. Louis after Peralta got a second opinion.

Matheny said he hasn't heard an exact date for Peralta's return to action and will have a better idea when the Cardinals consult with the surgeon.

Offseason acquisition Jedd Gyorko is likely to get the first chance to fill in at shortstop. The Cardinals also have utilityman Greg Garcia and prospect Aledmys Diaz in camp.

column3: Video: Trump protester sucker-punched at rally in North Carolina
column5:
A protester was being led out of a Donald Trump event Wednesday night when a man attending the rally sucker-punched the protester in the face, videos show.

The incident, captured from multiple angles, involved security leading the protester, a black man, out of Trump's Fayetville, N.C. event when an apparently white man sporting a ponytail walks over and quickly punches the protester in the face as at least one member of security watched, recordings show.

The Washington Post interviewed the the protester, Rakeem Jones, who said the punch blindsided him.

After I get it, before I could even gain my thoughts, Im on the ground getting escorted out," Jones said, adding, "I was basically in police custody and got hit.

Shortly after the punch, men in uniforms that read "Sherrif's Office" detained Rakeem on the ground. It's not clear whether the man who assaulted him was detained.

Jones attend the rally with friends including a Muslim, a gay man and a white woman, he told The Post. He said "no one in our group attempted to get physical," but said the woman with him began shouting after Trump's speech began.

The protesters shouted back.

Ronnie Rouse, who was at the event with Jones, told The Post the audience members shouted "Go home n-----s" and "You need to get the f--- out of there!"

Both the Sheriff's Office of Cumberland County, where Fayetteville is located, and the city's police denied detaining Jones, who was not arrested.

The altercation marks the latest violent incident between Trump supporters and protesters at the candidate's events.

Earlier this month, video captured several white men shoving and yelling at a young black woman who protested a Trump event in Kentucky.

One of the men involved was identified as a white nationalist named Matthew Heimbach. Another, a young recruit slated to join the Marines, was later discharged by the Marine Corps for taking part in what it called a "racially charged" event.

Shaun King, an activist who helped identify the young Marine recruit, is now seeking to identify the ponytailed man who punched Jones.

Help me identify the racist Trump supporter who repeatedly punched this protestor in the face last night.



CRIMINAL!https://t.co/lNrUME2jCo  Shaun King (@ShaunKing) March 10, 2016

As The Post notes,Trump has not always discouraged violence against protesters at his events.

At a November event, attendees punched and kicked a Black Lives Matter activist.

"Maybe he should have been roughed up," Trump said.

[h/t The Post]

Follow Josh Hafner on Twitter: @joshhafner

column3: Senate passes bipartisan bill to combat painkiller abuse, heroin addiction
column5:
Overdose deaths from opioids, including heroin and prescription painkillers, have more than tripled since 2000. (Photo: AP)

WASHINGTON  The Senate passed a bipartisan bill Thursday to help states and local governments fight Americans' growing addiction to heroin and prescription painkillers  an epidemic that has caused drug overdose to become the nation's leading cause of accidental death.

Senators voted 94-1 to approve the Comprehensive Addiction and Recovery Act, which was sponsored by Sens. Sheldon Whitehouse, D-R.I., and Rob Portman, R-Ohio. The bill authorizes the attorney general to provide grants to states, local governments and non-profit groups for programs to strengthen prescription drug monitoring, improve treatment for addicts, and expand prevention, education and law enforcement initiatives.

The bill still must be approved by the House, where it has been introduced by Rep. Jim Sensenbrenner, R-Wis.

The Senate vote came after Democrats complained that the bill does not include any money to carry out the programs.

The legislation authorizes $725 million for federal grants but does not allocate any actual funds, which would have to be approved as part of legislation to fund federal agencies for the 2017 fiscal year. Senate Republicans last week blocked an effort by Sen. Jeanne Shaheen, D-N.H., to add $600 million in emergency money to the bill.

"Let's not pretend that there is new money for this," Whitehouse said. "The sooner we can get this funded, the sooner we can save lives."

GOP leaders said that Congress already appropriated more than $400 million in funds that are available now for programs to combat opioid abuse as part of a huge spending bill passed in December.

"This authorization bill, in conjunction with the $400 million appropriated for opioid-specific programs just a few months ago, can make important strides in combating the growing addiction and overdose problem weve seen in all 50 states," said Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky.

President Obama is asking Congress for an extra $1.1 billion in his 2017 budget request to pay for drug treatment for people addicted to prescription painkillers and heroin.

Each day, 44 people die in the U.S. from an overdose of prescription painkillers, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Drug overdose is now the the leading cause of accidental death in the United States, surpassing car crashes, according to the American Society of Addiction Medicine. Opioid abuse is the main problem, with nearly 19,000 overdose deaths related to prescription pain relievers and nearly 10,600 overdose deaths related to heroin in 2014. The rate of heroin overdose deaths nearly quadrupled from 2000 to 2013 as many prescription drug abusers turned to the illegal drug as a cheaper alternative that is easier to get, the society said.

The most common drugs involved in prescription overdose deaths include hydrocodone, oxycodone, oxymorphone, and methadone, according to the CDC. People who take prescription painkillers can become addicted with just one prescription. Nearly 7,000 people are treated in hospital emergency rooms every day for abusing painkillers, the CDC said.

The legislation passed by the Senate authorizes the expansion of prescription drug monitoring programs, which are state-run databases that track the prescribing and dispensing of controlled prescription drugs to patients. The databases can track whether patients are filling multiple prescriptions for painkillers from more than one doctor.

Federal grant money could be used to help develop drug treatment programs as alternatives to putting opioid addicts in jail. Grants also could pay for special programs to help military veterans overcome their addiction to painkillers.

The bill directs the Department of Health and Human Services to convene an inter-agency task force to develop best practices for prescribing pain medication to try to reduce over-dependence on opioids.

Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/1piwEOB

column3: Chrysler underprices rivals with new breakthrough minivan
column5:
Fiat Chrysler has completly revised the minivan, with the Pacifica (Photo: AP)

DETROIT -- Fiat Chrysler Automobiles said Thursday that the pricing of its all-new 2017 Chrysler Pacifica minivan will start at $29,590 for the entry-level model and start at $43,490 for the top-of-the-line model when delivery and destination charges are included.

At those prices, the new Pacifica is competitive with its two primary rivals -- the Honda Odyssey and Toyota Sienna -- while also offering an all-new look aimed at attracting new buyers as well as new features inside.

The Auburn Hills automaker, which is credited for inventing the minivan segment, will offer five different trim levels of the new minivan when it goes on sale this spring. The pricing released today doesn't include the cost of the Pacifica Hybrid, which is scheduled to go on sale later this year.

FCA's pricing announcement for the Pacifica has been highly anticipated in the automotive for several reasons. First, the Pacifica will eventually replace two minivans -- the Dodge Grand Caravan and the Chrysler Town & Country. That means FCA eventually hopes Pacifica's sales volume will equal or exceed the combined sales of those two models.

Currently, the Dodge Grand Caravan starts at $22,095 and tops out at $30,995 while the Chrysler Town & Country starts at $29,995 and tops out at $40,645. FCA plans to continue making the Grand Caravan, a popular fleet vehicle, for another year or two.

column3: Dale Earnhardt Jr. becomes treehouse master
column5:
USA TODAY Sports' Jeff Gluck previews the race in Phoenix. USA TODAY Sports

Dale Earnhardt Jr. will be featured on 'Treehouse Masters' on Friday night. (Photo: Jasen Vinlove, USA TODAY Sports)

Dale Earnhardt Jr. has a Western town, a wrecked car graveyard and a vintage gas station on his North Carolina property.

But his latest addition -- a treehouse completed last year -- might be his pride and joy.

Actually, just calling it a treehouse vastly undersells the impressive structure. The elevated clubhouse/getaway was made using a blueprint from Treehouse Masters host Pete Nelson and is worthy of being featured on the show.

On Friday, it will be. Earnhardt will appear with Nelson on the Animal Planet broadcast at 10 p.m. ET, and an exclusive sneak peak at the episode can be seen in this video:

"Building the treehouse is something I wanted to do for a long time," Earnhardt said in a statement. "After seeing the Treehouse Masters show and doing some research on the plans that Pete sells, it's something we decided to do.

"I was able to use a local contractor who usually builds boat docks on Lake Norman to do the work. I'm really proud of the finished product and it was great to have the opportunity to show Pete what we'd built and let him offer some advice on what we can improve."

Nelson said in a statement he was "thrilled" to have inspired Earnhardt on the treehouse project.

"I even learned a thing or two. I give him an A+," Nelson said.

Gluck on Twitter @jeff_gluck

PHOTOS: Behind the wheel with Dale Earnhardt Jr.

column3: Rhino poaching crisis increasing in Africa
column5:
A black rhino male and calf in Mkuze, South Africa. (Photo: Karl Stromayer, AP)

Rhinos killed by poachers in Africa continued to rise for the sixth year in a row.

At least 1,338 rhinos were killed by poachers across Africa in 2015, according to 2015 data by the International Union for Conservation of Nature. Since 2008, at nearly 6,000 African rhinos have been killed by poachers.

The extensive poaching for the illegal trade in horn continues to undermine the rhino conservation successes made in Africa over the last two decades, said Mike Knight, chair of the commission's African Rhino Specialist Group.

The number of white rhino appear to have leveled off in Africa, with 2015 numbers showing an estimated 19,700 to 21,000, the IUCN reported. The black rhino is listed by the IUCN as critically endangered with about 5,000 left of their kind.

"Recent success in black rhino conservation is heartening, but a lot of work remains to bring the population up to even a fraction of what it once was and ensure that it stays there," according to the World Wildlife Fund's website.

South Africa currently conserves 79% of Africas rhinos and has endured about 85% of poaching on the continent since 2008, according to IUCN.

The rhino horn, retailing for $60,000 a pound, is considered to be more valuable by weight than gold, diamonds or cocaine, William Ripple, an Oregon State University professor of ecology told the Washington Times.

Demand is particularly high in markets in South East Asia for medicinal products, according to the World Wildlife Fund.

column3: GOP is betraying constitution on Supreme Court nomination fight, Obama says
column5:
President Obama and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau hold a joint press conference in the Rose Garden of the White House Thursday. (Photo: Chip Somodevilla, Getty Images)

WASHINGTON  President Obama accused Senate Republicans of betraying their own constitutional principles Thursday, saying that their plan to stonewall his Supreme Court nominee because it's an election year is "nowhere to be found" in the nation's founding charter.

He repeated his vow to make a nomination despite Senate opposition, and said the Senate was making up new rules that have never existed before.

"That's the kind of approach that they have vehemently rejected and accused liberals of engaging in all the time," he said in a press conference in the White House Rose Garden with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau. He charged that Republicans "can't abandon principles  if these are their principles  simply for political expediency."

Obama did not give any hints of where he is in the process of vetting a candidate to replace the conservative stalwart Justice Antonin Scalia, who died last month. But said he hoped to nominate someone quickly so the court can return to its full complement of nine justices. He suggested that the opposition from Republicans was not constraining the pool of candidates willing to be vetted and nominated.

Obama reiterated the qualities he's looking for in a nominee: Someone who "follows the Constitution, cares about things like stare decicis and precedent, understands the necessary humility of a judge at any level, at looking at statute, and at what the elected branches are doing."

He said he's also looking at someone who will protect the rights of minority groups and uphold the Bill of Rights.

And he said while he doesn't want the courts to become an extension of partisan politics, he also noted that justices read the newspaper and "courts can't be hermetically sealed from the rest of society."

column3: TV comedies get real about addiction, recovery
column5:
Chip (Will Arnett) is a recovering alcoholic in Netflix's 'Flaked.' (Photo: Matt Kennedy/Netflix)

Will Arnett's new show starts not at a frozen banana stand, but an Alcoholics Anonymous meeting.

In the opening moments of Flaked, Arnett, playing a fortysomething slacker named Chip, says that he is a recovering alcoholic who killed a man while drunk-driving a decade earlier. It's not exactly terrain that's ripe for laughs, but territory comedies such as HBO's Girls, Netflix's Loved and CBS' Mom have been willing to explore with addiction storylines.

Co-created by Arnett and Mark Chappell, Flaked premieres on Netflix Friday and follows Chip and his friends whose harbored secrets threaten to unravel their easygoing lives in Venice, Calif. Although the Arrested Development star is quick to note that the slice-of-life show is not solely about AA, he says that it draws loosely upon his own earlier battles with alcoholism.

"When I see people saying, 'Other shows have tackled (the subject) better,' I say, 'You can't say that it's not accurate, because it's my experience,' " Arnett says. "I'm shedding a little light on my relationship with my own sobriety, which at times has been tricky at best."

Lesley Arfin similarly infused some of her own past into Love, which she co-wrote with her husband Paul Rust. The first season tracks the will-they-or-won't-they courtship of aspiring writer Gus (Rust) and radio producer Mickey (Gillian Jacobs), portrayed as a functioning adult who can hold down a job and maintain a steady social life. But unbeknownst to Gus, she also has an AA sponsor and goes to meetings for alcohol addiction  tallying her days sober with an app on her phone and occasionally relapsing with a drug-addled night out.

Creating Love, "I wasn't trying to think, 'How can every single person relate to this one character?' " Arfin says. "As far as Mickey's concerned, she's new to recovery, so it's not going to be her whole personality or overtake anything."

Gus (Paul Rust) and Mickey (Gillian Jacobs) make a brutally honest, dysfunctional pair in Netflix's 'Love' (Photo: Suzanne Hanover/Netflix)

One of the biggest writing challenges was to entertain without being glib or disrespectful of recovering addicts' struggles. The solution, Rust says, was to "just let the person who was dealing with it be the one who has the sense of humor about it."

Mom creator Chuck Lorre agrees that finding that balance can be "difficult, but it's worth trying." The sitcom, about a mother (Allison Janney) and daughter (Anna Faris) in recovery together, has tackled weighty topics of relapsing, illness and death in its three seasons  most recently, an episode last month that ended with the fatal overdose of a teen addict (Emily Osment).

"The reality of somebody becoming sober and going back to getting loaded, and the jeopardy that they're in, was something we wanted to deal with," Lorre says. "Obviously the conversation is, 'How do the other people carry on? How do you make sense of that afterwards?' The tragedy of that lingers. ... I'm hoping that the audience will allow us to take those moments and let them play without any comic overlay."

That viewers are seemingly more receptive to these issues can only be a good thing, Arfin believes.

"Anything that advances the conversation of, 'Oh, I'm on medication. It doesn't mean I belong in a nuthouse,' " she says. "Real people have these kinds of embarrassing problems that don't have to be so embarrassing. Maybe if we write about it on TV, then we can make it more accessible to others."

Christy (Anna Faris, left) listens to her mother, Bonnie (Allison Janney) share during an AA meeting on CBS' 'Mom.' (Photo: Sonja Flemming/CBS)

CINCINNATI (AP)  The Bengals have signed starting safety George Iloka and offensive tackle Eric Winston while working on a deal with cornerback Adam "Pacman" Jones.

Iloka and Winston were among the team's 13 unrestricted free agents. The defensive secondary was particularly vulnerable, with Iloa, Jones, cornerback Leon Hall and starting safety Reggie Nelson entering free agency.

Iloka started every game in 2013-14 and a dozen last season, when he was hurt. He got a five-year deal. Winston, the head of the players' union, appeared in 13 games last season and started two at right tackle when Andre Smith was hurt. He got a one-year deal.

Jones posted on social media that he would get a three-year deal to stay.

column3: Falcons re-sign DE Adrian Clayborn, add DE Derrick Shelby
column5:
FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga. (AP)  The Atlanta Falcons have re-signed defensive end Adrian Clayborn to a two-year contract and have added former Miami end Derrick Shelby with a four-year deal.

A day after making former Cleveland center Alex Mack the NFL's highest-paid player at his position, the Falcons turned their attention Thursday to shoring up a pass rush that's ranked no higher than 28th in sacks since 2012.

Their 19 sacks last season were fewest in the league.

Clayborn, a five-year veteran, led Atlanta with 15 quarterback hits and was second with three sacks in 16 games. The former first-round pick of Tampa Bay signed a one-year contract with the Falcons last spring.

Shelby, a four-year veteran who's missed just one game in his career, had 3.5 sacks last season.

The Falcons released defensive tackle Paul Soliai, a two-year starter, on Wednesday.

column3: Study: States that raised minimum wage had stronger job growth
column5:
A recent study by the Center for Economic and Policy Research attempts to undercut the argument that raising the minimum wage kills jobs.

The study, which updates a Goldman Sachs analysis to include data from April and May, shows that the 13 states that increased their minimum wages on Jan. 1 have had stronger employment growth than the 37 states that didnt. The study compared average employment during the first five months of 2014 with the last five months of 2013.

The average change in payrolls in the 13 states that increased their minimum wages was 0.99% vs. 0.68% in the other states. On January 1, Connecticut, New Jersey, New York and Rhode Island boosted their pay floors as a result of legislation. The other nine states  Arizona, Colorado, Florida, Missouri, Montana, Ohio, Oregon, Vermont and Washington  automatically raised their minimums by smaller amounts based on inflation.

CEPR acknowledges this analysis is far from scientific and draws no direct link between raising the minimum wage and payroll gains. Still, it does provide evidence against theoretical negative employment effects of minimum wage increases, CEPR researcher Ben Wolcott writes.

Critics of minimum wage increases argue they raise business costs, forcing employers to lay off workers or hire fewer people.

But CEPR senior economist John Schmitt says one reason minimum pay hikes actually could bolster employment growth is that they help businesses fill openings more quickly. Big employers of low-wage workers, such as fast food chains, virtually always have job vacancies, he says.

Another reason, he says, is that low-wage workers tend to spend nearly all their extra cash, lifting the local economy and creating more jobs.

column3: Chiefs announce signings of Howard, Hali in free agency
column5:
KANSAS CITY, Mo. (AP)  The Kansas City Chiefs have begun to announce their wave of free-agent signings, starting with veteran linebacker Tamba Hali and defensive tackle Jaye Howard.

Hali agreed to a three-year deal to remain with Kansas City on Tuesday, while Howard reached a two-year deal to stay with the Chiefs on Wednesday. Both were valuable pieces to a defense that last season led the Chiefs to their first playoff victory in more than two decades.

Kansas City also agreed to a three-year deal with veteran linebacker Derrick Johnson, a five-year contract with former Browns offensive tackle Mitchell Schwartz and contracts with backup linebackers Frank Zombo and Jonathan Massaquoi during the first day of free agency.

Those contracts are expected to be announced once they are signed.

column3: New study finds Uber, Lyft don't threaten new car sales
column5:
A driver waits to pick up passengers at an Uber and Lyft pick up area at the Bellagio hotel and casino in Las Vegas. (Photo: John Locher, AP)

A new study, the second study in the last three weeks, predicts that ride- and car-sharing won't hurt new car sales, despite their growing popularity.

Kelley Blue Book commissioned the study that was conducted by Vital Findings to understand why people use ride-sharing and car-sharing, as well as opinions and behaviors surrounding current and future transportation.

One of the findings is that these alternatives are used mainly as substitutes for taxis and traditional rental car companies, and have very limited impact on current or future vehicle ownership. Of those consumers surveyed, 74% said driving themselves is their preferred mode of transportation in the next six months.

Ride- and car-sharing services are getting a lot of attention these days, and we wanted to better understand the current landscape of these app-fueled platforms, said Karl Brauer, senior analyst for Kelley Blue Book. While there are numerous benefits to ride sharing and car sharing, our data reveals that owning a car still reigns supreme, with reliability, safety and convenience all being major factors.

Last month, the Boston Consulting Group estimates that by 2021, about 35 million people will share access to about 246,000 vehicles. But only about 6 million of those people will be in North America, compared with 14 million in Europe and 15 million in Asia-Pacific.

Today about 5.8 million people worldwide pay for the ability to rent 86,000 vehicles owned by companies like Zipcar, Daimler's Car2Go, BMW's Drive Now or peer-to-peer services such as Turo that allow owners to rent out their vehicles to others.

The Kelley Blue Book study looked closely at attitudes about Uber and Lyft, which use a smartphone app that enables consumers to request and pay for a ride on demand from drivers who typically own the cars they drive.

column3: $125 or $185? What Apple stock is worth
column5:
Apple just delivered nothing short of a profit party last night  topping just about every financial metric possible. But the stock isnt doing anything. How can that be?

Shares of the electronic gadget maker are flat at $132.93 Tuesday  a shocking development after reporting first calendar quarter results last night. Apples shares had even moved higher in afterhours trading Monday night after it reported 36% higher adjusted profit.

Apples stall in the light of strong results highlights how stocks and companies are not the same thing. While the company itself has delivered on financial targets, and even beat the whisper numbers, all that and more is priced into the stock.

So why is the stock down? But the question is, what is Apple really worth. Here are a couple ways to look at it:

* $125 a share. Do you have an iPhone? Probably. Lots of your friends probably do too. And thats the big problem. Problem you say? Its all about growth. While Apple is trying to diversify into watches and payment services, its still the iPhone company. And iPhone growth is likely to decelerate as the U.S. market is saturated, says Abhey Lamba, Mizuho Securities, who raised the price target on the stock after the first-quarter, but still says the stock is worth just $125 a share. New moves like the Apple Watch cant make up for future slowing in iPhone sales, Lamba says.

iPhone is the largest and most profitable product segment for Apple

and is the primary stock driver. We expect decelerating sales will create

a headwind on the stock. Managements commentary about Apple Watch,

combined with our checks in Asia continue to indicate unit volumes are slow

to ramp. Even if Watch results are above investor expectations, we dont think

it will be enough to offset the slowing iPhone category, Lamba says in a note to clients.

* $128 a share. Breaking down Apple into units gives investors a unique look at what the company is worth. Using this methodology, Trefis estimates the company is worth $128 a share.

* $133 a share. Apple investors have shown in the recent history this stock is worth 18 times its trailing diluted earnings. Here are some numbers to make it all more clear. Apple has delivered $7.39 a share in diluted earnings per share excluding extraordinary items over the past twelve months. Thats an astounding amount of profit, to the tune of $43 billion. But the problem is that investors have pushed the market value of the company to a record-breaking $767 billion. In other words, investors are paying $17.84 for a claim in just one dollar of earnings. And its at the 18 a share P-E level  where the stock has peaked multiple times before and that appears to be the price investors are willing to pay for the company now.

* $147.34 a share. Analysts currently peg the value of Apple at $147.34 a share in 18 months. The analysts have been consistently ratcheting up their expectations as the company continues to beat expectations the past five quarters.

* $150 a share. UBS, which has been more bullish on the stock than most analysts, says investors should focus on the valuation based on projected earnings. On that basis, $150 a share would be just 16.5 times expected earnings in 2015, says UBS. Thats a 10% discount to the markets valuation, UBS says. Earnings growth should be about 40% the next two quarters, UBS says, so its not that much of a stretch, the firm says.

* $185 a share. Apple deserves to be richly valued for its Picasso-Like Quarter, according to a report from FBR. The company still can grow in China and new products and services will drive it to a premium valuation, FBR says. The only correct thing to do is apply a rich 19 times valuation to the 2016 earnings estimate, giving you $185 a share, FBR says.

Its a wide range of value. But thats what you get with a highly contested, highly valued stock like this.

column3: Men Can Stop Rape event at Radford U. mostly missing one thing
Men Can Stop Rape event at Radford U. mostly missing one thing: Men
column4: ['Courtney Rozen', 'Jillian Deutsch', 'Sam Lisker', 'Usa Today Network Josh Hafner Usa Today', 'Varsity Tutors']
column5:
A Men Can Stop Rape presentation at Radford University ended in controversy last week. But it wasnt the topic that was concerning, it was the makeup of the attendees: Roughly one man to every 10 women.

@aabos it's sad that it was mandatory for all sororities by fraternities only had to send like 8-10 I believe  Allyson Yates (@AYatess) March 2, 2016

Interested to see how men are going to learn to stop rape when barely any men were required to be here   Litney Houston (@catey_cope) March 2, 2016

Panhellenic Council President Kaitlyn Julien told WSLS that she had received hundreds of calls and text messages from outraged sorority members.

And she tells USA TODAY College, The women saw it as a really important topic, (but) the men were just thinking in terms of it being, (well), another speaker.

The university held the public event, called Reimaging Consent: How Healthy Masculinity Can Prevent Rape, to help kick-off Womens History Month. Men Can Stop Rape is a Washington, D.C.-based organization that seeks to mobilize men to use their strength for creating cultures free from violence, especially mens violence against women, according to its website.

Both the Panhellenic Council and the Interfraternity Council had provided money to sponsor the event.

The difference in attendance, says Julien, likely had to do with the Panhellenic Council voting to make the event mandatory for all Greek women (each of the seven sororities has some 80 members) while the Interfraternity Council, made up of 12 fraternities, voted to require eight men per chapter to show up.

Radford University host's Men Can Stop Rape on campus to kick-off Women's History Month. #letsendit #ItsOnUs pic.twitter.com/40YFtgUAuZ  RU Greek Life (@RUGreeks) March 2, 2016

Interfraternity Council President Dustin Craig told WSLS that they made that decision to ensure there were enough fraternity brothers to attend other events that week. But Craig could not recall if there were any Greek events the night of the presentation, the website reports.

Craig chalked it up to a lack of communication.

We are working to better the communication between the two councils, Julien says.

column3: Justin Upton not concerned
column5:

The Cardinals are prepared to be without him until June at the earliest. St. Louis isnt chasing outside help at the position and are evaluating SS Aledmys Diaz, 2B Greg Garcia and 2B Jedd Gyorko.

column3: Health officials call on Congress to approve Zika funds
column5:
In this Feb. 24, 2016 photo, an employee with the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention tests human blood samples for Zika at the CDC's dengue lab in San Juan, Puerto Rico. One of the CDC's main goals is to test every single pregnant woman in Puerto Rico for Zika and prevent people from contracting the virus. (Photo: Danica Coto, ap)

Federal health officials from the Obama administration called on Congress Thursday to approve the president's request for $1.8 million in emergency funding to combat the Zika virus.

The directors of the both the Centers for Disease Control and the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Disease said their agencies' work is hampered by a lack of secure funding.

The allergy and infectious disease institute has been forced to move money away from other areas in order to work on Zika virus vaccines, said Anthony Fauci, director of the allergy and infectious disease institute, part of the National Institutes of Health. The institute could have to slow down or stop working on a universal flu vaccine, as well as vaccines to prevent HIV and respiratory syncytial virus, or RSV, a disease that can be very dangerous in babies.

Fauci said his agency hopes to begin an early trial of a Zika virus, called a Phase 1 trial, by late summer or early fall.

"We may find ourselves halfway through a Phase 1 trial and not being able to finish it and take the next immediate step," Fauci said.

Although the pharmaceutical industry has historically shown relatively little interest in developing vaccines against tropical diseases, the Zika epidemic in the Americas has attracted several companies who now want to partner with the federal government. Those partnerships could be in jeopardy if NIH funding doesn't come through. Without secure funding, NIH could be seen as an "unreliable partner," Fauci said.

The CDC, which has devoted 750 staff to fighting Zika, has stopped working on other diseases, said CDC director Thomas Frieden. The agnecy is no working working on dengue, a sometimes fatal illness spread by the same mosquito that spreads Zika. Hawaii has been fighting a dengue outbreak, and the disease is widespread in Puerto Rico.

In addition, the CDC's facility for insect-borne diseases in Fort Collins, Colo., is now working full-time on Zika virus and has stopped researching diseases spread by ticks.

"We hope Congress will rapidly provide resources for a robust response," Frieden said.

column3: Sophie Gregoire-Trudeau pops with Canadian color at the White House
column5:
First lady Michelle Obama and first lady of Canada Sophie Gregoire-Trudeau, at the White House welcoming ceremony for the Canada state visit on March 10, 2016 in Washington. (Photo: Pablo Martinez Monsivais, AP)

The Canadians are here, and whaddya know, the snowbirds brought spring.

Check out Sophie Gregoire-Trudeau, first lady of the north, who arrived at the White House Thursday for a state visit with husband, the just-elected Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, son of the storied former PM, Pierre Trudeau.

But eyes were on Sophie, 40, and no wonder: She practically popped with color, clad in a long-sleeved, form-fitting dress in red solids mixed with pink/purple florals by Canadian designer Lucian Matis, according to his tweet.

Michelle Obama and Sophie Gregoire-Trudeau laugh during arrival ceremony on the South Lawn of the White House, in Washington. (Photo: OLIVIER DOULIERY/POOL, EPA)

Her entire outfit was Canadian, according to Canadian media reports. She carried a red clutch with scalloped details by Aldo and pink pointy-toed pumps by Zvelle.

Sophie Gregoire-Trudeau wearing @lucianmatis in Washington DC https://t.co/aZS3gMGzsW  Lucian Matis (@lucianmatis) March 10, 2016

Mrs. Trudeau especially stood out in the welcoming ceremony crowd next to first lady Michelle Obama, who wore a black duster over a dark teal sleeveless dress in a batik-style pattern.

But both women seemed to be having a good time, roaring with laughter at one point.

Michelle Obama says Sophie Gregoire-Trudeau "is like my soul mate right now." #PMJTinDC#squadgoalspic.twitter.com/5qg4G7zHIx  Melissa Royle (@melissaroyle) March 10, 2016

Lots of anticipation about what each woman will wear at Thursday night's state dinner for the Trudeaus. Maybe they both will wear Canadian.

The last time a Canadian prime minister named Trudeau was feted at the White House it was 1977 and Jimmy Carter was president. Pierre Trudeau dined on Alaska king crab and his wife, Justin's mother Margaret Trudeau, made headlines by wearing a dress that ended about two inches below the knee, even though all the other women, including former first lady Rosalynn Carter, wore long gowns. And that Mrs. Trudeau, now 67, had a run in her stocking.

Meanwhile, President Obama and the youthful-looking prime minister, 44, seemed to be hitting it off, too. At one point, as the two men greeted excited fans on the South Lawn, Obama picked up a baby from the greeting line and showed him to Trudeau.

Later, in their remarks, the two traded jokey trash talk about the usual weather in Ottawa (snow), who has the better beer and hockey teams, and the current possessor of the Stanley Cup.

As the audience oohed and roared with laughter, POTUS teased Trudeau: "Wheres the Stanley Cup right now?," he said, according to the White House transcript. "Don't get me started," Trudeau joked back.

"I'm sorry. Is it in my hometown with the Chicago Blackhawks?," Obama continued as the audience cheered. " In case you were wondering? In case you Canadians were wondering, where is it?"

The charismatic Canadian prime minister has won hearts over his progressive policies and easy charm. Trudeau hopes to capitalize on the attention to focus "on substance." Video provided by Newsy Newslook

column3: Ivy League to add men's, women's hoops tournaments in 2017
column5:
The Ivy League is adding men's and women's conference tournaments for the 2017 season that will determine the conference's automatic berths for the NCAA Tournament.

The Ivy League had traditionally sent its regular season champion to the tournament.

The 2017 tournament for men and women will be held March 11 and 12 at the Palestra in Philadelphia. The Palestra is the on-campus home for Ivy League team Penn.

Only the top-four teams in the standings will advance to the tournament.

Yale won for men and Penn the women this season under the traditional round-robin format.

Robin Harris, the conference's executive director, says the format of the tournament lets the league preserve its significance of the regular season while giving athletes and fans something to anticipate.

column3: Apple confirms event for March 21
column5:
Apple's media invite for an event on March 21. (Photo: Apple)

Apple confirmed Thursday it will host an event on March 21 where it is widely expected the tech giant will unveil a smaller iPhone.

The event will take place on Apple's campus in Cupertino, Calif., according to an invite sent to media on Thursday. The event takes place the day before Apple returns to federal court in its battle over an FBI request to unlock an encrypted iPhone used by one of the killers in the San Bernardino, Calif., shootings.

Multiple media reports suggest Apple will introduce an iPhone with a 4-inch touchscreen, smaller than its current iPhone 6S and 6S Plus, which feature screens of 4.7 inches and 5.5 inches respectively.

The launch of a new iPhone model comes at a critical time for Apple, as sales of its flagship device are showing signs of a slowdown. Last quarter, Apple revealed sales of the iPhone were flat, and warned they will trend lower during the current quarter.

Apple is also expected to reveal a smaller version of its iPad Pro tablet. The device would feature a 9.7-inch touchscreen, the same size as Apple's iPad Air.

Follow Brett Molina on Twitter: @brettmolina23.

column3: Denver interested in Brian Hoyer?
column5:
Detroit Tigers OF Justin Upton (ankle) doesnt seem very concerned with his left ankle injury and was walking fine after leaving the trainers room Wednesday, March 9. Upton said his ankle rolled a little bit when it was stepped on, but he thinks hell be fine. Upton will take Thursday, March 10, off and re-evaluate the injury Friday, March 11.

Tip: This could be a big blow to Upton owners early in spring. Keep an eye on his progress this weekend. If the injury isn't anything serious, Upton carries elite power onto a new team with a much more potent offense than he had last year in San Diego. Upton is worth selecting in the early rounds as your second outfielder.

column3: Former Bills LB Nigel Bradham joins Eagles
column5:
The Philadelphia Eagles have agreed on a two-year contract with linebacker Nigel Bradham.

The 26-year-old Bradham is the third former Bills player to join the Eagles this week. The team also signed cornerback Leodis McElvin on Tuesday and cornerback Ron Brooks on Wednesday.

All three played for new Eagles defensive coordinator Jim Schwartz when he held that position in Buffalo in 2014.

Bradham started the first 11 games last year and had 57 tackles before an injury ended his season. He had 100 tackles, 212 sacks, one interception, two forced fumbles and seven pass breakups under Schwartz in 2014.

Bradham will help fill the role created by the trade of linebacker Kiko Alonso to Miami.

___

column3: Devin Booker recovers from slump
column5:
Mar 6, 2016; Memphis, TN, USA; Phoenix Suns guard Devin Booker (1) dribbles during the second half against the Memphis Grizzlies at FedExForum. Phoenix defeated Memphis 109-100. Mandatory Credit: Nelson Chenault-USA TODAY Sports (Photo: Nelson Chenault, Nelson Chenault-USA TODAY Sports)

Devin Booker has finally climbed out of his post All-Star break slump.

For the first time since early February, Booker makes his way back into our top five, while injuries have plagued Kristaps Porzingis, Jahlil Okafor, Bobby Portis, and Stanley Johnson.

Check out our weekly rookie rankings below, looking at the ever-changing list of the NBA's newcomers as we near the final stretch of the season.

1. Karl-Anthony Towns

No. 1: Karl-Anthony Towns (Photo: Matthew Emmons, USA TODAY Sports)

Last week's rank: No. 1

Towns is the clear-cut choice for Rookie of the Year, and he continued to show why after another week of dominance. To put his elite rookie status into better perspective, take a look at his 36 double-doubles. The last first-year player to eclipse the 30 double-double mark in a season was Blake Griffin in the 2010-11. The rookie big men in recent years that didn't? Anthony Davis, Andre Drummond, DeMarcus Cousins, Kenneth Faried, Kevin Love, Marc Gasol, and Al Horford, to name a few.

Weekly statistics - Points: 24.0, rebounds: 9.0, assists: 3.0, blocks: 1.5, field goal percentage: 65.7%, games played: 4, minutes: 33.6

Season statistics - Points: 17.7, rebounds: 10.2, assists: 1.7, blocks: 1.8, field goal percentage: 54.5%, player efficiency rating: 23.16, minutes: 31.0

2. Kristaps Porzingis

Last week's rank: No. 2

The three-time Eastern Conference Rookie of the Month has slowed down a bit as of late, and that's just fine. Porzingis has already exceeded his pre-draft expectations. With a leg bruise that has hindered both his minutes and production, as well as New York's meager chance at a spot in the postseason, it's in their best interest to take it easy on their franchise player as the season winds down.

Weekly statistics - Points: 11.3, rebounds: 5.0, assists: 1.7, blocks: 0.7, field goal percentage: 31.4%, games played: 3, minutes: 20.9

Season statistics - Points: 13.9, rebounds: 7.3, assists: 1.2, blocks: 1.9, field goal percentage: 42.1%, player efficiency rating: 18.14, minutes: 27.7

3. Jahlil Okafor

Last week's rank: No. 3

Okafor remained on the bench for the Philadelphia 76ers this week because of a nagging shin injury, and could remain on the sidelines for the remainder of his rookie season. There is no definite timetable for his return, and you can expect the Sixers to err on the side of caution. Still, that's not enough to knock him out of our top three, as he has been one of the top performers of the rookie class in the season's entirety up to this point.

Weekly statistics - Did not play

Season statistics - Points: 17.5, rebounds: 7.0, assists: 1.2, blocks: 1.2, field goal percentage: 50.8%, player efficiency rating: 17.46, minutes: 30.0

4. Devin Booker

No. 4: Devin Booker (Photo: Jennifer Stewart, USA TODAY Sports)

Last week's rank: No. 8

Booker is back. His three-point shooting prowess was on display this week, as he led all rookies in scoring, including a career-high 34-point performance on Thursday and a 32-point outing on Wednesday. He also led all rookies in three-pointers made (2.5 a game) and minutes (38.5). With the Phoenix Suns' season all but over, expect the rookie sharpshooter to keep firing away.

Weekly statistics - Points: 26.8, rebounds: 3.0, assists: 5.0, steals: 0.3, field goal percentage: 48.1%, games played: 4, minutes: 38.5

Season statistics - Points: 11.8, rebounds: 2.2, assists: 2.0, steals: 0.5, field goal percentage: 43.2%, player efficiency rating: 12.06, minutes: 25.1

5. D'Angelo Russell

Last week's rank: No. 4

Russell had another strong series of games as the starting point guard for the Los Angeles Lakers, but his highlight of the week my have occurred off the court. Reigning 2015 and surefire 2016 NBA MVP Stephen Curry spoke highly of the the rookie point guard via Slyce:

Stephen Curry on D'Angelo Russell pic.twitter.com/PhswZTcfCH  Diamond Leung (@diamond83) March 7, 2016

Season statistics - Points: 13.3, assists: 3.5, rebounds: 3.5, steals: 1.2, field goal percentage: 42.7%, player efficiency rating: 14.67, minutes: 27.9

Weekly statistics - Points: 18.3, assists: 4.3, rebounds: 2.3, steals: 2.3, field goal percentage: 40.8%, games played: 3, minutes: 32.8

6. Nikola Jokic

Last week's rank: No. 6

Only Karl-Anthony Towns has a higher player efficiency rating for rookies than Jokic this season. This week, it was yet another solid series of games for the Serbian big man, as he led all rookies in rebounding while falling just one board shy of a clean sweep of three double-doubles in three games.

Weekly statistics - Points: 16.0, rebounds: 11.0, assists: 3.3, blocks: 1.0, field goal percentage: 42.2%, games played: 3, minutes: 29.5

Season statistics - Points: 9.9, rebounds: 6.4, assists: 2.1, blocks: 0.6, field goal percentage: 51.5%, player efficiency rating: 21.84, minutes: 20.4

7. Emmanuel Mudiay

No. 7: Emmanuel Mudiay (Photo: Isaiah J. Downing, USA TODAY Sports)

Last week's rank: No. 9

Mudiay's main downfall has been his continued shooting struggles and his inability to limit turnovers. This week, he only gave the ball away six times over the course of three games and put together a 25-point performance on 56.3% shooting in a loss to the Brooklyn Nets on Friday. He also led all rookies in field goal attempts (18.7 a game), as his confidence continues to climb, particularly in the absence of Danilo Gallinari.

Weekly statistics - Points: 18.7, assists: 6.7, rebounds: 5.7, steals: 1.3, field goal percentage: 37.5%, games played: 3, minutes: 34.5

Season statistics - Points: 11.7, assists: 5.8, rebounds: 3.4, steals: 1.1, field goal percentage: 34.5%, player efficiency rating: 9.17, minutes: 30.4

8. Myles Turner

Last week's rank: No. 5

As can be expected with all NBA rookies, Turner had an off-week. In his three games, he never scored in double-digits, and he shot five for 24 from the field. He was also trumped by Solomon Hill in the starting lineup in Friday's game against the Charlotte Hornets, but reclaimed the starting duties for the next two games. As a pivotal part of the Indiana Pacers' playoff push, all signs say that Turner  the Eastern Conference Rookie of the Month for February  will be back in top-form sooner rather than later.

Weekly statistics - Points: 5.7, rebounds: 5.3, assists: 0.7, blocks: 1.0, field goal percentage: 20.8%, games played: 3, minutes: 26.6

Season statistics - Points: 10.4, rebounds: 5.1, assists: 0.5, blocks: 1.5, field goal percentage: 50.4%, player efficiency rating: 15.80, minutes: 22.6

9. Justise Winslow

No. 9: Justise Winslow (Photo: Brad Penner, USA TODAY Sports)

Last week's rank: No. 7

Winslow has struggled to score throughout the majority of his rookie campaign, ranking 13th in points and 14th in field goal percentage amongst the NBA's newcomers. But his combination of maturity, athleticism, and defensive dexterity have continued to give him adequate minutes on the floor, as he ranks fourth amongst all rookies in minutes per game and second with a defensive rating of 97.9.

Season statistics - Points: 6.1, rebounds: 5.3, assists: 1.4, steals: 0.8, field goal percentage: 42.4%, player efficiency rating: 7.90, minutes: 28.2

10. Bobby Portis

Last week's rank: 10

Portis has been dealing with an eye issue this week that has limited him to just eighth total minutes in two games. He will be a game-time decision for Thursday's game against the San Antonio Spurs, according to the Chicago Tribune.
