column3: 5 reasons why bond yields are on the rise
column5:
The era of record-low bond yields, born a few years back at the depths of the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression, seems to be nearing an end.

Suddenly, not every investor in the world thinks government bond yields in the U.S., or places like Germany, will stay near record low levels for much longer, now that eurozone economies are showing signs of life and the Federal Reserve is on track to eventually hike short-term rates.

And that change in thinking, has caused the 10-year U.S. Treasury yield to spike up today as high as 2.356%, its highest level since late November, and up nearly three-quarters of a percentage point above its Feb. 2, 2015, intraday low of 1.65%.

Similarly, the German 10-year bond, which had been acting like the ultimate safe-haven investment earlier this year when its yield flirted with going negative, has risen in a matter of weeks above 0.7% and was yielding 0.678% in afternoon trading.

Here are five reasons why bond yields are up and what it could mean for both bond and stock market investors.

1. Momentum trade reverses.

Everybody was betting that yields would stay low forever and kept buying bonds. But that changed after bond gurus Bill Gross of Janus and Jeffrey Gundlach of Doubleline Capital have said betting against German government bonds is a good bet. So selling replaced buying and bond prices fell.

It appears everyone is scrambling to be short,  or putting on new trades that make money when German bonds fall in value and yields rise, says Axel Merk, chief investment officer at Merk Investments.

The momentum trade may work in reverse now, Merk told USA TODAY. Little has changed in terms of fundamentals, but this is a market far removed from reality. Trouble is that valuations are high and investors have been complacent; as fear may be returning to the market, both stock and bond investors may be scrambling to get out. Fasten your seatbelt, we havent seen anything yet.

2. Deflation fears fade.

Everyone wanted to be in bonds when inflation, the enemy of fixed-income investments, was dormant. But now inflation is perking back up in the eurozone and nearing the Feds 2% mandate here at home. As a result, the threat of deflation has diminished, says Don Luskin, chief investment officer at TrendMacro.

And that is pushing up bond yields  which move in the opposite direction of prices.

Global oil prices have rallied from the lows in March, which has reinvigorated inflation expectations around the world, Luskin says. Naturally, this makes bond yields go up  especially when everyone had believed that deflation was virtually our destiny in this time of secular stagnation.

3. Sign ECBs QE program is working.

Yields should rise if economic activity starts to pick up with the help of central bank stimulus, adds Kotok.

Eurozone area yields, which have gone up the most, have been driven higher by the ECBs quantitative easing (QE)  or bond-buying  program, Kotok explains. Its unintuitive, but this is the same thing that happened in the U.S. all three times the Federal Reserve did QE. At first yields fall, but then they move higher. Its really not that strange. The idea of QE is to improve inflation and growth expectations. So if QE succeeds, it means yields will go higher, not lower. In fact, thats how you know that QE is doing its job.

4. Investors reposition portfolios.

The current spike in yields isnt related to any new economic developments or news, but instead is about positioning, argues Bill Hornbarger, Moneta Groups chief investment strategist.

You had many people leaning into the QE trade in Europe in a momentum trade. They were buying European sovereign debt at sometimes negative yields, on the idea that they could trade it at a higher price and lower yields to someone else. I believe a few people started to reverse the position and very quickly you had many people following suit. Very analogous to yelling fire in the crowded theatre, many people trying to get out of a small door. As European yields rose, coupled with Fed rhetoric, U.S. yields have also risen in sympathy.

As for U.S. stocks, a sharp spike in bond yields could be an excuse for the long-awaited correction, or a drop of 10% or more, he adds.

We are down a little bit from the all-time highs and we havent had a real 10% correction in six years or so, Hornbarger says. That correction will happen at some point. If bonds continue to struggle this could be the excuse for it to happen.

5. Its a short-term yield-spike tantrum.

We are watching a tantrum in bonds and it started in the euro zone, then spread worldwide. I think it is reaching extremes. says David Kotok, chief investment officer at Cumberland Advisors.

And while the bond tantrum triggered stock uncertainty, Kotok isnt expecting a major move down in stocks.

Says Kotok: Value in stocks remain intact. Inflation remains low. Economic growth is gradually firming. Greece is a mess but it is now small and old news.

The good news in all this recent bond market volatility?

The shift is arguably a healthy one to the extent it takes yields away from uncharted terrain and reduces the extent of the necessary selloff when the Fed starts hiking rates later this year, says Eric Lascelles, chief economist at RBC Global Asset Management.

Adds Hornbarger: I think it is going to be hard to point to a single event and say this is the end of the bond bull market. ... The conditions are (still) in place for yields to stay low for an extended period.

But low would still include a 10-year note a full percentage point higher than today, Hornbarger says, adding that if global yields calm down and the Fed stays on hold this year, you could get another move down in yields to the cyclical lows.

column3: (*) FACTS/FLUKES: Kipnis, B. Miller, Quintana, An. Sanchez, Britton
column5:
Kipnis fading...When Facts/Flukes columnist Dave Adler looked at Jason Kipnis (2B, CLE) last July, he pointed out that Kipnis had changed his approach, trading strikeouts and power for contact and BA. He also noted that Kipnis was running less often and might not be a 30-SB threat going forward. Is there any hope of Kipnis returning to 2013 levels?

Year AB HR/SB BA xBA HctX h% PX xPX Spd SB% ct% Eye LD OPS ==== === ===== === === ==== == === === === === === ==== === === 2011 136 7/5 272 289 103 32 166 126 89 93% 75 0.32 21% 841 2012 591 14/31 257 259 97 29 76 91 105 82% 82 0.61 23% 714 2013 564 17/30 284 265 109 35 125 128 99 81% 75 0.53 25% 818 2014 500 6/22 240 249 92 29 72 84 95 88% 80 0.50 23% 640 2015 565 9/12 303 285 107 36 103 97 120 60% 81 0.53 27% 823 ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ 15-1H 320 6/10 341 307 110 39 112 89 122 67% 84 0.75 29% 925 15-2H 245 3/2 253 256 102 32 92 109 111 40% 78 0.33 24% 687

We are unlikely to see concurrent HR/SB totals approaching 2013, but he should remain a valuable BA asset with some power & speed.

His Spd is still intact and actually better than ever in 2015. Formerly pristine SB% fell sharply in the 1H before the bottom dropped out in the 2H.

2013's power spike appears to have been an outlier given the slightly below league average xPX levels posted in three of the last four seasons. Any 15-1H PX optimism is nullified by the corresponding xPX.

Consistently good LD% reached new heights in 2015 and, when considered in conjunction with HctX & Spd, give credence to his improved h%. BA/xBA are never too far apart and almost converge over the larger sample of Kipnis' MLB career (.272 BA/.270 xBA).

Volatile OPS has much to do with h% fluctuations that may be the result of things beyond Kipnis' control. Consistent Eye, LD%, Spd, and HctX should provide a more stable h% & OPS year-to-year.

Kipnis hit the DL in early August with a sore left shoulder that likely contributed to his subpar 15-2H. Though Kipnis is unlikely to return to the near-$30 level of 2013, he maintains a stable set of skills that should continue to provide double-digit HR and SB totals along with a good BA.

Unlock all of our insights on your way to a fantasy title! See what our season-long coverage offers and then subscribe to BaseballHQ.com.

Miller flying under the radar...Traded by the Mariners to the Rays this offseason, Bradley Miller (SS/OF, TAM) begins the 2016 season as the presumptive regular SS in Tampa Bay. The former 2nd round pick has continued to flash the same intriguing power/speed skills in the majors that he did in the minors and as an amateur. What should we expect from Miller in his upcoming age 26 season?

Year AB HR/SB BA xBA bb% ct% Eye HH% GB/LD/FB PX hr/f SB% Spd SBO% ===== === ===== === === === === ==== === ======== === ==== === === ==== 2012* 147 3/4 264 --- 12 79 0.67 --- -------- 82 ---- 76% 115 9% 2013+ 563 17/10 269 264 8 81 0.46 30% 46/22/32 97 10% 56% 137 11% 2014 367 10/ 4 221 236 8 74 0.36 31% 42/19/39 105 10% 67% 124 7% 2015 438 11/13 258 254 10 77 0.47 30% 48/20/31 97 10% 76% 113 14% ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- MLB career splits: vLHP 305 2/3 226 --- 6 75 0.24 24% 50/18/32 45 3% 43% --- ---- vRHP 806 27/19 256 --- 10 79 0.51 33% 44/21/35 111 12% 79% --- ---- * MLEs + inc MLEs

There's a lot to like here, but ineptitude vs LHP governs his potential ceiling:

League average PX and above average Spd make Miller a legit double-digit HR/SB threat at SS. Solid plate discipline, sufficient hard contact, and satisfactory batted ball profile should keep BA from becoming a drag.

2015 SB% rose to just beyond the break-even point and likely allowed Miller greater freedom on the base paths as SBO% doubled. Increased patience drove bb% into the double digits and should help sustain increased SBO%.

Career results and skills vs LHP plummet across the boardand 2015 was no different. Currently, he's a liability when facing LHP and a potential strong-side platoon partner with teammate Tim Beckham (.733 OPSvL).

Miller has been mentioned as a likely candidate for the 2016 leadoff role in Tampa Bay, a development that could be a boon for his SB totals if consummated. His legs are one of the several paths to a $20 season mentioned in the 2016 Baseball Forecaster and the ADPs indicate that he can be acquired for much less. With multi-positional eligibility and upside beyond our projection, Miller makes for an attractive, potentially profitable 2016 investment.

Strong 2H a harbinger for Quintana?...When we last had a look under the hood at Jose Quintana (LHP, CHW) in July 2015, we indicated potential for ERA, Ctl, and Dom improvement over the balance of the season. On cue, Quintana posted a 2.94 ERA, 1.19 WHIP, and 127 BPV during the 2nd half of 2015. Now that we've finished tooting our own horn, should his strong finish move him up our 2016 draft boards?

Year IP ERA xERA S% GB/LD Ctl Dom Cmd FpK Ball% SwK hr/9 BPV DOM/DIS ==== === ==== ==== == ===== === === === === ===== === ==== === ======= 2012 136 3.76 4.34 75 47/22 2.8 5.3 1.9 61 38% 8 0.9 46 32%/32% 2013 200 3.51 3.85 75 43/20 2.5 7.4 2.9 66 37% 9 1.0 86 55%/12% 2014 200 3.32 3.51 73 45/22 2.3 8.0 3.4 66 36% 9 0.4 104 66%/ 6% 2015 206 3.36 3.60 75 47/23 1.9 7.7 4.0 69 35% 9 0.7 112 66%/ 6% ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 15-1H 99 3.81 3.89 73 44/23 2.4 7.6 3.2 68 35% 10 0.7 96 56%/ 6% 15-2H 107 2.94 3.34 77 50/23 1.5 7.8 5.2 69 35% 9 0.7 127 75%/ 6%

While probably not an augury of sub-3.00 ERAs to come, there is room for potential improvement at the margins:

Improved FpK and Ball% indicate that sub-2.0 Ctl could stick in 2016. This has also pushed Cmd to 4.0, a level typically achieved by the best SP in the game.

His 2H GB% spike comes via pitch-mix change; Quintana decreased 4-seam FB use by 15% and increased use of sinking fastball and curveball by roughly the same amount. Both his fastball and curveball induce groundballs at a rate of 50% or more.

Quintana's hr/9 has been better than average the last two years, and the additional GBs may help mute regression. But the greater positive effect could be on S%, as groundballs provide more double play opportunities with runners on base. This may explain the 2nd half S% uptick.

SwK and Dom have remained largely static from 2013-2015, but if Quintana continues to increase use of his best pitch (curveball use, 2013-15: 20%/25%/31%) and it continues to induce more whiffs (SwK, 2013-15: 12%/12%/14%) his Dom could inch up into the low 8.0 range.

Though his stuff is not overpowering and he doesn't have much more room for growth, Quintana is a consistently good SP who often flies under the radar. Recent PQS-DOM%/DIS% figures paint a very accurate picture of who he is, and 2H DOM% also illustrates well the smidge of remaining projection. As one of only seven SP with AAA reliability and a 100+ BPV, Quintana should not be overlooked as you plan for your 2016 drafts and auctions.

For Sanchez, it looks worse than it really is...Just about anyone who rostered Anibal Sanchez (RHP, DET) in 2015 feels shame, regret, and a determination not to make the same mistake twice. After posting a 5.00+ ERA in each of the season's first two months, Sanchez drew us back with a 2.63 ERA in June, before resuming his championship-inhibiting ways in July/August. His season finally (and mercifully) concluded when he was placed on the DL with a rotator cuff strain on August 20. Does this signal the end of fantasy relevance for Anibal Sanchez?

Year IP ERA xERA Dom Ctl Cmd SwK Ball% Vel GB/LD/FB hr/f H%/S% BPV ==== === ==== ==== ==== === === === ===== ==== ======== ==== ===== === 2011 196 3.67 3.38 9.3 2.9 3.2 12 35% 91.7 44/20/36 10% 32/74 109 2012 196 3.86 3.7 7.7 2.2 3.5 10 34% 91.8 46/21/32 11% 32/72 103 2013 182 2.57 3.08 10.0 2.7 3.7 13 36% 93.0 45/22/33 6% 32/79 131 2014 126 3.43 3.58 7.3 2.1 3.4 10 35% 92.1 46/19/35 3% 29/67 97 2015 157 4.99 4.11 7.9 2.8 2.8 10 37% 91.9 40/21/39 16% 29/66 85 ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ 15-1H 112 4.65 3.85 8.0 2.6 3.1 10 36% 91.9 41/21/38 15% 27/64 94 15-2H 45 5.84 4.75 7.7 3.4 2.2 9 38% 91.8 37/22/42 18% 33/70 60

With good health, a return to 2012-14 skill level is possible, but there's more risk now:

Ugly 4.65 ERA in the 1H was largely the result of an unfortunate 15% hr/f. BPV and xERA indicate that Sanchez' skills were still intact to that point.

2H skills and results can at least be partially attributed to the cranky shoulder that eventually ended his season prematurely.

Consistent Vel and SwK raise no warning flags, and are sufficient enough for Sanchez to maintain his typical ~8.0 Dom level. The combination of rising Ball%, FB%, and hr/f in 1H to 2H is a cause for concern and may keep Sanchez from bouncing all the way back.

Sanchez' two-year run of single digit hr/f rates in 2013-2014 were bound regress at some point. His 3-year hr/f average from 2013-15 of 9% is the same as his career rate, so perhaps the optimist would say 2015's 16% hr/f was merely statistical normalization. It does appear that some of 2015's poor performance can be blamed on injury and since there's little indication of diminished velocity or stuff, the 32-year-old Sanchez could end 2016 with a line that looks very similar to the one he posted in 2014. However, it would be wise to keep the 2016 Baseball Forecaster's "5.00 ERA, more DL time" downside in mind and invest modestly, if at all.

Britton is an elite closer...When the Orioles decided to move Zach Britton (LHP, BAL) to the bullpen prior to the 2014 season, they asked him to ditch all of his secondary pitches and focus on improving the command of his sinker. Britton then went out and limited opposing hitters to a .500 oOPS in 2014, and hurled his sinker 91% of the time. He then worked to improve his breaking ball, and his SwK rate on the pitch increased from 18% to 31%, clearly the driving force behind the additional 3.5 strikeouts per nine that he added in 2015. What could Britton be working on for 2016and could he possibly get any better?

Year SV ERA xERA S% GB Dom Ctl Cmd FpK Ball% SwK Vel hr/9 BPV ==== == ==== ==== == == ==== === === === ===== === ==== ==== === 2011 0 4.61 4.20 68 53 5.7 3.6 1.6 53 40% 7 92.1 0.7 35 2012 0 5.07 4.01 68 61 7.9 4.8 1.7 51 42% 10 92.0 0.9 52 2013 0 4.95 4.76 72 58 4.1 3.8 1.1 54 40% 7 91.6 0.9 6 2014 37 1.65 2.44 85 75 7.3 2.7 2.7 55 36% 13 95.1 0.5 111 2015 36 1.92 1.75 82 79 10.8 1.9 5.6 64 31% 17 95.9 0.4 200 ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 15-2H 13 2.03 1.55 82 86 11.0 2.0 5.4 68 31% 19 96.6 0.6 208

Britton has already ascended higher than most expected, but may not have reached the pinnacle:

Pitching out of the pen has allowed Britton to really let loose and it appears his fastball velocity may not have topped out yet, approaching 97 mph in the 2nd half. GB% also spiked with move to the pen and has continued to rise, topping out at an amazing 86% in the 2nd half.

Increased velocity and improved command must make his sinker seem like a bowling ball to opposing hitters. Extremely high S% is probably very sustainable as GBs with runners on often result in a force out or double play.

2015 Ball% and 15-2H FpK are indicative of Ctl levels closer to 1.5. With a 17%+ SwK there's room for more Dom growth too.

If he's not already the top closer in the game, Britton has certainly worked his way into the conversation. His 2015 BPIs, already lofty, somehow improved in the second half. If you're in the market for an elite closer in 2016, Britton is as good or better than the first ones off the board and can often be acquired a round or two later.

column3: Oilers' Nurse suspended 3 games for being aggressor
column5:
(Photo: The Associated Press)

NEW YORK (AP)  The NHL has suspended Edmonton Oilers defenseman three games for being the aggressor in a fight with Roman Polak of the San Jose Sharks on Tuesday.

The NHL announced the suspension Thursday.

Nurse took exception to a hit Polak made on teammate Matt Hendricks and started fighting the Sharks defenseman before he dropped his gloves. Nurse was given a two-minute minor for roughing and a five-minute major penalty for fighting.

Nurse violated the rule that prohibits fighting an unwilling combatant. He will forfeit $13,925 as a result of the suspension and miss games against the Minnesota Wild, Arizona Coyotes and Nashville Predators.

column3: Colin Kaepernick to draw more interest
column5:
Detroit Tigers OF Justin Upton (ankle) doesnt seem very concerned with his left ankle injury and was walking fine after leaving the trainers room Wednesday, March 9. Upton said his ankle rolled a little bit when it was stepped on, but he thinks hell be fine. Upton will take Thursday, March 10, off and re-evaluate the injury Friday, March 11.

Tip: This could be a big blow to Upton owners early in spring. Keep an eye on his progress this weekend. If the injury isn't anything serious, Upton carries elite power onto a new team with a much more potent offense than he had last year in San Diego. Upton is worth selecting in the early rounds as your second outfielder.

column3: Spider-Man finally shows up in the new Captain America: Civil War trailer
column4: ["Hemal Jhaveri Writes Mostly About The Nhl For Ftw She Likes 'fast Furious' Really Thinks Rick Michonne Should Be A Couple", 'Hemal Jhaveri', 'Maggie Hendricks', 'Charles Curtis', 'Ted Berg', 'Nate Scott', 'Steven Ruiz', 'Nina Mandell', 'Laken Litman', 'Luke Kerr-dineen']
column5:
Marvel just released a new Captain America: Civil War trailer and wouldnt you know it, things are about to get very serious and violent!

The new trailer doesnt reveal too many more plot details, but fans finally get their first look at Spider-Man, played by newcomer Tom Holland, when he swoops in at the very end after getting a call from his good friend Tony Stark.

Ill admit, the trailer looks pretty excellent and shows us a lot more of the conflict between Iron Man and Captain America and how their major rift starts to form.

We also get more of a glimpse between the epic beat down Captain America and Iron are going to give each other. Its all very tense and dramatic, with a lot of hurt looks passing between the former bros.

Captain America: Civil War is out May 6 but you should probably just camp outside theaters now.

column3: Restricted free agent running back Anderson visits Dolphins
column5:
MIAMI (AP)  Restricted free agent running back C.J. Anderson is visiting the Miami Dolphins, who need a replacement for Lamar Miller.

The visit Thursday, Anderson's first in free agency, was a small victory for the Dolphins because he's being courted by other teams.

Anderson, a three-year veteran, rushed for 720 yards last year for the Super Bowl champion Denver Broncos. They would have five days to match any offer from the Dolphins.

New Miami coach Adam Gase was offensive coordinator for the Broncos and Anderson in 2013-14. The Dolphins lost Miller when he agreed to a free agent deal Wednesday with the Houston Texans.

___

column3: Keystone pipeline company weighing acquisition
column5:
A sign is posted in front of TransCanada's Keystone pipeline facilities in Hardisty, Alberta, on Nov. 6, 2015. (Photo: Jeff McIntosh, The Canadian Press via AP)

The Canadian company that failed to win approval of the Keystone XL pipeline has reportedly set its sights on a potential deal to acquire a major U.S. gas pipeline company.

Calgary, Alberta-based TransCanada is discussing a plan to acquire pipeline operator Columbia Pipeline in a deal that could be valued at more than $10 billion, according to a Wall Street Journal report.

The talks come as energy companies are facing financial intense pressure amid rock-bottom oil prices that have undermined profits. Although the pain has been largely confined to oil producers and services companies, analysts say the ripple effects will soon begin to hurt pipeline operators, as well.

"It is company policy not to comment on market rumors or speculation," TransCanada spokesman James Millar said in a statement. "As we have said previously, TransCanada remains focused on opportunities that would be in line with our strategy and grow shareholder value."

Columbia Pipeline spokesman James Yardley declined to comment.

TransCanada shares (TRP) fell 3.1% to $35.96 in mid-day trading. Columbia Pipeline shares (CPGX) shot up 14.9% to $22.69.

The potential accord comes after TransCanada lost its bid to construct a pipeline that would have transported oil from Canadian oil sands through the American heartland to the Gulf Coast.

The controversial proposal faced stringent opposition from environmentalists who feared the Keystone XL pipeline's potential impact on climate change. President Obama denied a permit that would have been necessary for the project to move forward.

TransCanada recorded an after-tax non-cash charge of $2.9 billion its balance sheet after the Keystone XL plan collapsed. The company swung from a net profit of $1.7 billion in 2014 to a net loss of $1.2 billion in 2015.

Houston-based Columbia, on the other hand, enjoyed a net profit of $530.2 million in 2015, nearly double its profit of $269.1 million in 2014.

Columbia is a master limited partnerships that operates about 15,000 miles of pipelines, primarily in the Marcellus and Utica Shale areas. It also controls underground natural gas storage.

Follow USA TODAY reporter Nathan Bomey on Twitter @NathanBomey.

Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/1paOAKg

column3: Racket sponsor backs Sharapova despite failed drug test
column5:
(Photo: The Associated Press)

VIENNA (AP)  Maria Sharapova's racket supplier became the first main sponsor to publicly back the five-time Grand Slam champion after she admitted to failing a doping test.

Austria-based company Head announced Thursday it was planning to extend its sponsorship deal, three days after Sharapova revealed her use of the banned substance meldonium.

Head CEO Johan Eliasch said Sharapova has made "a manifest error" by her continued use of the drug after it was banned, but added there was no "evidence of any intent by Maria of enhancing her performance or trying to gain an unfair advantage."

Eliasch said his brand, which started sponsoring Sharapova in 2011, "is proud to stand behind Maria, now and into the future and we intend to extend her contract. We look forward to working with her and to announcing new sponsorships."

Several other brands, including sports gear giant Nike, watch maker TAG Heuer, and sports car company Porsche, were quick to suspend their support of the world's highest-earning female athlete after her announcement Monday that she failed the drug test at the Australian Open in January, days after the substance was banned.

A former No. 1 for a total of 21 weeks, Sharapova earned an estimated $29.5 million last year alone, mostly off the court. Sharapova has 35 career singles titles and more than $36 million in career prize winnings.

Sharapova said she has taken meldonium for 10 years for various health issues and that she neglected to click on a link in a late December email to check the new list of banned substances. She faces a lengthy ban, which could prevent her from competing for Russia at the Olympics in Rio de Janeiro.

"She has and still is dealing with the medical conditions she described," Eliasch said. "Prior to 2016, we believe that Maria has never throughout her career been taking any WADA banned substances or any other illegal substances."

Eliasch said Sharapova was taking meldonium in such low doses that the drug couldn't possibly have had a stimulating effect on her performance, and that "we further conclude this falls into the category of 'honest' mistakes."

According to Eliasch, it "is common ground within the scientific community" that for meldonium to provide "any relevant performance enhancing effect it has to be taken in daily dosages in excess of 1,000 to 2,000mg."

The dosages Sharapova had been taken "were significantly short of performance enhancing levels," according to the CEO.

"The honesty and courage she displayed in announcing and acknowledging her mistake was admirable," Eliasch said. "Maria may have made a mistake, but she has earned the benefit of the doubt and we are extending it to her."

Copyright 2016 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.

column3: Arkansas, Oklahoma State to play in Frisco classic in 2017
column5:
FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. (AP)  The University of Arkansas and Oklahoma State baseball teams have accepted an invitation to play in the first Frisco College Baseball Classic.

The tournament will be in March 2017 in Frisco, Texas  the home of the Frisco Roughriders who are the Double-A affiliate of the Texas Rangers.

Arkansas and OSU are also scheduled to play each other twice later this season after the Razorbacks ousted the Cowboys from the NCAA baseball regional in Stillwater last season.

The tournament field also includes Nebraska and Arizona.

column3: Escaped Miss. murder suspect killed during home invasion
column5:
Rafael McCloud (Photo: Warren County Sheriff's Department)

JACKSON, Miss.  A man killed Thursday during a home invasion in Mississippi was an escaped murder suspect, a sheriff said.

Warren County (Miss.) Sheriff Martin Pace said in a text message that the man killed Thursday in a Vicksburg, Miss., home was 34-year-old Rafael McCloud.

McCloud escaped from the Warren County Jail on March 2 after taking a guard hostage with a homemade shank and stealing his clothing, keys and radio.

On Thursday, Vicksburg Police Chief Walter Armstrong said McCloud tied up a family and may have been at the home for three hours before 911 was called. The husband, who was stabbed in the shoulder, was able to get free of his bonds.

An hours-long struggle ensued at the end of which the homeowner shot McCloud in the head.

Authorities said McCloud broke into the homeowner's garage Thursday morning.

Law enforcement officers block off the scene before bringing out the body of a man killed in a home invasion in Vicksburg, Miss., on Thursday, March 10, 2016. Warren County Sheriff Martin Pace said the ma killed was escaped murder suspect Rafael McCloud. (Photo: Justin Sellers, The (Jackson, Miss.) Clarion-Ledger)

The hostages included a husband, wife and a child. There are no other reports of injuries besides the husband and the suspect.

McCloud was being held in the death of Sharon Wilson. Wilson, 69, was considered a missing person until her body was found outside the abandoned Kuhn Memorial State Hospital by ghost hunters. McCloud was indicted in January by a Warren County grand jury for capital murder, burglary of a dwelling, rape, sexual battery without consent, attempted arson, larceny-motor vehicle and possession of a weapon after felony conviction in connection with Wilson's slaying.

Contributing: The Associated Press. Follow Therese Apel on Twitter: @TRex21

Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/1piCCz8

column3: NBA on pace for record-breaking triple-double numbers
column5:
Feb 27, 2016; Oklahoma City, OK, USA; Oklahoma City Thunder guard Russell Westbrook (0) drives to the basket against Golden State Warriors forward Draymond Green (23) during the fourth quarter at Chesapeake Energy Arena. Mandatory Credit: Mark D. Smith-USA TODAY Sports (Photo: Mark D. Smith, Mark D. Smith-USA TODAY Sports)

In part because of the continual stat-stuffing performances by Oklahoma City Thunder guard Russell Westbrook and Golden State Warriors forward Draymond Green, the NBA's players are on pace to collectively accomplish something that would end a 25-year drought and has only been done four times in league history.

Sixty triple-doubles.

According to statistics provided by NBA.com and the Elias Sports Bureau, 19 different players  from ages 21 to 35, from point guards to centers  have combined to put together 51 triple-doubles this season. This marks the 12th time in NBA history  and the first time since the turn of the millennium  that the league has amassed 50 or more triple-doubles. If they reach 60, it would be the first time since the 1989-90 season.

Led by Magic Johnson (11 triple-doubles) and Larry Bird (10), the 1989-90 season was also the last time that two players recorded 10 or more triple-doubles in a single season, a feat that Green and Westbrook  with 11 apiece  already have matched.

Green's 11 overshadow the previous record for power forwards set by Charles Barkley and Kevin Garnett (7), and it took him less than half the season to do so. He also became the 15th player in NBA history to conjure up three consecutive triple-doubles earlier in the season.

Westbrook's 11 make him the first player since Jason Kidd in 2006-07 and 2007-08 to record double-digit triple-doubles in consecutive seasons.

Follow AJ Neuharth-Keusch on Twitter @tweetAJNK

column3: Greg Norman is still salty that Fox Sports fired him as its U.S. Open commentator
column4: ['Luke Kerr-dineen', 'Maggie Hendricks', 'Charles Curtis', 'Ted Berg', 'Nate Scott', "Luke Kerr-dineen Is A Writer Editor At Ftw Anglo-american Who Likes All Sports But Especially Golf Soccer He Saw The Spice Girls In Concert Once It's Been Downhill Ever Since", 'Hemal Jhaveri', 'Nina Mandell', 'Laken Litman']
column5:
On the spectrum of broadcasting live sports, you wont find more difficult than golf. The rules are nuanced, the shots are detailed, its painfully slow at times, and it all happens across huge amounts of land. Fox Sports broadcast of its first U.S. Open last year wasnt perfect by any means, but all things considered, it wasnt bad.

But changes are abound ahead of this years tournament, and one of the most notable is the firing of commentator Greg Norman and replaced with Paul Azinger. Azinger is more experienced and, frankly, just a better fit. It wasnt all bad during his inaugural broadcast  he did some especially good work following Jason Days collapse with vertigo  but his fate was effectively sealed at the end of the tournament: Dustin Johnson lost to Jordan Spieth after a brutal choke, and rather than offer anything in the way of personal analysis from a man who has succumbed to that fate many times himself, Norman was unrelentingly bland.

Norman doesnt see it that way, though. Speaking with Golf.com, the two-time major champion said he was blindsided by the decision:

We had, quite honestly, incredible pre-game meetings, post-game meetings, and there was never any indication that I was going to get the boot up my butt, so it came as a total surprise to me. And the reasons for it are just so off base. They called me unpredictable. Thats basically the reason why they let me go.

Norman says he was handcuffed by not being allowed to do certain segments and said he was extremely well prepared:

Rating Five Golden Stars on Blackboard (Photo: phototechno, Getty Images/iStockphoto)

Many shoppers rely on reviews, but a lot of those reviews are written by biased "customers" who shouldn't be trusted.

Deal expert Matt Granite has found a free and easy tool to help shoppers weed out fake reviews.

Watch the video above for details and follow @MattGranite for more money-saving tips.

Matt Granite is a consumer reporter with WKYC in Cleveland. His videos offer tips to consumers on how to save money.

column3: Family says church didnt help disabled girl see brother play basketball
column4: ['Cam Smith', 'Smith Iii', 'Detroit Free Press', 'Jim Halley', 'Wtsmith Greenvillenews Com', 'Lthompson Gannett Com', 'Mick Mccabe', 'Luke Thompson', 'Usa Today High School Sports', 'Kaitlyn S Ross Wxia']
column5:
A Decatur, Ga., family cannot understand why a church will not help their disabled daughter get inside, especially to the basketball courts to watch her brother play.

Zoe, a 7-year-old, uses a wheelchair and her mother told TEGNA partner WXIA that she thinks the church could fix it at no cost, but they refuse to help.

It isnt getting inside the church thats a problem  its getting down to the basketball courts.

Her brother plays every week, although the season recently ended. Zoe loves to watch the games, her mother said she is being purposefully left out.

Zoe lights up when she sees her older brother.

Her brother just walked down the stairs, and this is her reaction, her mother said. And this is how she is when she sees him playing. She gets excited when she sees him!

But she hasnt been able to see him play.

His games are at the Clairmont Presbyterian gymnasium and Zoes mom, Anu, said the main entrance is inaccessible.

It seems like all we have been getting are a number of excuses, she said. And dancing around the issue rather than actually trying to come up with a solution.

In a statement, the church said they have tried to accommodate Zoe and they are working on improving accessibility to their gym for future events.

While Zoe cant get down the stairs in her wheelchair, Anu said theres a side door to the gym that the church could easily leave open. But theyve refused.

Im not asking for any money to be spent  any construction  but Im asking that they just unlock a door for us to get in, the girls mother said.

I can handle it, but its disrespectful to Zoe, Anu said. Shes a person, not one person from the organization has even acknowledged Zoe through all of this. So its really  its been very frustrating.

Documenting her frustration on Zoes Facebook page, Anu said that of all places, a church should be willing to help her daughter.

Especially at a place thats supposed to be welcoming, loving and accepting  its felt quite the opposite for us, she said.

And she said Zoe is the one who misses out.

She just wants to go watch her brother play a basketball game, Anu said. And its almost as if shes being denied that right to do so.

Anu said she will keep fighting for accessibility so other people will be able to get in and enjoy.

column3: Cleveland in on Colin Kaepernick
column5:
Updating previous reports, San Francisco 49ers QB Colin Kaepernick is the chief trade target of the Denver Broncos.

Tip: It looks like CK is Denver's No. 1 choice to replace Brock Osweiler and Peyton Manning in 2016. Kaepernick is coming off a terrible year that also ended in injury, so he won't be highly coveted in fall drafts. There is upside if he can stay healthy in an offense that could suit his strengths, but Kap is nothing more than a midrange fantasy backup for now.

column3: Will the Dallas Mavericks make the playoffs?
column5:
Mar 1, 2016; Dallas, TX, USA; Dallas Mavericks forward Chandler Parsons (25) and forward Dirk Nowitzki (41) celebrate during the second half against the Orlando Magic at the American Airlines Center. The Mavericks defeat the Magic 121-108. Mandatory Credit: Jerome Miron-USA TODAY Sports (Photo: Jerome Miron, Jerome Miron-USA TODAY Sports)

With a little more than a month to go in the NBA regular season, we take a look at the teams fighting for their playoff lives.

Record: 33-32

Standing: No. 7 in Western Conference

Will make postseason if: They play defense.

The Mavericks are currently on a four-game skid, a half game ahead of the eighth place Houston Rockets. With the Memphis Grizzlies' five and a half games ahead of the pack and holding firm to the fifth place spot, the Mavs' destiny lies somewhere in between. But with the Golden State Warriors and San Antonio Spurs destined for a Western Conference Finals battle, the difference between the sixth and eighth spot is pivotal. What can help propel a run at the sixth spot while preventing a drop to eighth or lower? Defense.

The Mavericks have held their opponents to less than 100 points 24 times this season. They have won 20 of those games. In their 33 total wins, they have held opponents to 97.2 points per game on 42.5% shooting. In losses, those numbers divert to 108.4 points allowed at a 47.5% clip. While their offense has proven to have enough firepower to knock off some of the league's top teams, winning games on the defensive end of the floor could make all the difference, especially with the Warriors, Portland Trail Blazers (back-to-back), Sacramento Kings, Cleveland Cavaliers, and Los Angeles Clippers  all top 10 scoring teams  still remaining on the schedule.

Will miss postseason if: They continue to play down to their opponents.

Ten of the Mavs' 32 losses on the season have come against teams that aren't currently in the playoff picture. Most recently, it was back-to-back losses against the Kings at home and the Nuggets in Denver, followed by a loss to the Detroit Pistons. Their remaining schedule is far from a cakewalk, with 11 of their 17 games against current playoff teams. While those games are essential, it's the matchups with the Pistons (April 1), Kings (March 27), Nuggets (March 28), New York Knicks (March 30), Minnesota Timberwolves (April 3), and Utah Jazz (April 11) that could very well determine the Mavs' postseason fate.

Wild card: David Lee.

Lee wasn't much of a factor during his 30 games with the Boston Celtics this season, but the veteran big man has found new life since joining the Mavericks recently. Dallas is 3-5 since the acquisition and Lee is getting comfortable with his new role, but his numbers have skyrocketed across the board since the switch, and he has the potential to make a strong impact.

Being able to deploy Lee as a second option adds some much-needed depth to the rotation of bigs and takes some weight off Zaza Pachulia's shoulders, who  in 50 games without Lee  averaged the most minutes per game of his career since the 2005-06 season. In the eight games since, his minutes have dropped from 29.6 to 20.8, while Lee's have risen 15.7 to 19.6. Mavericks coach Rick Carlisle is fortunate enough to have two starting centers on his roster, and you have to trust that he will find a way to make it work.

Our next team up: Jazz.

Follow AJ Neuharth-Keusch on Twitter @tweetAJNK

column3: Amazonian oil disaster disrupts one of worlds most bio-diverse places
column5:
Donald Moncayo, activist and member of the Union of Affected People by Chevron in Ecuador, shows oil under the ground in the Amazonia rainforest. (Photo: Kamilia Lahrichi for USA TODAY)

AMAZONIA, Ecuador  Indigenous communities in the Amazonian rainforest believe that nature has a spirit.

Trees, flowers and plants have as much importance as human lives in Ecuadors rainforest, thought to be the most biologically diverse place on the planet.

To take down a tree is like killing a grandfather, said Humberto Javier Piaguaje Lucitante, an indigenous leader from the Secoya tribe living in the town of Lago Agrio, at the edge of the Amazonia.

As he makes his way through the humid jungle with a silver stick, he explains that nature is an ancient wealth for locals.

For indigenous tribes in Ecuador's Amazonia, nature has a spirit. (Photo: Kamilia Lahrichi for USA TODAY)

Things started to change in the 1960s, when oil operations kicked off.

Today, Ecuador has the worst environmental record in South America, according to Mongabay, a U.S.-based news website covering the environment.

Oil exploration, logging, and road building have had a disastrous impact on Ecuador's primary rainforests, which now cover less than 15% of the country's land mass, Mongabay reported.

The Latin American country has been the battleground between indigenous and environmentalist groups, on one side, and governments and corporations drilling for oil into the Amazonia, on the other, in a legal wrangling of great international sprawl.

For almost two decades, Ecuadorian lawyers and activists have sued Chevron, the second largest oil company in the U.S., for allegedly dumping billions of gallons of crude residue into looms and waterways that locals drink.

The plaintiffs speak for about 30,000 indigenous people.

Although Chevron never operated in Ecuador, the subsidiary it acquired in 2001, Texaco Petroleum, did for 30 years.

In the latest twist, the International Court of Justice noted in January 2016 that the Ecuadorian government was responsible for freeing Texaco Petroleum from liability for oil pollution claims when it left Ecuador in 1992. The government certified that the oil company had carried out a cleanup of oil production sites.

Chevron applauded the decision.

The oil giant has called the lawsuit a fraud and pointed to the unethical action by the plaintiffs lawyers. If they win the case, they could collect $9.5 billion in damages for environmental contamination  Ecuadors Supreme Court ordered it in 2012.

Had the oil spill occurred in the U.S., it could have proceeded much faster because it would not have involved a trip to the courts of another country, said Michael Gerrard, a professor, who teaches a course on environmental law, at Columbia Law School.

For indigenous communities in Ecuador, the class suit is about justice rather than money.

We live in a paradise and we do not want to keep seeing it being destroyed, said Bartholome Baptista Chiwango Parilia, a Kichwa leader living in Yacuma, about an hour-drive from the city Tena, in Ecuadors eastern province, and a 30-minute trip on a canoe through the rainforest.

There is a shared feeling among indigenous tribes that the high-stake lawsuit is a David and Goliath fight.

Many among the indigenous tribes throw the responsibility on both governments and oil corporations.

All governments in Latin America are corrupted, said Parilia, as he paddled slowly. None of them are fair.

In another part of the Amazonia, about two-hour drive from El Coca city, the farmer Jose Aveiga showed an oil well that the Ecuadorian government drilled on what he said is his land to extract crude, without asking permission.

Ecuadorian farmer Jose Aveiga shows an oil well that the government drilled without permission on what he says is his land. (Photo: Kamilia Lahrichi for USA TODAY)

For the past 15 years, he has been embattled in a legal fight with the state to get rid of the well. It has decimated the plants and livestock around, explains Aveiga, as he showed large areas of oil spills on the ground.

Crude oil has prevented me from producing and my plants are dying because of oil contamination, he said.

I feel sickened. Do you know how many animals I have lost here? I have lost pigs and chickens, he told USA TODAY.

In the end, if the plaintiffs in the Chevron case win the long-lasting class suit, it would empower indigenous tribes as well as civil society organizations across the globe to fight oil corporations  such as BP, which spilled over 200 million gallons of crude oil into the Gulf of Mexico in 2010.

Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/1paRQpf

column3: DeMarco Murray feels fresh after light workload in Philly
column5:
(Photo: The Associated Press)

NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP)  DeMarco Murray says he feels fresh after a much lighter workload than he wanted last season in Philadelphia, and he can't wait to get to work with the Titans after doing his own research about Tennessee.

Murray said Thursday that he feels good and fresh, though not by his own choice.

The NFL's 2014 rushing leader finds himself with a new team for a second straight season after the Eagles traded him to Tennessee, and Murray signed a new contract with the Titans on Wednesday.

General manager Jon Robinson says this is just the start of the change coming for a team 5-27 the past two seasons.

The Titans also confirmed deals for Texans center Ben Jones, Miami wide receiver Rishard Matthews and veteran quarterback Matt Cassell.

column3: Who's in, who's out of the NCAA tournament?
column5:
USA TODAY Sports' Scott Gleeson breaks down who's in and out days from Selection Sunday. USA TODAY Sports

Syracuse Orange head coach Jim Boeheim gestures from the bench against the Pittsburgh Panthers in the second half during day two of the ACC conference tournament at Verizon Center. The Panthers won 72-71. (Photo: Geoff Burke, USA TODAY Sports)

Examining the 20 remaining NCAA tournament bubble teams' resumes, conference-by-conference, heading into Selection Sunday.

Results/records are shown are against Division I opponents only.

Removed from consideration: Houston.

Breakdown data as of March 10.

 Locks: Cincinnati

 Probable: N/A

 Bubble: UConn, Temple, Tulsa

In for now

UConn: 21-10 (11-7), 60 RPI, 56 SoS, 104 non-conference SoS

The Good: Wins vs. Texas, Tulsa, SMU The Bad: No bad losses to date

 Needs to do: Win against Cincinnati in the AAC tournament and Huskies are probably safe.

Tulsa: 20-10 (12-6), 50 RPI, 55 SoS, 101 non-conference SoS

The Good: Wins vs. Wichita State, UConn, SMU, Temple The Bad: Losses vs. Oral Roberts, Memphis

 Needs to do: Two wins in the AAC tournament and the Golden Hurricane might be safe.

Temple: 20-10 (14-4), 59 RPI, 62 SoS, 75 non-conference SoS

The Good: Wins vs. SMU, UConn (twice), Tulsa The Bad: Losses vs. East Carolina, Memphis

 Needs: Cant afford a loss against East Carolina/South Florida winner in AAC tourney.

 Locks: Virginia, North Carolina, Miami, Notre Dame, Duke, Pittsburgh

 Probable: N/A

 Bubble: Syracuse

Syracuse: 19-13 (9-9), 67 RPI, 37 SoS, 109 non-conference SoS

The Good: Wins vs. Texas A&M, Duke, Notre Dame, St. Bonaventure, UConn, Florida State The Bad: Loss vs. St.Johns, Georgetown, Clemson

 Needs: The Orange wait and hope other bubble teams lose so that they maybe they can back their way in.

 Locks: N/A

 Probable: Dayton

 Bubble: St. Bonaventure, St. Joseph's, VCU, George Washington

In for now

St. Bonaventure: 22-7 (14-4), 27 RPI, 82 SoS, 166 non-conference SoS

The Good: Wins vs. St. Josephs (twice), Davidson, George Washington, Dayton The Bad: Losses vs. Siena, Duquesne, LaSalle

 Needs: One win in the A-10 tournament might be enough; two should do it for sure.

St. Josephs: 24-7 (13-5), 29 RPI, 76 SoS, 71 non-conference SoS

The Good: Wins vs. Dayton, Princeton, Temple, George Washington The Bad: Losses vs. Duquesne

 Needs: One win in the A-10 tournament might be enough; two might be needed.

VCU: 22-9 (14-4), 40 RPI, 68 SoS, 59 non-conference SoS

The Good: Wins vs. St. Bonaventure, St. Josephs, George Washington, Davidson (twice) The Bad: Losses vs. Massachusetts, George Mason

 Needs: One win in the A-10 tournament might be enough; two should do it for sure.

Out for now

George Washington: 22-9 (11-7), 62 RPI, 101 SoS, 208 non-conference SoS

The Good: Wins vs. Virginia, Seton Hall, VCU, Davidson The Bad: Losses vs. DePaul, Richmond, St.Louis

 Needs: Probably need to get to the tourney final, beating St.Josephs and Dayton along the way. If Dayton loses, then GW probably needs to win the tournament. A first game loss and the Colonials sit and wait for disappointment.

 Locks: Villanova, Xavier, Seton Hall, Providence, Butler

 Probable: N/A

 Bubble: N/A

 Locks: Iowa, Michigan State, Maryland, Purdue, Indiana, Wisconsin

 Probable: N/A

 Bubble: Michigan, Ohio State

Out for now

Michigan: 19-11 (10-8), 68 RPI, 58 SoS, 184 non-conference SoS

The Good: Wins vs. Maryland, Texas, Purdue The Bad: No bad losses to date

 Needs: Cannot afford an opening-round loss in the Big Ten tournament. Two wins might get Wolverines in, three probably will.

Ohio State: 19-12 (11-7), 76 RPI, 46 SoS, 98 non-conference SoS

The Good: Win vs. Kentucky, Michigan, Iowa The Bad: Losses vs. Texas-Arlington, Memphis, Louisiana Tech

 Needs: Probably need to win at least three in the Big Ten tournament, beating high RPI teams. An early loss ends hope.

 Locks: Oklahoma, Kansas, Iowa State, West Virginia, Texas, Baylor, Texas Tech

 Probable: N/A

 Bubble: N/A

 Locks: Oregon, USC, Utah. Arizona, California, Colorado

 Probable: Oregon State

 Bubble: Washington

Washington: 18-13 (9-9) 79 RPI, 34 SoS, 120 non-conference SoS

The Good: Wins vs. USC, Texas, Colorado The Bad: Loss vs. Oakland, UCSB

 Needs: Beat Oregon and the Huskies are in the mix, one more win vs. Arizona or Colorado might be enough.

 Locks: Texas A&M, Kentucky

 Probable: South Carolina

 Bubble: Vanderbilt, Florida, Alabama

In for now

Vanderbilt: 19-12 (11-7), 51 RPI, 27 SoS, 27 non-conference SoS

The Good: Wins vs. Texas A&M, Florida (twice), Alabama, Stony Brook, Kentucky The Bad: Loss vs. Arkansas, Mississippi State

 Needs: Cannot afford a loss to Tennessee. Win that and the Commodores are probably safe. Win against LSU and they're are in.

Out for now

Florida: 18-13 (9-9), 58 RPI, 18 SoS, 7 non-conference SoS

The Good: Wins vs. West Virginia, St. Josephs The Bad: Loss vs. Tennessee

 Needs: Must beat Arkansas in SEC tourney opener. A win vs. Texas A&M helps a great deal, a loss and they need help

Alabama: 17-13 (8-10), 73 RPI, 39 SoS, 25 non-conference SoS

The Good: Wins vs. South Carolina, Notre Dame, Wichita State, Texas A&M, Florida The Bad: Loss vs. Auburn, Mississippi State, Arkansas

 Needs: A loss against Ole Miss in the SEC tournament opener ends hope. A win and then a win against Kentucky might be enough. If the Tide lose, they need help.

If teams do not win their conference tournament to secure auto-bid.

 Locks: N/A

 Probable: N/A

 Bubble: Monmouth, Wichita State, San Diego State, Valparaiso, St. Mary's, Little Rock

In for now

Monmouth: 27-7 (17-3), 55 RPI, 164 SoS, 97 non-conference SoS

The Good: Wins vs. USC, Notre Dame, UCLA, Georgetown, Iona The Bad: Losses vs. Canisius, Army, Manhattan

 Needs: The Hawks have to hope the committee values a solid non-conference slate; many of those teams didnt turn out to be as good as expected, but they sure tried.

Wichita State: 23-8 (16-2), 47 RPI, 100 SoS, 10 non-conference SoS

The Good: Win vs. Utah, Northern Iowa The Bad: Loss vs. Illinois State

 Needs: The Shockers need other bubble teams to lose so they can stay in as they have no more games to play to help themselves.

San Diego State: 21-8 (16-2), 42 RPI, 72 SoS, 2 NonCon SoS

The Good: Win vs. California The Bad: Losses vs. Grand Canyon, San Diego, Fresno State, Boise State

 Needs: Another team that is relying on other teams to lose. A run to the MWC final will help the Aztecs case but will be tense on Selection Sunday if they lose early.

Out for now

Valparaiso: 24-6 (16-2) 53 RPI, 161 SoS, 51 non-conference SoS

The Good: Win vs. Oregon State The Bad: Losses vs. Wright State (twice), Ball State, Green Bay

 Needs: Need many bubble teams to lose for any hope

St. Marys: 26-5 (15-3) 36 RPI, 147 SoS, 161 non-conference SoS

The Good: Win vs. Gonzaga (twice) The Bad: Loss vs. Pepperdine (twice)

 Needs: The Gaels have little that is impressive on their profile besides their record. They need other bubble teams to lose.

Little Rock: 25-4 (17-3), 52 RPI, 245 SoS, 276 non-conference SoS

The Good: Win vs. Tulsa, San Diego State The Bad: Losses vs. Louisiana-Monroe, Arkansas State, Appalachian State

 Needs: If they get to the conference tourney final, then the Trojans will be in the discussion, but they need other bubble teams to lose

***

Note: All RPI and statistical data is used from WarrenNolan.com.

About our bracketologist: Shelby Mast has been projecting the field since 2005 and has finished as one of the top 5 national bracketologists for his website, Bracket W.A.G. Hes predicted for The Indianapolis Star, collegeinsider.com and is an inaugural member of the Super 10 Selection Committee. Follow him on Twitter @BracketWag.

column3: U.S. market reaction to Greek crisis is critical
column5:
Its not surprising that stocks fell sharply in Asia and Europe to kick off the trading week after Greece shuttered its banks after debt talks broke down. Whats key, however, is how Wall Street reacts.

In pre-market trading, U.S. stocks are down about 1.2%, which is less than the declines in early trading in Europe and losses suffered overnight in Asia.

Indeed, how Wall Street reacts to the mounting crisis in Greece and the rising odds of a Greek exit from the 19-nation eurozone could provide investors with a better sense of how vulnerable markets are.

The U.S. is still the most important market, says Axel Merk, chief investment officer at Merk Investments.

GLOBAL STOCKS: Markets plunge as Greece closes banks and debt talks falter

IN GREECE: Debt crisis scares some, but welcomed by others

The fact that stocks in Germany and France are down around 3% and the Shanghai composite index fell another 3.3% to officially enter bear market territory was pretty much expected, as many investors had bet that a deal would get done between Greece and the institutions that lent them bailout money. But that didnt happen. For now, markets are waiting for developments to unfold, with Greek banks and its stock market closed for at least a week, as the Greeks are set to vote Sunday July 5 on whether to accept creditors austere bailout terms.

About three hours before the opening bell on Wall Street, U.S. stock futures are down, but not by a massive amount. To say U.S. stocks are plunging in pre-market trading would be an overstatement.

The Dow Jones industrial average is down about 200 points, which equates to a drop of 1.2%, which cant be considered a plunge. Similarly, the benchmark Standard & Poors 500-stock index, a better gauge of the broad U.S. market, is down by a similar amount.

Thats not to say the trading day wont have a fair share of turbulence. However, if Wall Street trades calmly, as it appears now, and losses dont accelerate, it could act as a calming influence on world markets on a difficult day.

Most of the Wall Street experts USA TODAY spoke with dont expect a massive downdraft in the U.S. stock market. Merk, for example, says while stocks are vulnerable in the U.S., Greece would simply be a catalyst to sell.

U.S. stocks, of course, are still trading near record highs, and by at least one valuation metric, the price-to-earnings ratio, the market is overvalued relative to history.

Bill Hornbarger, chief investment strategist at the Moneta Group, said late Sunday night that he expects markets to be lower today, but added that the drop in the U.S. wont be too severe.

The reason: a break down in bailout talks between Greece was never ruled out entirely by Wall Street.

This has always been a possibility, says Hornbarger.

What the markets want is a clear-cut resolution, one way or the other. And that day of reckoning is coming closer.

The markets will like some clarity, says Hornbarger.

What markets hate is uncertainty, adds Mark Luschini, chief investment strategist at Janney. And not knowing if Greece will stay in the euro or exit the 19-nation economic and political group creates a lot of angst.

The uncertainty about the payment, let alone the surprise from (Greek Prime Minister Alexis) Tsipras to stage a referendum, is enough to create increased uncertainty as to whether Greece leaves the euro, he says.

But, for now, he doesnt see a massive swoon in the U.S. stock market, which will be viewed as a haven of sorts. Whats more, the final chapter in the Greek drama has yet to play out as the referendum is six days away.

I dont think it will be a severe selloff since nothing conclusive comes today, says Luschini. And Europe is renown for moving to solve their issues only after a market riot.

column3: Khiry Robinson joining Jets

The New York Jets could target Houston Texans QB Brian Hoyer if they arent able to trade for San Francisco 49ers QB Colin Kaepernick.

Tip: Hoyer would be a last-ditch effort for the Jets if they can't re-sign Ryan Fitzpatrick or trade for Kap. Hoyer is more of a game manager behind center and would have very little fantasy value. If he came to the Jets, it would also hurt the fantasy values of Brandon Marshall and Eric Decker.

column3: Rutgers fires Eddie Jordan, ending painful tenure
column5:
Rutgers honors the 1975-76 Mens basketball Final Four team. STAFF VIDEO BY MARK R. SULLIVAN

The favorite son inherited a train wreck and could not get it back on track, for a variety of reasons.

Eddie Jordan won just 29 games in three seasons at Rutgers. (Photo: Mel Evans, AP)

Eddie Jordans three-year tenure as Rutgers mens basketball coach, which started as a feel-good story about a favorite sons return home, ended Thursday after a painful string of losing.

Athletics director Pat Hobbs, a hoops-savvy guy hired in November to clean up a department in disarray, fired Jordan as was widely anticipated. According to Jordans five-year contract, Rutgers owes him $2 million for the final two years. Thats 70 percent of what he would make if he stayed on.

The Scarlet Knights finished 7-25 overall and 1-17 in the Big Ten, marking the programs lowest winning percentage since 1956. They endured a club-record 17-game losing streak and suffered 32 straight Big Ten defeats dating back to last season.

WHO WILL REPLACE JORDAN? Take a look at our short list

Jordans record ended up at 29-67. As the search for his successor begins, all eyes turn toward Dan Hurley, a brand-name Jersey guy who rebuilt Wagner and Rhode Island. Hobbs last mens basketball coaching search, at Seton Hall, produced Kevin Willard, who is enjoying a breakthrough campaign of 22-8 in his sixth season.

Rutgers head coach Eddie Jordan, center, saw a lot of losses in three years. (Photo: Mel Evans, AP)

Whoever the next Rutgers coach is, he will enter a situation better than the one Jordan inherited. A point guard on Rutgers 1976 Final Four team, Jordan served as an NBA head coach for three different franchises before returning home to put out the fire that raged after former coach Mike Rices tumultuous departure.

He restocked a depleted roster in his first few months, but the Scarlet Knights finished 2014 with a 12-21 mark after a 92-31 loss to Louisville in the American Athletic Conference Tournament. In year two Rutgers, debuting in the Big Ten, went 10-22 overall and 2-16 in the league, ending with a 15-game losing streak after an upset of fourth-ranked Wisconsin.

RELATED: Jordan: I'm proud of what we've done

This season Rutgers suffered a rash of injuries, often fielding just seven scholarship players, and its two best players served disciplinary suspensions. A 17-game losing streak eclipsed the program record of 16 set in 1987-88.

Jordan's main accomplishment: Getting his degree (and his players getting them too). (Photo: File photo)

Jordan has said, with merit, that his primary charge was to heal a program that was broken in Rices wake. At the time, respected Notre Dame head coach Mike Brey called for it to be shut down and TV camera crews roamed the dorms trying to corner mortified players for interviews.

Upon hiring Jordan, Rutgers president Robert Barchi touted the coachs devotion to our universitys values and our commitment to promoting an atmosphere of respect and dignity for everyone.

In that sense, Jordan did the job. For the most part, his players performed well in the classroom and handled themselves well off the court. They emulated the skipper, who earned his bachelors degree while coaching the team and remained likable despite the mounting losses; Rutgers fans declined to boo him at games, as opposed to the way they rained jeers on embattled Rutgers football coach Kyle Flood in the fall.

Athletics director Pat Hobbs has led hoops searches before. (Photo: File photo)

Jordan also had to contend with institutional drawbacks, from hopelessly antiquated facilities to a naturally awkward conference fit to athletic department leadership that, prior to Hobbs hiring, was an industry punchline.

A salient example of the dysfunction: The RAC still lacks air conditioning, two years after its installment was approved.

That said, Jordan struggled to adjust to the college game, from recruiting presence to defensive tactics.

It all added up to a perfect storm of losing, an epic pileup that was too much to overcome, even for a favorite son.

column3: Still talent left to be signed
column5:
USA TODAY Sports breaks down the biggest deals on a busy first day of free agency. USA TODAY Sports

Ryan Fitzpatrick (Photo: ASSOCIATED PRESS)

The majority of the NFL's most coveted free agents have already been snapped up. But there are still a handful of notable names available as the market heads into its second day.

1. DE Robert Ayers: With a career-best 9.5 sacks for the New York Giants in 2015, his market is heating up with the other marquee pass rushers already signed (for big money) and the draft devoid of any that look like immediate impact players.

2. T Russell Okung: He never developed into the next Walter Jones for the Seattle Seahawks  an unfair comparison by definition  and required shoulder surgery after dislocating it in the playoffs. Still, don't expect him to be out of work long, even has he attempts to negotiate his own deal.

3. QB Ryan Fitzpatrick: He's suddenly a more intriguing commodity now that Brock Osweiler has been claimed by the Houston Texans. Though Fitzpatrick seems a natural fit for the New York Jets, for whom he had a career year in 2015, no reason for him not to do some exploratory research to gauge his value.

4. CB Brent Grimes: Released by the Miami Dolphins on Wednesday, he should find encounter decent market. Grimes has only missed one game over the past three seasons and has been named to the Pro Bowl in all of them. But his outspoken wife could be a red flag for some teams.

5. S Eric Weddle: An all-pro in 2014, he slumped last year while dealing with injuries and what seemed like season-long divorce proceedings from the San Diego Chargers. Still, Weddle is an accomplished veteran at a position that could be tough to fill via free agency or the draft.

6. DT Nick Fairley: Theres little question about his talent, though hes certainly looked even better while playing on star-studded lines for the Lions and Rams. Fairley has had off-field issues and his motor hasnt always run hot.

7. CB Casey Hayward: His ability to play in the slot could make him a more attractive option to some teams than a big corner like Smith.

8. G Louis Vasquez: His skill set was no longer a fit in Denver, but expect the former all-pro to have more than a few offers to sift through.

9. S Reggie Nelson: It took a while for the 2007 first rounder to hit his stride, but he's coming off his first Pro Bowl season after tying for the league lead with eight interceptions. Nelson's age (32) is the only thing holding him back from a bigger deal.

10. TE Zach Miller: After missing three seasons due to injury, he proved to be playmaker in 2015 for the Chicago Bears, catching 34 passes for 439 yards despite splitting targets with Martellus Bennett.

11. WR Mohamed Sanu: He's only averaged 38 catches during his four-year career. Still, quality wideouts are in short supply, and the draft pipeline doesn't look overly promising this year, either. Bonus: Sanu's rocket arm will allow offensive coordinators to have some nice trick plays in their arsenal. He visited Falcons Wednesday night and is scheduled to visit Patriots on Thursday.

Follow Nate Davis on Twitter @ByNateDavis

column3: 16 stellar stocks are out of this world
column5:
Now that weve finally seen Pluto  some investors might want to see whether they can grab a piece of space for themselves.

NASA and SpaceX dont trade on a stock exchange, but there are other ways to try to invest in interstellar exploration. Elon Musks SpaceX is well known. Its also a privately held company. But there are at least 16 publicly traded ways to play various aspects of space exploration, aerospace technology or related launch systems, including Aerojet Rocketdyne (AJRD), Orbital ATK (OK) and Boeing (BA), just to name a few. Enthusiasm over space exploration and launch systems has certainly spread to Wall Street. A custom equal-weighted index of the 16 moonshot shots is out of this world this year, rising 13.4%. That makes the Standard & Poors 500 roughly 2% gain this year look downright grounded.

Its important to note these companies are included because theyve been named in company filings by key space companies, to be competitors in the industry. That doesnt mean theyre directly involved in the Pluto missions. These companies make components or systems that can be used in space or propulsion systems that could find applications if interest in exploration continues to grow. Some make products for flow control or lifts primarily used in other industries that also have applications in aerospace.

These companies do have one thing in common. Analysts see upside in the shares of all of the stocks (the only exception is Airbus, only because there is no U.S. consensus estimate available). Not many industries have so much universal enthusiasm.

Analysts are most bullish on Kratos Defense & Security, which is more of a play on war than on space exploration. The company has a business unit that focuses on unmanned systems.

That includes sensors, avionics and electronic parts that find their way into aerospace systems. Shares are already up 22% this year to close Thursday at $6.12 a share. Analysts say this stock could be worth $8.50 a share in 18 months, which if correct, is 39% upside.

Perhaps the best known and most direct way to play space exploration is Orbital ATK. Orbital touches the space and avionics business with three of its business units: flight systems, defense systems and space systems. Orbitals flight systems unit builds rockets for midsize space vehicles primarily to place satellites in orbit. Shares have been stellar, rising 34% this year. Despite that gain, analysts remain bullish. The stock, which closed at $73.41 Thursday, could be worth nearly 19% more in 18 months if the average analyst is correct, S&P Capital IQ says.

Of course, its important to note that space exploration is risky business. Even Musks own SpaceX has had its fair share of costly mishaps.

But just take a close look at those pictures of Pluto. Maybe youll find a way to profit the next time our telescopes whiz by.

column3: Ford upgrades bulletproofing in police cars
column5:
A Michigan State Police officer shoots at the doors of a Ford Police Interceptor Utility vehicle during ballistic testing of doors against small arm fire at the Livingston Conservation and Sports Association in Brighton, Mich. Ford will soon be offering doors on its Police Interceptor sedans and SUVs that can protect against armor-piercing bullets. (Photo: Ryan Koehler, AP)

In a sign of the times, Ford Motor says it upgrading protection in the doors of its police cruisers to defend against armor-piercing bullets.

With a greater danger that assailants will use high-powered or assault rifles with rounds that can easily punch through cars doors, Ford officials say it's an improvement that police departments have been seeking.

"Officers globally told us they needed protection from armor-piercing ammunition and we added ballistic protection to an already great product," said Arie Groeneveld, chief engineer for Ford's police car lineup.

Ford is a leading maker of police pursuit vehicles. After dominating the market for years with its Crown Victoria sedan, many departments have embraced the police version of its Ford Explorer SUV.

Entry holes through the outer skin of the door panel of a Ford Police Interceptor Utility vehicle during ballistic testing of doors against small arms fire (Photo: Ryan Koehler, AP)

column3: Spider-Man steals the show in new 'Captain America: Civil War' trailer
column5:
Steve Rogers (Chris Evans) has to tread carefully everywhere he goes in 'Captain America: Civil War.' (Photo: Zade Rosenthal)

Friends battle friends and it's hero vs. hero in the new Captain America: Civil War trailer.

On Team Cap, who prefers not to have the government run the Avengers: Captain America, Falcon, Hawkeye, Scarlet Witch, Ant-Man and the Winter Soldier (aka Cap's old BFF Bucky Barnes).

On Team Iron Man, who's cool with not having as much freedom to go around saving the world willy-nilly: Iron Man, War Machine, Black Widow, Vision and Black Panther.

And ... oh hey, look out! Here comes the Spider-Man!

Yeah, let's look at that Spidey moment one more time.

CASUAL.

The movie is set to hit theaters on May 6.

column3: Why this big bank has okayed jeans, scooters and Foosball at work
column5:
A sign at One Chase Plaza in lower Manhattan on Oct. 14, 2014, in New York City. (Photo: Spencer Platt, Getty Images)

NEW YORK-- As more banking activities move online, JPMorgan Chase & Co. is shedding its pinstriped suits and stodgy offices in a bid to win over coders and engineers.

JPMorgan, the nation's largest bank by assets, opened a digital hub in Manhattan's Hudson Yards neighborhood in December to house 700 tech workers. Unlike its more traditional Park Ave., headquarters, the digital team is allowed to wear jeans, ride around the office on scooters, and play Foosball and XBOX at work.

If that sounds a lot like tech giant Google, it's because it is. Executives with the digital team talked to executives at Google, Amazon and other tech companies about how to best design the space to spur innovation, said James Young, the chief information officer for the bank's digital unit.

What they came up with was three football fields of open-floor space that is designed to encourage casual meetings and brainstorming sessions. "There are more seats away from desk than at desks," said Young. "We don't want people spending their day looking at email," he said.

For Mario Pedernera, a program manager, the new space has given way to "democracy with a lowercase 'd.'" It encourages workers "fresh out of college" to share ideas with the team's top executives at open-space meetings, he said.

The move highlights the emphasis the bank is putting on online and mobile banking, including plans later this year for Chase Pay, a digital payment system that will compete with Apple Pay, Android Pay and Samsung Pay. Like its Silicon Valley competitors, Chase Pay will let people use their phones to pay for things in stores and restaurants. The new digital wallet is also expected to let customers use their Chase log-in information to buy things on third-party web sites.

On Thursday, Chase launched a redesign of its retail banking web site, chase.com as part of its on-going effort to service and encourage the move away from bank branches.

*Contributing: Edward C. Baig.

Follow USA TODAY reporter Kaja Whitehouse on Twitter: @kajawhitehouse

Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/1piEFTQ

column3: Rutgers fires Eddie Jordan, ending painful tenure
column5:
Rutgers honors the 1975-76 Mens basketball Final Four team. STAFF VIDEO BY MARK R. SULLIVAN

The favorite son inherited a train wreck and could not get it back on track, for a variety of reasons.
