column3: Student wants Justin Bieber to say 'sorry' for uses wrong verb form in song
TV show power rankings; Downton Abbey takes the No. 1 spot
column4: ['Hemal Jhaveri', 'Ted Berg', 'Charles Curtis', 'Luke Kerr-dineen', 'Nate Scott', 'Nina Mandell', 'Laken Litman', "Nate Scott Is A Writer Editor At Ftw Leading The Site's Culture Coverage He Likes Writing About Soccer Basketball Music Tv The Evils Of The Ocean"]
column5:
Here it is, a brand spanking new feature: A weekly power ranking of the 25 most vital shows currently on TV.

How am I judging it? The criteria is murky, though it factors in ratings, command of the zeitgeist, and quality. Basically: Are people watching it? Are people talking about it? And is it any good?

My own critical input is obviously a factor, but Im not going to put a show I personally love in the top spot every week, or else wed just have Match of the Day and Its Always Sunny In Philadelphia alternating as the winner indefinitely. Also, it has to be airing new episodes. Also, Im excluding news programming. Its all vital and important and shouldnt be held up to or compared to The Voice.

Here they are:

1. Downton Abbey (PBS)

Downton Abbey starts and ends its time in the FTW weekly TV power rankings No. 1 spot. Did most of us stop watching the show after that (spoiler alert) handsome blond dude beefed it? Yes, yes we did. But the loyal hangers on got to say their goodbyes this week, and in honor of that, we hand it the crown. Goodbye, sweet Downton. I always liked that dog in the opening credits.

2. American Crime Story: The People vs. O.J. Simpson (FX)

The best show on television as far as Im concerned. The dramatic look back at the O.J. Simpson trial started as a slightly kitschy nostalgia party with a miscast lead and WAY too much Kardashian kids, but man, this show gets better and better every week.

Once the show shifted focus from David Schwimmer and Cuba Gooding Jr. (as Robert Kardashian and O.J. Simpson, respectively) and realized the heart of the show was with Sterling K. Brown, Sarah Paulson and Courtney B. Vance (playing Christopher Garden, Marcia Clark and Johnny Cochran) the whole thing took off. Twenty years ago, I thought I never wanted to see another minute of the O.J. Simpson trial. I was wrong.

3. The Bachelor (ABC)

From my colleague Luke Kerr-Dineen, who at first claimed he didnt watch the show before sheepishly admitting that he watched the show:

The self-regenerating reality show never fails to provide the cringe-worthy, mouth-watering drama that we all secretly crave but then hate ourselves for secretly craving. In the Women Tell All episode last week we were left to stew over how that scoundrel software salesman Ben Higgins sent home the bubbly, fun-loving (fellow software salesperson!) Caila Quinn after he revealed his love for the other two remaining contestants, but not her. Shes among the favorites to be the Bachelorette next season, but alas: How cruel love can be sometimes.

4. The Walking Dead (AMC)

From our expert, Walking Ted Berg: The Walking Dead had some down moments earlier this season when it spent too much time dwelling on all the sheltered softies of Alexandria, but things have picked up lately now that Rick Grimes and his team have taken up contract killing in the zombie apocalypse.

Nothing good ever lasts in the Walking Dead world, but the discovery of trade partners for Ricks group adds exciting possibilities for their attempt to rebuild society and all the ways it will inevitably go awry.

5. Better Call Saul (FX)

The ratings may be sluggish, but this quirky prequel to Breaking Bad is finding its swagger in its second season, and people who love it really love it. Like, annoyingly so. Please, everyone who talks to me about this show: I get it. Its very good. Please leave me alone.

6. Blackish (ABC)

Were just a few weeks out after the show made the proverbial leap with a startling episode on police brutality, but this still feels like the most vital network comedy on right now ... and it isnt particularly close.

7. Billions (Showtime)

This show followed the rules of success for a prestige TV show a little too closely (kick off with a sex scene to hook the viewers! big names and salty language!) but its good fun, and more programming about the dirty deeds of the obscenely wealthy is fine by me.

8. American Crime (ABC)

American Crime rebounded from an iffy first season and bounced back with a spectacular second ... which now looks like may be its last.

This is show creator John Ridley in Vulture:

I really believe in my heart that in the end everything is going to work out the way it needs to work out. I could not have had bigger and better supporters than ABC. Im not saying that in the past tense as if there wont be a third season. But other than sitting around in passing thinking about what stories I want to engage in, I really havent gone through the process in thinking a lot about the show. Irrespective of what happens, ABC has done something that is just singular.

9. House of Cards (Netflix)

Much like Downton Abbey, Im not sure many people kept watching this show after a main character beefed it at the end of season one. (Spoiler alert, I guess, whatever.) But people are still apparently down with Kevin Spacey looking into the camera and talking to them, and theres still buzz going on this thing, but I will say Im glad its over and done with.

10. The Voice (NBC)

It. Will. Not. Die.

11. Vanderpump Rules (Bravo)

Ive never seen this show but everyone else at FTW freaked out when I initially left it off this list, and theyre still mad at me that its not in the Top 10. I will watch it this weekend, though, because I care about this list and all of you. I will dive headfirst into the Vanderpump. I am become Vanderpump.

12. Broad City (Comedy Central)

If you arent following along with their live-tweeting of episodes, you arent living.

WUT YA FAVORITE RAT NAME  Broad City (@broadcity) March 10, 2016

13. Fresh Off the Boat (ABC)

This show continues to be wonderful, and managed to pull off something this past week I wasnt sure was possible, a network TV episode that addressed the difficulties of platonic friendship between males and females without devolving into Youre in the friend zone, BROSEPH idiocy. Not enough people watch this show.

14. Vinyl (HBO)

Vinyl isnt good per say, but people seem to like it and talk about it. I like Bobby Cannavale, I dont know why they dont use Olivia Wilde more, and the rest of the show is a big ole pile of meh.

15. Crazy Ex-Girlfriend (CW)

A musical TV show based off an overplayed meme continues to be one of the most refreshing things on television. Miracles happen. MIRACLES ARE REAL.

16. Full Frontal with Samantha Bee (TBS)

I feel like this is the month that people have woken up to the fact that this show is as interesting, necessary and funny as anything John Oliver and Trevor Noah are doing. Samantha Bee is doing it, gang.

17. Jane The Virgin (CW)

Our second CW show in the power rankings! Trying to describe the plot to this show is pointless  the last episodes have featured a broken proposal, an FBI investigation, new love, and a woman artificially inseminating herself with a turkey baster (seriously)  but if youre going to have campy fun, why not have like all the campy fun?

18. Girls (HBO)

This show doesnt much feel vital anymore, but recalling Hannah from Iowa back to New York has at least made Girls feel like Girls again. Listen, I am 100% certain someone can make a show set in Iowa that is wonderful. The person who makes that show should be from Iowa. This show is not that.

19.Gotham (Fox)

I didnt know anyone else still watched Gotham, but the ratings for the show are chugging along, and I still crack up whenever that slimy bro whos supposed to be young Penguin shows up on screen. He took Todd from Wedding Crashers and turned him into a super villain, and every time he shows up I cant stop myself from hooting and clamoring for him to tell that mean ocean.

20. Pretty Little Liars (Freeform)

Am I the only person who cant tell any of the characters on this show apart?

21. Last Week Tonight with John Oliver (HBO)

Give John Oliver a week, hes going to give you a 7-minute segment that will be eminently shareable on the internet. He is the Aggregator King.

22. Its Always Sunny in Philadelphia (FXX)

This show may be running out of ideas, but its absolutely delightful watching them try stuff out in its eleventh season. Some of the jokes hit, some miss, but theyve got total freedom and are making some of the weirdest comedy out there. Plus they did that Wade Boggs episode last year had me laughing as hard as I have at anything in a long time. Thats baseball, baby.

23. Love (Netflix)

I love this show for the reasons I love Judd Apatow projects and I hate this show for the reasons I hate Judd Apatow projects. There are moments of divine comedy that feel honest and earned, and theres a bunch of stuff that doesnt seem to matter and the entire thing is twice as long as it needs to be.

24. Togetherness, HBO

Ive never seen this show but my boss Jamie Mottram said to put it on here for all the dads and Im no idiot so heres the show my boss wanted on the list.

25. Man Seeking Woman (FXX)

From Ted Berg, who Im convinced is the only person alive who watches Man Seeking Woman, and for whom I did a favor by including this show on the list: Man Seeking Woman takes a somewhat familiar sitcom theme  a single guy living in a big city, looking for love  and puts a surreal twist on it, examining the trappings and triumphs of relationships in a refreshing and hilarious light. Recent episodes in the shows second season have been some of the series strongest, focusing on Joshs unrequited love for Rosa, the flirty work-crush who wont even kiss him in the dying moments of humanity as a giant asteroid bears down on Earth.

column3: George Karl to undergo procedure for cancer on Thursday
column5:
Jan 14, 2016; Salt Lake City, UT, USA; Sacramento Kings head coach George Karl works the sideline in the second quarter against the Utah Jazz at Vivint Smart Home Arena. Mandatory Credit: Jeff Swinger-USA TODAY Sports (Photo: Jeffrey Swinger, Jeff Swinger-USA TODAY Sports)

Sacramento Kings coach George Karl will undergo a cancer-related procedure on Thursday, according to the Sacramento Bee.

"I'm having a procedure for a cancer in my throat," he said after Wednesday night's loss to the Cleveland Cavaliers.

The Bee also reported that the procedure isn't serious, but that Kings general manager Vlade Divac told him to "take as much times as he needs."

Karl, a survivor of prostate cancer in 2005 and head and neck cancer in 2010, is in his second season with the Kings, and currently sits in fifth place on the NBA's all-time winningest coaches list with 1,167 victories and counting.

Their next game is at home against the Orlando Magic on Friday night, and it is not yet known if Karl will be able to attend.

Follow AJ Neuharth-Keusch on Twitter @tweetAJNK

column3: Obama says he's not to blame for the GOP 'crackup' that led to rise of Trump
column5:
President Obama speaks during a joint news conference with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau in the Rose Garden of White House Thursday. (Photo: Susan Walsh, AP)

WASHINGTON  President Obama rejected a theory Thursday that the once-improbable nomination of Donald Trump to succeed him is the result of the political polarization and active use of executive power that have characterized his presidency.

"I've been blamed by Republicans for a lot of things," Obama said, "but being blamed for their primaries and who they're selecting for their party is novel."

The explanation that Obama is responsible for Trump's rise was advanced by, among others, columnist Ross Douthat in the New York Times last month: "It isnt an accident that this is the way the Obama era ends  with a reality TV demagogue leading a populist, nationalist revolt."

Obama repeated his State-of-the-Union pledge to work for more civility in politics. "But what I'm not going to do is validate some notion that the Republican crackup that's been taking place is a consequence of actions that I've taken."

Obama said it was the Republicans who have adopted an us-versus-them, absolutist governing style which is "creating an environment where somebody like a Donald Trump can thrive."

"And in fact, in terms of his positions on a whole range of issues, they're not very different from any of the other candidates," he said. "Mr. Trump might just be more provocative in terms of how he says it but the actual positions aren't that different."

Obama's comments came during a news conference in the White House Rose Garden Thursday with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau. In a way, Obama was the first to bring up Trump, joking that "every time we have a presidential election, our friends to the north have to brace for an exodus of Americans who swear they'll move to Canada if the guy from the other party wins."

Trudeau, who has jokingly backed an Internet campaign to attract people to Canada if Trump wins, was more diplomatic in the Rose Garden.

"The relationship, the friendship between our two countries goes far beyond any two individuals or any ideologies," he said. "I have tremendous confidence in the American people and look forward to working with whomever they choose to send to this White House later this year."

column3: Pedro Alvarez adds power, left-handed bat to Orioles lineup
column5:
Pedro Alvarez agreed to a one-year deal with the Orioles. (Photo: Butch Dill, USA TODAY Sports)

SARASOTA, Fla.  The Baltimore Orioles have added even more offensive firepower to their lineup, making official Thursday an agreement with free agent slugger Pedro Alvarez on a one-year contract.

Alvarez was the No. 2 overall pick by the Pittsburgh Pirates in the 2008 draft, and since his first full season with the Pirates in 2012, he ranks 11th among all major league hitters in home runs.

The move to the American League will likely mean Alvarez will see most of his at-bats as a designated hitter.

Im very grateful for the opportunity to be here, Alvarez said. Obviously Ill be seeing a different group of pitchers, but we all watch enough baseball to know what everybody can do. Its just a matter of going out there and getting some experience.

The addition gives the Orioles another left-handed batter in an everyday lineup with six players whove had at least one 30-homer season in the majors. Manager Buck Showalter said hes looking at Alvarez to be more than just a DH against right-handed pitching.

I dont really go into it with any preconceived ideas, Showalter said. I know hes going to give us the ability to do a lot of different things and make everybody else better.

In 2013, Alvarez led the National League with a career-high 36. However, he also led the league in strikeouts that year  and his all-or-nothing approach at the plate is a trait he shares with several others in the Orioles lineup.

Orioles first baseman Chris Davis led the majors in strikeouts last season with 208 and offseason acquisition Mark Trumbo whiffed 132 times in 508 at-bats in 2015.

Im aware of it, but as long as the contact-to-damage ratio is high, Showalter said about his lineup of free-swingers. I know what it looks like, but Im looking forward to finding out.

The addition of Alvarez is expected to at least soften the blow of losing free-agent outfielder Dexter Fowler to the Chicago Cubs. The Os were believed to be close to reaching an agreement with Fowler on a multiyear deal two weeks ago, only to have it fall through when Fowler re-signed with the Cubs.

column3: Student wants Justin Bieber to say sorry for uses wrong verb form in song
column4: ['University Of Michigan', 'Michael Schramm', 'Courtney Rozen', 'Varsity Tutors', 'Jillian Deutsch', 'Sam Lisker']
column5:
It turns out Justin Bieber made a grammatical mistake in his song Boyfriend, and one student isnt having it.

According to a Facebook post by a UK teacher, one of her students penned a letter to Bieber about his incorrect usage of the subjunctive in his 2012 song.

In the song you can be heard  on a number of occasions  stating If I was your boyfriend: here you have clearly used the subjunctive mood incorrectly. The correct lyric should, in fact, be If I were your boyfriend. This is a very common mistake made by the general public today the student wrote.

The student continued, stating: If current performers, such as Beyonce, can write a song using the subjunctive mood correctly, so must you.

Were hoping is that it isnt too late for Bieber to say sorry.

Michael Schramm is a student at University of Michigan and a USA TODAY College digital producer.

column3: All rise! 9 amazingly feminist Ruth Bader Ginsburg quotes in honor of her new book
column5:
Ginsburg, taking us to church. (Photo: Jessica Hill, AP)

Get your pre-orders ready: the Notorious RBG's wisest words are getting the hardcover treatment.

Ahead of My Own Words, a new collection of Chief Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg's best writings and speeches coming in 2017, we revisit some inspiring words on feminism and gender equality from the Supreme Court's elder stateswoman.

1. On an all-female Supreme Court: "Now the perception is, yes, women are here to stay. And when Im sometimes asked when will there be enough [women on the Supreme Court], and I say 'When there are nine,' people are shocked. But thered been nine men, and nobodys ever raised a question about that." in a 2012 interview at the University of Colorado in Boulder

2. On unconscious bias: "I think unconscious bias is one of the hardest things to get at. My favorite example is the symphony orchestra. When I was growing up, there were no women in orchestras. Auditioners thought they could tell the difference between a woman playing and a man. Some intelligent person devised a simple solution: Drop a curtain between the auditioners and the people trying out. And, lo and behold, women began to get jobs in symphony orchestras."in a 2014 interview with Elle

3. On women and equality: "Women will have achieved true equality when men share with them the responsibility of bringing up the next generation."in a 2001 interview with The Record

4. On her definition of feminism: "I think the simplest explanation, and one that captures the idea, is a song that Marlo Thomas sang, 'Free to be You and Me.' Free to be, if you were a girldoctor, lawyer, Indian chief. Anything you want to be. And if youre a boy, and you like teaching, you like nursing, you would like to have a doll, thats okay too. That notion that we should each be free to develop our own talents, whatever they may be, and not be held back by artificial barriers." in a 2012 interview with Makers



5. On the dangers of young women growing up with feminism:One thing that concerns me is that todays young women dont seem to care that we have a fundamental instrument of government that makes no express statement about the equal citizenship stature of men and women. They know there are no closed doors anymore, and they may take for granted the rights that they have. in a 2014 interview with The New Republic

6. On cementing equal rights in the Constitution: "I remain an advocate of the equal rights amendment, I will tell you, for this reason: because I have a daughter and a granddaughter, and I would like the legislature of this country and of all the states to stand up and say, 'We know what that history was in the 19th century, and we want to make a clarion call that women and men are equal before the law, just as every modern human rights document in the world does since 1970.'" at her 1993 Senate confirmation hearings

7. On her fellow justices: "I was a law school teacher. And thats how I regard my role here with my colleagues, who havent had the experience of growing up female and dont fully appreciate the arbitrary barriers that have been put in womens way." in a 2015 interview with Bloomberg

8. On making yourself heard: "I don't know how many meetings I attended in the '60s and the '70s, where I would say something, and I thought it was a pretty good idea. ... Then somebody else would say exactly what I said. Then people would become alert to it, respond to it."

"It can happen even in the conferences in the court. When I will say something  and I don't think I'm a confused speaker  and it isn't until somebody else says it that everyone will focus on the point."in a 2009 interview with USA TODAY

9. On the importance of powerful women in male-dominated spaces: "I always thought that there was nothing an antifeminist would want more than to have women only in womens organizations, in their own little corner empathizing with each other and not touching a mans world. If youre going to change things, you have to be with the people who hold the levers." in a 2009 interview with The New York Times

To holding the levers!

Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/1piG90h

column3: PSG can clinch title this weekend
column5:
(Photo: The Associated Press)

MONACO (AP)  Having sealed a place in the quarterfinals of the Champions League, Paris Saint-Germain can clinch a fourth straight French title this weekend if results go its way.

If Monaco fails to beat Reims at home on Friday and PSG wins at Troyes on Sunday then PSG will seal its sixth French title overall.

PSG has won just one of its past four league games, but they were played around the two legs against Chelsea in the last 16 of the Champions League and coach Laurent Blanc rested key players.

The dropped points made no difference anyway, as PSG leads second-place Monaco by 23 points with only nine games remaining.

If not this weekend, Blanc's side can be crowned as champion the following week in front of its home fans when it takes on Monaco.

Here are some things to know about this weekend's games:

___

IBRAHIMOVIC'S TARGET: Zlatan Ibrahimovic, already PSG's all-time leading scorer with 137 goals, needs just two more to reach 100 in the French league.

He will fancy his chances of doing that on Sunday away to last-place Troyes, which has conceded 59 goals in 29 games, making it the worst defense in the league.

Ibrahimovic ended an uncommon mini-slump when he scored the second goal in a 2-1 win against Chelsea in the Champions League on Wednesday.

It was the imposing striker's first goal in four games, following some below-par performances against Lyon, Saint-Etienne, and Montpellier.

Ibrahimovic, who has 23 league goals so far, has nine games left to beat his personal best tally of 30, which he set with PSG three years ago.

PSG NEEDS VERRATTI: Although PSG got the better of Chelsea, PSG's midfield looked vulnerable without midfield dynamo Marco Verratti.

The Italian has been struggling with a groin injury and failed to make the starting lineup on Wednesday.

Without Verratti's quick passing and relentless harrying, PSG's central midfield was often under pressure. The aging legs of Thiago Motta mean he no longer covers the same ground as before, and he needs Verratti back by his side.

DRAW SPECIALISTS: Marseille either scores late goals or concedes late goals this season and the matches often end in draws.

The fact Marseille  the only French club to win the European Cup, back in 1993  languishes in mid-table is due in large part to its 14 draws.

On Wednesday, it conceded a late goal in a 1-1 draw away to Corsican side Gazelec Ajaccio, the week after scoring in injury time to salvage a 1-1 home draw against struggling Toulouse.

No other club has drawn more games than Marseille, which has one of the best away records and one of the worst at home.

The home record is so bad that Marseille has not won at Stade Velodrome since Sept. 13.

Marseille is away this weekend at Brittany-based side Lorient.

SAGNOL BANNED: Bordeaux coach Willy Sagnol has been handed a three-game ban by the French Football Federation for his behavior following a 4-3 loss against Nantes in the French Cup last month.

The FFF said on Thursday he was given the ban "because of his behavior" after Sagnol remonstrated vehemently with officials moments after the defeat.

That means the former France defender misses Saturday's game at Toulouse, a home game against Bastia, and the trip to Monaco on April 2.

Copyright 2016 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.

column3: Exxon beats Apple where it counts
column5:
Apple (AAPL) is No. 1 in most areas  except the one that matters most to many investors: dividends.

Apple edged out Exxon Mobil (XOM) as the most valuable company in the world years ago with a market value of more than $740 billion. And despite Exxon reporting better-than-expected profit $4.9 billion in the first quarter, Apples made much more: $13.6 billion.

But the area Exxon Mobil is still top is in the sheer amount of dividends it pays out. Exxon is again the largest dividend payer at a $12.2 billion annual rate, says Howard Silverblatt of S&P Dow Jones Indices. The oil giant edges out Apple at $12 billion.

Apples total dividend payout has fallen because the companys number of shares outstanding has dropped due to stock buybacks, Silverblatt says. The total dividend payout is the dividend per share times the number of shares outstanding.

But at a share level, Exxon still trumps Apple, too. Exxon yields 3.3% vs. 1.6% for Apple.

column3: TV show power rankings; Downton Abbey takes the No. 1 spot
column4: ['Hemal Jhaveri', 'Ted Berg', 'Charles Curtis', 'Luke Kerr-dineen', 'Nate Scott', 'Nina Mandell', 'Laken Litman', "Nate Scott Is A Writer Editor At Ftw Leading The Site's Culture Coverage He Likes Writing About Soccer Basketball Music Tv The Evils Of The Ocean"]
column5:
Here it is, a brand spanking new feature: A weekly power ranking of the 25 most vital shows currently on TV.

How am I judging it? The criteria is murky, though it factors in ratings, command of the zeitgeist, and quality. Basically: Are people watching it? Are people talking about it? And is it any good?

My own critical input is obviously a factor, but Im not going to put a show I personally love in the top spot every week, or else wed just have Match of the Day and Its Always Sunny In Philadelphia alternating as the winner indefinitely. Also, it has to be airing new episodes. Also, Im excluding news programming. Its all vital and important and shouldnt be held up to or compared to The Voice.

Here they are:

1. Downton Abbey (PBS)

Downton Abbey starts and ends its time in the FTW weekly TV power rankings No. 1 spot. Did most of us stop watching the show after that (spoiler alert) handsome blond dude beefed it? Yes, yes we did. But the loyal hangers on got to say their goodbyes this week, and in honor of that, we hand it the crown. Goodbye, sweet Downton. I always liked that dog in the opening credits.

2. American Crime Story: The People vs. O.J. Simpson (FX)

The best show on television as far as Im concerned. The dramatic look back at the O.J. Simpson trial started as a slightly kitschy nostalgia party with a miscast lead and WAY too much Kardashian kids, but man, this show gets better and better every week.

Once the show shifted focus from David Schwimmer and Cuba Gooding Jr. (as Robert Kardashian and O.J. Simpson, respectively) and realized the heart of the show was with Sterling K. Brown, Sarah Paulson and Courtney B. Vance (playing Christopher Garden, Marcia Clark and Johnny Cochran) the whole thing took off. Twenty years ago, I thought I never wanted to see another minute of the O.J. Simpson trial. I was wrong.

3. The Bachelor (ABC)

From my colleague Luke Kerr-Dineen, who at first claimed he didnt watch the show before sheepishly admitting that he watched the show:

The self-regenerating reality show never fails to provide the cringe-worthy, mouth-watering drama that we all secretly crave but then hate ourselves for secretly craving. In the Women Tell All episode last week we were left to stew over how that scoundrel software salesman Ben Higgins sent home the bubbly, fun-loving (fellow software salesperson!) Caila Quinn after he revealed his love for the other two remaining contestants, but not her. Shes among the favorites to be the Bachelorette next season, but alas: How cruel love can be sometimes.

4. The Walking Dead (AMC)

From our expert, Walking Ted Berg: The Walking Dead had some down moments earlier this season when it spent too much time dwelling on all the sheltered softies of Alexandria, but things have picked up lately now that Rick Grimes and his team have taken up contract killing in the zombie apocalypse.

Nothing good ever lasts in the Walking Dead world, but the discovery of trade partners for Ricks group adds exciting possibilities for their attempt to rebuild society and all the ways it will inevitably go awry.

5. Better Call Saul (FX)

The ratings may be sluggish, but this quirky prequel to Breaking Bad is finding its swagger in its second season, and people who love it really love it. Like, annoyingly so. Please, everyone who talks to me about this show: I get it. Its very good. Please leave me alone.

6. Blackish (ABC)

Were just a few weeks out after the show made the proverbial leap with a startling episode on police brutality, but this still feels like the most vital network comedy on right now ... and it isnt particularly close.

7. Billions (Showtime)

This show followed the rules of success for a prestige TV show a little too closely (kick off with a sex scene to hook the viewers! big names and salty language!) but its good fun, and more programming about the dirty deeds of the obscenely wealthy is fine by me.

8. American Crime (ABC)

American Crime rebounded from an iffy first season and bounced back with a spectacular second ... which now looks like may be its last.

This is show creator John Ridley in Vulture:

I really believe in my heart that in the end everything is going to work out the way it needs to work out. I could not have had bigger and better supporters than ABC. Im not saying that in the past tense as if there wont be a third season. But other than sitting around in passing thinking about what stories I want to engage in, I really havent gone through the process in thinking a lot about the show. Irrespective of what happens, ABC has done something that is just singular.

9. House of Cards (Netflix)

Much like Downton Abbey, Im not sure many people kept watching this show after a main character beefed it at the end of season one. (Spoiler alert, I guess, whatever.) But people are still apparently down with Kevin Spacey looking into the camera and talking to them, and theres still buzz going on this thing, but I will say Im glad its over and done with.

10. The Voice (NBC)

It. Will. Not. Die.

11. Vanderpump Rules (Bravo)

Ive never seen this show but everyone else at FTW freaked out when I initially left it off this list, and theyre still mad at me that its not in the Top 10. I will watch it this weekend, though, because I care about this list and all of you. I will dive headfirst into the Vanderpump. I am become Vanderpump.

12. Broad City (Comedy Central)

If you arent following along with their live-tweeting of episodes, you arent living.

WUT YA FAVORITE RAT NAME  Broad City (@broadcity) March 10, 2016

13. Fresh Off the Boat (ABC)

This show continues to be wonderful, and managed to pull off something this past week I wasnt sure was possible, a network TV episode that addressed the difficulties of platonic friendship between males and females without devolving into Youre in the friend zone, BROSEPH idiocy. Not enough people watch this show.

14. Vinyl (HBO)

Vinyl isnt good per say, but people seem to like it and talk about it. I like Bobby Cannavale, I dont know why they dont use Olivia Wilde more, and the rest of the show is a big ole pile of meh.

15. Crazy Ex-Girlfriend (CW)

A musical TV show based off an overplayed meme continues to be one of the most refreshing things on television. Miracles happen. MIRACLES ARE REAL.

16. Full Frontal with Samantha Bee (TBS)

I feel like this is the month that people have woken up to the fact that this show is as interesting, necessary and funny as anything John Oliver and Trevor Noah are doing. Samantha Bee is doing it, gang.

17. Jane The Virgin (CW)

Our second CW show in the power rankings! Trying to describe the plot to this show is pointless  the last episodes have featured a broken proposal, an FBI investigation, new love, and a woman artificially inseminating herself with a turkey baster (seriously)  but if youre going to have campy fun, why not have like all the campy fun?

18. Girls (HBO)

This show doesnt much feel vital anymore, but recalling Hannah from Iowa back to New York has at least made Girls feel like Girls again. Listen, I am 100% certain someone can make a show set in Iowa that is wonderful. The person who makes that show should be from Iowa. This show is not that.

19.Gotham (Fox)

I didnt know anyone else still watched Gotham, but the ratings for the show are chugging along, and I still crack up whenever that slimy bro whos supposed to be young Penguin shows up on screen. He took Todd from Wedding Crashers and turned him into a super villain, and every time he shows up I cant stop myself from hooting and clamoring for him to tell that mean ocean.

20. Pretty Little Liars (Freeform)

Am I the only person who cant tell any of the characters on this show apart?

21. Last Week Tonight with John Oliver (HBO)

Give John Oliver a week, hes going to give you a 7-minute segment that will be eminently shareable on the internet. He is the Aggregator King.

22. Its Always Sunny in Philadelphia (FXX)

This show may be running out of ideas, but its absolutely delightful watching them try stuff out in its eleventh season. Some of the jokes hit, some miss, but theyve got total freedom and are making some of the weirdest comedy out there. Plus they did that Wade Boggs episode last year had me laughing as hard as I have at anything in a long time. Thats baseball, baby.

23. Love (Netflix)

I love this show for the reasons I love Judd Apatow projects and I hate this show for the reasons I hate Judd Apatow projects. There are moments of divine comedy that feel honest and earned, and theres a bunch of stuff that doesnt seem to matter and the entire thing is twice as long as it needs to be.

24. Togetherness, HBO

Ive never seen this show but my boss Jamie Mottram said to put it on here for all the dads and Im no idiot so heres the show my boss wanted on the list.

25. Man Seeking Woman (FXX)

From Ted Berg, who Im convinced is the only person alive who watches Man Seeking Woman, and for whom I did a favor by including this show on the list: Man Seeking Woman takes a somewhat familiar sitcom theme  a single guy living in a big city, looking for love  and puts a surreal twist on it, examining the trappings and triumphs of relationships in a refreshing and hilarious light. Recent episodes in the shows second season have been some of the series strongest, focusing on Joshs unrequited love for Rosa, the flirty work-crush who wont even kiss him in the dying moments of humanity as a giant asteroid bears down on Earth.

column3: Sen. Lindsey Graham warns GOP obstruction on judges cuts both ways
column5:
Sen. Lindsey Graham, R-S.C. (Photo: Susan Walsh, AP)

Sen. Lindsey Graham, R-S.C., on Thursday ruefully endorsed his party's refusal to consider a Supreme Court nominee offered by President Obama, saying that while he understands the political reality, he believes the Senate's own precedents are being destroyed.

At a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing Thursday, senators of both parties returned to the talking points they have batted back and forth since the moments after the Feb. 13 death of Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia. Republicans, led by chairman Chuck Grassley, R-Iowa, said there is no point having a hearing on any Obama nominee because, during the current presidential election cycle, there is no way a nominee would be confirmed.

"A Supreme Court nomination in the middle of a presidential campaign would be all politics, and no Constitution," Grassley said.

Democrats argued that this is a violation of the constitutional principle that the Senate must advise and consent on nominees, and there is no excuse for a delay.

Only Graham, having recently dropped his own presidential bid, veered off script.

"We are setting a precedent here today  Republicans are," Graham said, and henceforth no president will be able to nominate a Supreme Court justice in a presidential election year. "That's going to be the new rule."

"This is where we find ourselves," Graham said. "I am saddened by the fact the Senate has gone down the road we've gone. I'm very much supportive of what you're doing Mr. Chairman. I don't think you are doing anything wrong." At this moment in the Senate, he said, playing politics with judges appears to be appropriate strategy on both sides of the aisle.

But Graham also warned that Republicans are in danger of losing the 2016 presidential election to Hillary Clinton, and that if she becomes president, she will likely nominate someone more liberal than Obama would offer. "And I am going to vote for that person if I think they are qualified," Graham said, because he believes "the president of the United States deserves the right to pick judges of their philosophy. That goes with winning the White House,"

Some conservatives back in South Carolina were furious that Graham voted to confirm Obama's Supreme Court nominees Elena Kagan and Sonia Sotomayor, but he won re-election in 2014 anyway. He also helped negotiate a bipartisan deal in 2005 that allowed some of former President George W. Bush's judicial nominees to win confirmation without a major change in Senate rules.

Graham said those days of compromise may be lost if each party nominates judges from the far left or far right because Democrats changed the rules for lower court appointments in 2013 so they only need a majority vote. The party in power no longer needs a few votes from the other side to confirm lower-court judges.

"Over time the judiciary will be more ideologically driven," Graham said. "It's just a matter of time before the Senate becomes the House when it comes to judges and I really hate that."

Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/1piGK26

column3: Fisher says Barnes altercation not behind firing from Knicks
column5:
NEW YORK (AP)  Derek Fisher says his altercation with forward Matt Barnes had nothing to do with his firing as New York Knicks coach.

Fisher wrote Thursday in a first-person piece in Sports Illustrated's The Cauldron that the Knicks never mentioned his personal life or that players had lost confidence in him because of it when they fired him in January after 112 years.

The altercation with Barnes, now with the Memphis Grizzlies, took place in California in October when Fisher was at the home of Gloria Govan, Barnes' estranged wife. Barnes learned Fisher was there and showed up to confront him.

In the article titled "Truth ," Fisher says he didn't retaliate when Barnes started throwing punches and there was no fight, and that his relationship with Govan wasn't a secret from Barnes.

Barnes and Fisher were teammates with the Los Angeles Lakers from 2010-12.

Copyright 2016 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.

column3: AP sources: Jets sign Forte, Robinson, re-sign Powell
column5:
NEW YORK (AP)  Two people familiar with the decisions say the New York Jets have agreed in principle to sign free-agent running backs Matt Forte and Khiry Robinson, and re-sign running back Bilal Powell.

The people spoke to The Associated Press on Thursday on condition of anonymity because the Jets had not announced the signings.

After spending his first eight NFL seasons in Chicago, Forte will likely replace the departed Chris Ivory as the starter in the Jets' backfield. Forte, a two-time Pro Bowl selection, ranks second in Bears history to Hall of Famer Walter Payton in several categories, including yards rushing.

Robinson, coming off a broken leg suffered last November, rushed for 766 yards and eight TDs in three seasons with New Orleans.

Powell set a career high with 47 receptions for 388 yards and two touchdowns last season.

___

column3: TurboTax messed up, refunds customers
column5:
Investors outraged by TurboTax recent change that forced them to pay 50% more for the tax preparation software can put down their pitchforks. TurboTax isnt just apologizing, but will refund the money.

Beginning Friday, TurboTax maker Intuit (INTU) will issue $25 refunds to any TurboTax customer forced to buy the most expensive version of the companys software this year after buying the less-costly Deluxe version last year. Intuit has put a link up on its website (turbotax.intuit.com/25back) where TurboTax customers can claim their refund.

Theres been a uproar among TurboTax users this year after Intuit announced a major change that amounted to a price hike on investors. Starting this tax year, any investor who sold even a single share of stock was forced to buy TurboTax Premier, which is the most expensive consumer version of the desktop software. In years past, the Deluxe version would handle capital gains calculations.

TurboTax users have taken to the Web to protest the change, including writing scathing reviews at Amazon.com. Some even were switching to H&R Blocks competing software  as H&R Block (HRB) was luring the customers away.

In addition to refunding $25 to affected customers, TurboTax General Manager Sasan Goodarzi is issuing a lengthy written apology to TurboTax customers for the change. We messed up. We made a change this year to TurboTax desktop software and we didnt do enough to communicate this change to you as proactively and broadly as we could or should have. I am very sorry for the anger and frustration we may have caused you, says Goodarzi in a letter to customers that was shared with USA TODAY by Intuit.

The $25 refund will be offered to customers who bought TurboTax Deluxe desktop software and filed their 2013 return  and have to upgrade to TurboTax Premier or Home & Business to file their 2014 return.

I deeply regret the anger and distress we have caused those of you affected by this change, Goodarzi wrote in the statement. Our hope is that we can regain your trust and demonstrate that our commitment to you has never been stronger.

Follow Matt Krantz at www.twitter.com/@mattkrantz

column3: Olympians Mikulak, Orozco lead US men at Pac-Rim
column5:
INDIANAPOLIS (AP)  Three-time national champion Sam Mikulak and fellow 2012 Olympic teammates John Orozco and Jake Dalton headline the U.S. men's team at the 2016 Pacific Rim Championships in Everett, Washington, next month.

Donnell Whittenburg and Alex Naddour, both members of the U.S. team that finished fifth at the 2015 world championships, and Eddie Penev will also compete for the Americans from April 8-10.

Whittenburg is coming off a second-place finish at the American Cup last weekend. Mikulak finished fourth in his first international competition since recovering from a torn Achilles.

The six-man team has a combined six world championship and 14 Pacific Rim championships between them. The U.S. won the event last year. The Pacific Rims are the major international tune-up for the Americans before the 2016 Olympics.

Copyright 2016 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.

column3: Frenchman Nacer Bouhanni wins stage 4 of Paris-Nice race
column5:
ROMANS-SUR-ISERE, France (AP)  French rider Nacer Bouhanni outpaced his rivals in a sprint finish to win the fourth stage of the Paris-Nice race on Thursday, while Australian Michael Matthews retained the overall lead.

Matthews beat Bouhanni in controversial circumstances on Tuesday's second stage when Bouhanni was penalized for deviating from his line in the final sprint.

"This time there's no controversy, I won," Bouhanni said. "Of course I was a bit revengeful, what happened in Tuesday's sprint upset me, and I slept badly that night. It consumed a lot of my energy and I wanted this win to forget all of that."

Bouhanni held off Belgian rider Edward Theuns and Andre Greipel of Germany to win the 195.5-kilometer (121-mile) trek from Julienas to Romans-sur-Isere at the foot of the Vercors mountain range in the Alps of southeastern France.

Matthews leads Tom Dumoulin of the Netherlands by 14 seconds overall, with Patrick Bevin of New Zealand 19 seconds back in third place.

The standings are set for a shakeup on Friday, when Stage 5 takes the peloton up the famed Mont Ventoux, one of the most feared climbs on the Tour de France.

Copyright 2016 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.

column3: Treating the Homeless
column5: Street medicine providers care for the homeless wherever they happen to be. Physician assistant Brett Feldmans program, about an hour north of Philadelphia, has succeeded in reducing the number of repeat visitors to the ER. (March 10) AP

column3: Starlin Castro 3B experiment over
column5:
New York Yankees 2B Starlin Castro will no longer be playing at third base this spring. Manager Joe Girardi wants Castro to make sure hes comfortable at second.

Tip: It might be best for Castro, although he won't be able to gain another position for fantasy eligibility. Castro is still young and finished the second half strong with the Chicago Cubs. A move to Yankee Stadium could help him approach 20 dingers as a nice target in the middle rounds for your middle infield.

column3: Vikings finalize deals with LG Alex Boone, LB Emmanuel Lamur
column5:
(Photo: The Associated Press)

MINNEAPOLIS (AP)  The Minnesota Vikings have signed left guard Alex Boone and linebacker Emmanuel Lamur, finalizing contracts they agreed to on a busy first day of free agency.

The Vikings announced Thursday that the deals with Boone and Lamur were done, after both players passed their physical exams.

Boone, who has a four-year contract with a maximum value of $26.8 million and $10 million guaranteed, moved from San Francisco practice squad member in 2009 to starter on the 49ers' Super Bowl team in 2012. Boone has started 59 games over the last four seasons.

Lamur left Cincinnati after four years there. Vikings coach Mike Zimmer was his defensive coordinator with the Bengals during his first two seasons.

___

column3: University of Southern California tuition hike sparks student outrage
Nobel laureate Aung San Suu Kyi denied Myanmar's presidency
column4: ['Est March', 'Special For Usa Today', 'Lucy Kafanov', 'P M']
column5:
Aung San Suu Kyi, center, leader of the National League for Democracy (NLD) party, arrives to participate in a gathering with newly elected lawmakers of her party on March 10, 2016, in Naypyitaw, Myanmar. The NLD, which won November general elections by a landslide, nominated two Suu Kyi loyalists to contest the president's post. (Photo: Aung Shine Oo, AP)

YANGON, Myanmar  She is the iconic face of democracy in a country crushed by more than a half-century of military rule  a former political prisoner, Nobel laureate and the head of the National League for Democracy party, which saw a landslide victory in November.

But of all the titles granted to Aung San Suu Kyi in recent years, the president of Myanmar, for now, will not be one of them.

Her party ended speculation Thursday about a Suu Kyi presidency by nominating her longtime confidant U Htin Kyaw as the countrys likely first democratically chosen head of state. Another nominee, Henry Van Thio, is expected to become vice president. The military, which controls a quarter of the legislature, will also nominate a candidate.

After a brief vetting process, lawmakers will vote later this month, and the new president will be installed April 1.

In a statement issued hours before the nomination was revealed, Suu Kyi asked supporters to rally around the partys decision.

I would like to appeal for people to stand by the NLD with wisdom and farsightedness, she said. This is an important step in implementing the desires and expectations of voters who enthusiastically supported the NLD.

For months, Myanmar was abuzz with expectation that The Lady, as Suu Kyi is known here, would achieve the impossible: negotiate a deal with the military that would allow her to serve as president despite a constitutional provision barring her from the role.

While several rounds of closed-door talks failed to clear a path to power, Suu Kyi has vowed to rule Myanmar, formerly known as Burma, by proxy, from a position above the president.

The army will continue to play a key role in the incoming government by retaining control of three powerful ministries  defense, interior and border security  while also wielding influence over Myanmars economy through military-owned conglomerates and businesses with close ties to outgoing President Thein Sein's government.

Thant Myint-U, a historian who has advised the government and the grandson of the former United Nations secretary-general U Thant, said the developments are part of a political change that is real and will transform the country, but in exactly what direction is still difficult to say.

Were still working in a constitutional framework first conceived by the then military regime nearly 20 years ago, he said. It's far from a democracy, but it is the arrangement that has allowed the army to take a big step back from day-to-day administration and allow for a degree of political freedom that we haven't seen in over half a century.

Htin Kyaw, 69, the party's presidential candidate, is an Oxford graduate who runs the Daw Khin Kyi Foundation, an education charity named after Suu Kyis mother that assists people in Myanmar's poorest areas. A former classmate of Suu Kyis at a high school in Yangon, he is seen as a party loyalist whose wife is a prominent legislator.

The party's other nominee, Van Thio, is an ethnic Chin member of parliament who could play a key role in helping resolve long-standing ethnic conflict within Myanmar.

The new government faces many challenges that include multiple ethnic separatist insurgencies, poverty and corruption, plus economic stagnation stemming from years of neglect by the ruling military junta.

The country is also under pressure from the international community to address the plight of the stateless Muslim Rohingya  a long-oppressed group that has been denied citizenship rights and largely confined to displacement camps after a wave of anti-Muslim violence in 2012.

It is unclear what formal role Suu Kyi, 70, will play in the new government. Some analysts suggested that she could be angling to be foreign minister or might attempt to pull the strings as a senior minister in the cabinet. Her party has declined to comment about Suu Kyi's next step.

In Yangon, the euphoria expressed by pro-democracy supporters after the Nov. 8 election has been replaced with cautious optimism.

Many of us had hoped that (Suu Kyi) would find a way to lead the country, but it was obvious that the military was not going to make this easy, said Kaung Myat Linn, a political science major at Yangon University. This is a good step toward democracy, but we need to stay vigilant. The army still has a lot of power, and things can always take a turn for the worse.

Reporting for this article was supported by a grant from the International Reporting Project.

Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/1piIPuW

We knew the Lonely Island were going to rally all their famous friends to show up in their new, wonderfully-titled movie, Popstar: Never Stop Never Stopping.

column3: Nancy Reagan's personal touch
column5:
Nancy Reagan waves to the delegates at the Republican National Convention in 2000. (Photo: Eileen Blass, USA TODAY)

Nancy Reagan was both a throwback and a groundbreaker. And a romantic.

The 1980 election that sent Ronald Reagan to the White House was the first of the 10 presidential campaigns I've covered. The Reagans and I moved to the White House together, in a way. I became the White House correspondent for Newsday just as Reagan was being inaugurated.

And that was an event that ended up giving me a glimpse into Nancy Reagan I didn't expect.

She was famously wary of reporters. They criticized her husband, snooped into her personal life, wrote about her propensity for designer clothes (borrowed, as it turned out) and sparked a mocking "Queen Nancy" meme when she used private funds to buy a new set of White House china in the midst of a recession.

Her "Just Say No" anti-drug campaign was in part an effort to add another dimension to her image, and in 1982 I sat down with her during a trip to Florida she took to tout the initiative. When the interview was over, I mentioned that my newspaper's assigned seat at the inauguration had been next to The Baltimore Sun's. My seatmate and I struck up a conversation and then walked downtown together to our offices.

Now, I told her, we had gotten engaged  thanking her for the role they had played, inadvertent though it was.

The month before our wedding, a thick cream envelope addressed in calligraphy arrived in the mail. The Dutch may have been mystified about why, exactly, this particular couple warranted an invitation to the White House State Dinner for Queen Beatrix. I knew it was a wedding present, completely unexpected and quite gracious, from a woman who was more complicated than we gave her credit for at the time.

With the benefit of hindsight, I think those complications were a key reason Nancy Reagan had a rocky start with the press and the public.

In some ways, she revived the stereotype of the most traditional of first ladies  content to live in her husband's shadow, consumed with glittering social affairs and her Hollywood friends. Her immediate predecessor, Rosalynn Carter, had attended Cabinet meetings. The first lady before that, Betty Ford, was so candid that she created headlines her husband had to handle.

In contrast, Nancy Reagan seemed to be one of the ladies who lunch.

While it took us a while to realize it, though, she was also a trailblazer  a presidential spouse who became one of the president's most trusted advisers and moderating voices on public relations, personnel and even foreign policy. When it comes to the substance of the presidency, we now know that Nancy Reagan ranks as the most influential first lady to serve between Eleanor Roosevelt and Hillary Clinton.

She had political antennae her husband lacked to sense when aides were serving their own interests rather than the president's, and she helped engineer the exit even of a White House chief of staff in the wake of the Iran-contra scandal. (Donald Regan got his revenge a year later in his 1988 memoirs when he revealed she was relying on an astrologer to set the president's schedule.) She encouraged Reagan to negotiate with a new Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, at a time some advisers and many conservatives were skeptical and opposed.

By the time the Reagans moved out of the White House, it was clear that Nancy Reagan had a depth and a determination that hadn't been fully recognized at first. In the years that followed, during what she called their "long goodbye," her devoted care for her husband and her advocacy on Alzheimer's disease and stem-cell research made her a hero to many.

Nancy Reagan died Sunday at age 94 in Los Angeles. On Wednesday and Thursday, thousands of people paid tribute to her, streaming by her casket at the Reagan Presidential Library and Foundation in Simi Valley, Calif. She will be buried Friday on a hillside next to her beloved Ronnie.

And by the way, Carl Leubsdorf (now with The Dallas Morning News) and I will be celebrating our 34th anniversary this spring.

Page is USA TODAY's Washington Bureau chief.

Susan Page interviews then-first lady Nancy Reagan. (Photo: handout)

Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/1paXcAH

column3: Surprising St. Bonaventure nudges into NCAA Tournament talk
column5:
With all due respect to Andrew Nicholson, St. Bonaventure coach Mark Schmidt regards this season as one of his most satisfying.

And Schmidt makes that acknowledgement before the Bonnies have even secured an NCAA Tournament berth as they did four years ago during Nicholson's senior season.

What's different this year is how St. Bonaventure (22-7, 14-4 Atlantic 10) has worked itself firmly into the tournament berth conversation without an eventual NBA first-round draft pick such as Nicholson.

"With Nicholson, it was expected for us, and if we didn't do well in the Atlantic 10, it would've been a disappointing year," said Schmidt, referring to the now Orlando Magic forward. "Whereas this year, if we came in eighth or ninth, people would be like, 'Well, yeah, that's where they were picked.' But we've exceeded expectations, so it's gratifying."

St. Bonaventure is the third seed entering the A-10 tournament, which it will open on Friday in the quarterfinal round against an opponent not yet determined.

Despite a thin bench and a lineup featuring just two seniors, the Bonnies are coming off a year in which they set a school record for conference wins, matched another mark for regular-season victories and finished in a three-way tie for first alongside Dayton and VCU. As of Tuesday, the Bonnies' ratings-percentage index ranked 27th in the nation, and Monday, they attracted six votes in The Associated Press poll.

One more win might be enough, while reaching the championship game on Sunday would all but secure the Bonnies' seventh tournament berth and third since 2000.

This was hardly what Schmidt, the A-10's coach of the year, envisioned five months ago, never mind five weeks ago.

In October, he was more pre-occupied with having enough healthy players to hold a 5-on-5 scrimmage following injuries to Jordan Tyson and Courtney Stockard. Come late January, there were questions of whether the Bonnies had peaked following three consecutive losses to Duquesne, Dayton and VCU.

Instead, they responded by winning 10 of their final 11, including a 79-72 victory at then-No. 15 Dayton  St. Bonaventure's first road win against a ranked opponent, not including games played at neutral sites.

"No question, that was a signature win," Schmidt said of beating Dayton on Feb. 20. "That was the win that gave us the ultimate confidence of (saying): 'You know something, we can win every one one of these games going down the stretch."

St. Bonaventure is led by its guard tandem of senior Marcus Posley and sophomore Jaylen Adams. Senior forward Dion Wright rounds out the Bonnies top three by averaging 16.4 points a game and a team-best 8.8 rebounds.

With only three trusted reserves, St. Bonaventure relies on a patient approach on offense that leans heavily on ball movement to set up players for open shots.

Posley leads the team in averaging 19.3 points, and scored 47 points  the most by a Division I player this season  in a 98-90 win over Saint Joseph's on March 2. Adams had a flair for dramatics by hitting a 3-point shot at the buzzer to secure a 65-62 win over St. Louis on Feb. 7. And the Bonnies have shown resilience by winning seven games by five points or fewer.

"It's still crazy to think about it, but a lot of people really didn't see this happening for us," Posley said. "It's a special year for us. The team's matured a lot."

Posley first saw a glimpse of the team's potential in a 79-66 loss at Syracuse on Nov. 17. It was a game the Bonnies actually led for much of the first 30 minutes, before running out of steam. Another bright spot was how the team rallied back to nearly overcome a 31-point deficit in an 85-79 loss to Dayton on Jan. 19.

The second-half surge, in which the Bonnies outscored the Flyers 61-40, provided Posley and his teammates confidence that they could compete against Dayton in their rematch.

Schmidt credits Posley for leading the team on and off the court. In two seasons at St. Bonaventure, the junior college transfer has already scored 1,076 points.

"He's been so much for our team. Without him, we're not here," Schmidt said. "He's the leader of our team. He gives our guys confidence. And when he's playing at that level, we're a pretty good team."

column3: University of Southern California tuition hike sparks student outrage
column4: ['University Of Michigan', 'Morgan Buckley', 'Courtney Rozen', 'Varsity Tutors', 'Michael Schramm', 'Jillian Deutsch']
column5:
Tuition at the University of Southern California is now more expensive than Harvard, Princeton, Yale and Stanford. And students at the private university arent happy about it.

On Monday, they protested a tuition hike of nearly $2,000 for the 2016-2017 school year, which raised the annual cost of attendance to $51,442. But that cost per student reaches nearly $70,000 once housing costs and other fees are factored in. According to the College Board, the average annual cost of private colleges in the U.S., including tuition and fees, was $32,405 for the 2015-2016 school year.

When I was a freshman, a financial planner here told me I wouldnt have to take out student loans and I believed it, Victor Sherman, a senior studying environmental studies, says. But guess what? Later this week Im going to get a loan. I dont want it, but I need it. I dont have enough money to pay.

The tuition hikes comes after the Undergraduate Student Government passed a tuition freeze resolution in November in an attempt to prevent an increase from the 2015-2016 tuition rate. The group also requested more transparency from the university about its allocation of funds.

But the school upped the cost regardless.

A screenshot of the increased tuition for the 2016-2017 school year began circulating on social media last week, ultimately leading to Mondays rally. The protests, according to president of USCs student government Rini Sampath, are an extension of requests made in Novembers resolution.

Student protestors still want a tuition freeze, increased transparency, and student-involvement in tuition-related decisions, she says.

I think this rally is an opportunity for students to share their stories. This is real; this is human, Sampath says. This isnt another $2,000 students can just cough up. Its affecting people. People are considering transferring.

Cynthia Bondeel-Timmerman a senior Public Relations major is a first-generation college who says she feels privileged to be at USC. But she says she also struggles to stay afloat. Bondeel-Timmerman has juggled numerous jobs on top of course work since her freshman year, she says.

I want to be able to be here, and I want to be able to graduate, she says. But Im literally drowning in debt and I dont know why anymore.

And the hike has even made a prospective student reconsider attending the school. The high school senior says he stumbled upon the protest Monday while visiting campus and was so moved by the participating students stories that he joined in.

I applied here, and Im really glad I ran into this. . .because I dont want to come here anymore, the prospective student, who lives in Los Angeles and asked to remain anonymous, says. I saw the school as just a godly thing and to see this injustice, it was just wild. I was in shock and disappointed and scared and sad all at once.

According to a College Board study released in 2015, 48% of bachelors degree recipients graduate with more than $20,000 in student debt. In 2014, USC fell below the national average in debt incursion. Its 2014 graduating class owed an average of $28,500, while the national average was $29,00, according to the Los Angeles Times.

A $500 difference does not mean were doing a great job here at USC, Sampath says. We need to have a discussion and bring awareness to the issue.

USC says it grants two-thirds of its students with some kind of financial aid. The university self-reported that it grants 25% of students merit-based financial aid.

But students say this isnt enough.

USC Provost Michael Quick told the Daily Trojan, the universitys student newspaper, that the school is making strides in maintaining affordability while simultaneously working to remain competitive with other elite universities.

Were competing with the Stanfords and the Ivy League schools of the world, and when youre competing for best faculty in the world, thats expensive, Quick told the Los Angeles Times. As we build infrastructure, thats expensive.

But Alec White, a USG senator and USC senior argues that making college affordable for low-income students would help the university remain competitive. White says other elite universities have tuition payment minimums. In other words, some institutions dont require tuition from families who fall below a certain level of combined income and assets. Stanford, for example, does not make families with less than $125,000 in minimum assets and income pay any tuition.

We pay more tuition than Harvard and Stanford, White says. If USC wants to take the competition seriously and get Ivy League acceptees (sic) to come here, we really have to start giving them a reason to come here. We have to show them they can afford going to a world class university.

Protests concluded on Monday with a sit in at the Office of the Provost at USC. According to the rallys Facebook page, students are still committed to direct action to ensure their demands are heard by the USC administration.

The university has not yet issued an official response.

column3: Was Russell Westbrooks historic 25-10-20 stat line a sham?
column4: ['Hemal Jhaveri', 'Ted Berg', 'Charles Curtis', 'Luke Kerr-dineen', 'Nate Scott', 'Steven Ruiz', 'Nina Mandell', 'Laken Litman']
column5:
Russell Westbrook made history last night, recording the first 25-point, 10-rebound, 20-assist line since Magic Johnson in 1988. Or so we thought.

Upon further review, we have to call Westbrooks assist total into question. Heres his 13th assist of the night:

Luckily, NBA.coms awesome Video Boxscore allows us to confirm that Westbrook did, indeed, receive an assist for that Kevin Durant bucket even though he was not the one who made the final pass. (Click on the 20 in the assist column for Westbrook for a cut-up of his assists).

Per NBA.com, In basketball, an assist is awarded only if, in the judgement of the statistician, the last players pass contributed directly to a made basket. An assist can be awarded for a basket scored after the ball has been dribbled if the players pass led to the field goal being made.

Theres no grey area in this situation: The stat-keeper clearly erred in giving Westbrook the dime instead of Steven Adams, who not only made the pass but also set a screen to give Durant more room to make the shot. Adams was not credited with an assist during the game.

So that settles it: Westbrook should have been awarded for only 19 assists. What a scrub.

column3: Facebook CEO leads list of U.S. youngest
column5:
Being a CEO is a great gig if you can get it  so much so that many CEOs hang onto their jobs well into their 70s and 80s. But some CEOs are getting a jump start.

There are 10 CEOs of companies in the Standard & Poors 1500 index aged 40 or younger, according to a USA TODAY analysis of data from S&P Capital IQ. These CEOS, including Mark Zuckerberg at social networking king Facebook (FB), Joey Agree at real-estate firm Agree Realty (ADC) and Sardar Biglari of restaurant chain Biglari (BH) have reached the top of the corporate chain well before hitting their big 4-0. The ages are based on data from the companys most recent regulatory filings.

The average age of CEOs in the S&P 1500 is 56, giving you an idea of just how unusual these leaders are. But interestingly, the companies with the youngest CEOs have been outperforming the market  along with those with the oldest leaders. Shares of the companies with CEOs aged below 40 are up an average of 39.7% over the past two years. That beats the 36% gain of the S&P 1500 as a whole.

Theres no question some CEOs are self-made. Zuckerberg, co-founder of Facebook is a prime example. And theres certainly cases of the CEO position being a family affair. Joey Agree took over as CEO at Agree Realty after his father Richard Agree stepped down Jan. 7, 2013. Joey Agree was paid $1.7 million in 2013, and has served as the companys president since June 2009.

Judging a CEOs skill based on age alone isnt the most telling. But some of these young CEOs will face some major challenges this year, putting their experience to the test. Several of the youngest CEOs are in the energy sector, which is in upheaval due to the plunging price of oil. Northern Oil and Gas (NOG), led by 38-year-old co-founder Michael Reger explores for oil and natural gas in North Dakota and Montana. Shares have already been under pressure.

And Basic Energy (BAS) provides well site services for oil and natural gas drilling. Its led by 39-year-old Thomas Monroe Roe Patterson. Plummeting oil prices have not be flattering to this stock, either.

There are other companies with young CEOs that face indirect hits from oil. Era Group (ERA), for instance, provides helicopter transportation services to oil and gas companies as well as government agencies. CEO Christopher Bradshaw is 38.

Getting to the top isnt easy in the corporate world. But these CEOs will show investors if they have what it takes to stay there.

S&P 1500 COMPANIES WITH THE YOUNGEST CEOS

Company Symbol CEO CEO age Facebook FB Mark Zuckerberg 30 Agree Realty ADC Joey Agree 35 Biglari Holdings BH Sardar Biglari 36 Era Group ERA Christopher Bradshaw 38 Knight Transportation KNX David Jackson 38 Northern Oil NOG Michael Reger 38 Steven Madden SHOO Edward Rosenfeld 38 Basic Energy BAS Thomas Roe Patterson 39 Sensient Technologies SXT Paul Manning 39 Yahoo YHOO Marissa Mayer 39

Sources: S&P Capital IQ, USA TODAY research, limited to primary CEOs who reported age in regulatory filings

column3: ISIL steps up mustard gas attacks on Kurds in Iraq
column4: ['Est March', 'Special For Usa Today', 'Matthew Vickery', 'P M']
column5:
Kurdish Peshmerga forces detain suspected members of the Islamic State who mixed with a group of villagers fleeing to Sinjar, Iraq, a Kurdish-controled area on Nov. 16, 2015. (Photo: John Moore, Getty Images)

MAKHMOUR, Iraq  Ahmad Rasool, 21, was drinking tea with 20 other Kurdish soldiers when Islamic State mortars begun to hit. The Kurds were used to such attacks after battling the militants for more than a year, but this one was different: On impact, clouds of what turned out to be mustard gas filled the air.

"Suddenly I had to really scratch my back, Rasool told USA TODAY about the August 2015 attack. Red spots then started to appear on my skin like boils. ... I saw that some of the other soldiers, their skin and hands were swelling up.

Rasools position had been hit by what has been confirmed to be the first chemical weapons attacks on Iraqi soil since the late dictator Saddam Hussein unleashed chemical weapons against Kurds in 1988. Other Kurdish positions around Kirkuk and Gwer also were hit last summer.

Chemical attacks by the extremist group are becoming more frequent in Iraq, causing panic and disarray among soldiers and civilians alike, according to the Kurdish fighters, known as Peshmerga.

On Wednesday, the U.S. military revealed that it destroyed an Islamic State chemical weapons facility as a result of intelligence from a captured fighter who was a top chemical weapons official under Saddam.

Chemical weapons are banned under an international treaty signed in the wake of their lethal use during World War I.

Makhmour has been hit by four chemical attacks  chlorine and mustard gas  since the August strike, the soldiers said. Mortars made of metal pipes and more sophisticated 122mm Grad rockets carry the potentially deadly chemicals.

With the chemical attack it isnt clear what is going to happen, what the harm will be," Rasool said. "For me, it is more dangerous than a normal attack.

Kurdish Commander Mahadi Younis said he believed the weapons were being manufactured in nearby Mosul, the Islamic States stronghold in Iraq. Although they were crudely made and have caused no known fatalities yet, Younis said the militants likely will make them more lethal.

They are experimenting with new tactics, and new ways of fighting us, Younis said. They use anything they have to survive, without even considering the lives of civilians.

Malik Ellahi, a spokesman for the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, the international group that monitors illegal use of such weapons, told USA TODAY that the repeated reports of Islamic State attacks is a serious concern. Ellahi said the OPCW recently sent a team of experts to work with the Iraqi government to investigate the use of chemical weapons.

While the group has confirmed that mustard gas has been used, it has yet to confirm recent reports that the militants are now using chlorine. The alleged chlorine attacks include:

--On Feb. 25, the Islamic State launched 19 rockets on Sinjar, a remote corner of northern Iraq where the militants previously attempted to wipe out a local community of the Yazidi religious sect. Nearly 200 people were treated for severe vomiting, nausea, and headaches, according to local media reports and the Free Burma Rangers, a non-profit group of medics who work in the region.

--On March 2, the Tal Afar district near Sinjar was hit by at least six rockets seen emitting a yellow smoke on impact. Three civilians including two children were hospitalized with nausea, vomiting, and skin irritation, according to the International NGO Safety Organization, a British charity that supports the safety of aid workers. Taza, an Iraqi town near Kirkuk, experienced a similar attack on the same day, sending 40 people to Kirkuk General Hospital with similar conditions, the aid workers safety group said.

--On March 3, 20 rockets were fired at Keske Junction north of Mosul. Marwan Ahmad, 32, who lives in a small hamlet at the junction, described panicked scenes as the rockets rained down on the homes of civilians and the surrounding fields. He said only one rocket exploded, injuring a dozen people, while the other 19 lie embedded in the ground.

Ahmad, who was in his house when the attack began, said one landed just yards away. "I saw the smoke, and tears started running down my face, my skin was itchy, it started to go red, and bubbled up," he said. Ahmad said he had to be taken to a hospital and a cousin remains very ill from the attack.

Kurdish Lt. Muhammed Sabrihe said he fears the Islamic State is turning increasingly to easy-to-conceal chemical weapons as the militants lose ground to Kurdish fighters and Iraqi security forces aided by increased airstrikes conducted by a U.S.-led coalition.

Sabri said it is a sign of the militants desperation on the battlefield. Now we expect them [chemical attacks], he said. They have been weakened recently, and this is their response.

Follow Vickery @mmvickery

Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/1paZ78z

column3: 13 stocks with over-the-moon price targets
column5:
Everyone can use a good goal to shoot for. And theres nothing wrong with shooting for the moon. But some Wall Street analysts are giving stocks lofty targets that blur the line between ambitious and astronomical.

There are 13 stocks in the Standard & Poors 500, including drugmaker Merck (MRK), cosmetics company Avon (AVP) and retailer Michael Kors (KORS) that have at least one analyst with a price target thats 60% or higher than the current stock price, says a USA TODAY analysis of data from S&P Capital IQ.

Its very important to note this analysis is based on the absolutely highest recorded price targets  not the average ones, which are two completely different things. Price targets are based on where analysts see the stock headed up to 18 months from now.

The topic of the highest price target has become relevant again, as stocks blast past or rapidly approach their average targets thanks to the raging bull market. Its up to investors to decide if these extreme upside targets are prescient, or a sign of the top. Chipotle (CMG) on Tuesday gained $69.44 to $659.77, putting it in striking distance of the analysts average price target of $667. Thats why investors are now focused on the highest price target of $800 a share set Tuesday by David Tarantino of T.W. Baird.

But Chipotle is far from being the stock with the highest-of-the-high price targets compared to the current price.

Take the example of Merck. The highest price target on the stock is $125 a share, which is a staggering 114% upside from the Tuesday closing price of $58.43. That high per-share price target is quite a bit higher than the average, which is sitting at a significantly less lofty $64.47.

Another case in point is red-hot retailer Michael Kors (KORS). The highest price target is $134 a share, which is 63% higher than the Tuesday close of $82.22. But as high as that might be, its not all that far from the average price target of $107.50 a share.

Below is the list of 13 companies that have the highest-of-the-high-price targets, relative to the current prices (average price targets are included reference):

Company Symbol % upside to high target Average target Tues. close Chesapeake Energy CHK 150% $33.62 $26.85 Merck MRK 114% $64.47 $58.43 Peabody Energy BTU 98% $20.62 $15.18 Avon AVP 81% $16.21 $13.84 ADT ADT 78% $39.71 $33.16 Tesoro TSO 73% $67.25 $57.98 Wynn Resorts WYNN 69% $245.70 $207.29 Denbury Resources DNR 66% $21.10 $17.47 Intuitive Surgical ISRG 66% $461.06 $392.16 Michael Kors KORS 63% $107.50 $82.22 PVH PVH 63% $145.90 $110.80 Urban Outfitters URBN 63% $42 $33.84 Range Resources RRC 61% $101.10 $76.57

Sources: S&P Capital IQ, USA TODAY research

Some investors might be interested to see which stocks have the absolute highest-of-the-high-price targets (not relative to the current stock prices). You dont have to look far to see Chipotles famous $800-a-share high target. Not surprisingly, these are the companies with the highest current stock prices, including:

Company Symbol High stock target Tues. close Berkshire Hathaway BRK.A $225,000 $192,640 Priceline PCLN $1,592 $1,230.66 Chipotle Mexican CMG $800 $659.77 Google GOOGL $750 $603.57 Graham Holdings GHC $695 $694.82

Sources: S&P Capital IQ, USA TODAY research

Great expectations are fantastic if the stocks can keep up. But investors expecting the moon might be disappointed if they get anything less than that.
